story:
Summary

My name is Kate Burbeck. Some of you know me as a politely spoken children's librarian. Others will know me for my edgy, provocative, off-the-wall stand-up comedy. While living in Alice Springs I have also written short plays and experimented with spoken word performance. I have sometimes wondered why? Why have I dabbled in these arts? Now I know. The pieces of the puzzle have fallen into place and I have written a play. And I also know that I need your help because this is what I foresee:

The planets are aligning. The Earth is trembling with fearful anticipation. We must re-cali-brate our tools of prophecy. At the spring equinox of 2016, in the heart and soul of the driest continent on Earth, in Alice Springs, Australia, there will be a great flood of primordial juices - a Great Coming.

Welcome to my Cuntry: There's No One Here So Come On In is an absurdist, feminist journey of self-discovery, exploring time travel, the value of dreams and artificial intelligence. Blurring the line between satanic ritual and artistic performance, this play unveils the mystique of obscenity and its potential to unleash tremendous power. The great, terrifying 'nothing' is coming and the audience will journey with Kate Burbeck as she gazes down her own navel, looking for the cause of it all, for the very 'root of the cunt' (in the etymological sense).

Welcome To My Cuntry will be a theatrical experience like no other. Think Donnie Darko meets Carrie meets The Rocky Horror Picture Show on a stage. And you could be part of the show before the curtains are even raised.

By helping to make this production a success, you will be helping to bring my life's work to fruition.


What We Need & What You Get

I'm seeking to raise $15,000. By contributing to this campaign you will be assisting me to cover the costs of the production. This includes paying the director, the production manager, the musicians, the film and technical crew, as well as paying for props, costumes, the hire of the theatre and everything else that goes into creating a fantastic theatre production! With nine actors and musicians and a production team of seven people, this is not a small task and we want to make it work! 


The Impact

While Alice Springs has a healthy theatre sector, there is a strong need for further, ongoing stimulation of theatre production in this community. My project will deliver needed stimulation through a production grown and owned in Alice Springs. The presentation of this project as a theatrical production is dependent on support from artists and art workers within a community – it cannot be a 'one-woman' show. This is the biggest and most ambitious show I've ever created. Previously, I've have created and performed short pieces of stand-up comedy, short plays and spoken word. This is the first full length play that I have written and I am also producing it and performing in it. However, its success also depends on your support. I hope you will make a donation and I hope you will come to see it! By helping to make this production a success, you will be contributing to building a show which could be toured interstate, such as to the Adelaide Fringe Festival.

Risks & Challenges

All projects are not without risks. For example, a member of the cast may fall ill. Or the 100 year flood may actually arrive before the show starts and the Totem Theatre may be swept away!

But I can improvise and so can my team. I am a problem solver and I have the skills to make this project work. While undertaking a Bachelor of Information Studies over the past six years, I have learned about project management and leading and managing teams, among many other things. I also have many years of experience in organising and managing community events. Furthermore, having lived in Alice Springs for 12 years, I'm surrounded by a community of talented and clever people and I know they want to see me succeed.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute, you can still help my campaign. You can:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about Welcome To My Cuntry and my fundraising campaign.
  • You can use the Indiegogo share tools to put the word out on social media!

Thank you and I hope to see you at the Totem Theatre in Alice Springs in September, 2016!

story:
The Stage Play

A post-apocalyptic America struggles to survive. Among the survivors are six individuals, all with their own goals; their own objectives. Elizabeth, a tough yet worn woman is searching to know what happened to her family when the United States fell. On her journey, she meets Joshua, a young boy born into this torn world. Together they travel across the country, meeting new people and learning more about the world they live in, who to trust and how to survive the spread of a deadly virus.

The story of RESIDUE is told through deep, complex characters and relationships. My aim is to create a strong, entertaining piece of theatre that can really be performed anywhere, no matter what the size of the performance space.

RESIDUE is currently set to run at The Lost Theatre in Stockwell on Monday 17th July 2017.

Why We Need Funding

A small extract of RESIDUE was performed in London as part of a New Writing evening at The London College of Music. The response was overwhelmingly positive and we decided to take RESIDUE in it's entirety to The Lambco Fringe Festival. I have worked with Richard Lambert on the Lambco Fringe before, and they are incredibly supportive of new writing. This year, the Festival has moved to The Lost Theatre in Stockwell, London. Unfortunately, we are unable to afford the various costs of the theatre, tech and staff. On top of this, we need to advertise, we need to print programmes and pay for props/set. We are very excited to bring RESIDUE to The Lambco Fringe and beyond. We are only able to book 1 day of the Festival due to high demand from other producers, but if enough money is raised and there is enough demand, we will contact other theatres to extend RESIDUE's run.

Unfortunately, due to the rules and restrictions of both the festival and the theatre, we are unable to offer tickets as rewards for donating, and they will need to be purchased when booking opens. The theatre only seats 180 people, so hopefully we can fit in every backer. As mentioned above, if enough money is raised, we will explore a longer run at other theatres.

The Team

RESIDUE is directed by Aaron Hayes and Alex Friel and will contain beautiful, emotional underscoring by Alex Friel and Kelly Greenhalgh.
I am serving as writer and producer. RESIDUE is a very exciting opportunity for us, and we hope you can support us and come see the show this July.

RESIDUE will be recorded with multiple cameras to create a fully edited video of the performance. As well as this, a 360 Camera will be used to create a special RESIDUE VR Viewing Experience!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to back us here on IndieGoGo, you can help us by sharing our social media channels and telling your friends about us!

https://www.facebook.com/ResidueOnStage

https://twitter.com/residueonstage

Thank you for checking out our IndieGoGo page. We hope you enjoy RESIDUE: The Stage Play!

story:
Impronte is a contemporary dance performance based on my journalistic research on migration and the refugee crisis. The project is composed of four pieces, each adding a different perspective on the complexities of the migrant experience.

We are a group of seven artists, also a refugee from Africa is part of our team. The first of the four pieces uses a soundtrack a compilation of statements made by world politicians in the past two years as well as fragments from interviews with refugees. The second piece is based on the real story of a Syrian refugee, once a famous actor, who has been escaping for the past five years. The third piece is always site specific to the city where we perform (first performance was in Bologna, Itlay) and reflects on the migration story of each particular city we visit. In the case of Bologna, my journalistic research focused on the neighborhood  of Pilastro, suburb, which has been the centre of deep sociopolitical debate since it was once built in the 1960s as it welcomed migrants coming from the South of Italy.  The last piece of this project talks about the a different kind of border, the one between two people in a love relationship. As a whole, 'Impronte' focuses on the migration crisis, themes of identity, and love, struck by the fear and insecurity in today’s society.

We have had our first performance on the 8th of April at the Theatre DOM La Cupola in Bologna but we still need your help! This project has been partially funded by the Ministry for Cultural heritage and Activities in the Emilia-Romagna region but we are now asking for donations to help fund the remainder. 

We are kindly asking for your donation so as to ensure that all six of the very talented dancers and actors are compensated for their weeks and weeks of hard work. Furthermore, there we had extra production costs and are on a journey of taking this project further.

We hope that both those inside and outside of the arts community can give generously. Thank you for your donation!

The Italian dance magazine published this article on 'Impronte': 

http://www.danzaeffebi.com/dintorni-danza/isabe...

There where the border begins, ends my identity.

“We met there, you were different. You spoke another language”

“I was different. I didn’t speak your language”

“Your hand joined mine, but later a frontier separated us beyond seas”

Centuries later, my house was in flames and my fleeing steps created an abyss inside of me.


Impronte

Choreographed by Isabel Cuesta
 Dove inizia il confine e finisce la mia identità.

– Ci siamo conosciuti lì, tu eri diversa, parlavi un'altra lingua.

– Io ero diversa non parlavo la tua lingua

– La tua mano si incrociò con la mia, ma dopo una frontiera ci allontanò al di là del mare.

Secoli dopo la casa mia era in fiamme e i miei passi in fuga hanno creato un confine dentro di me.

story:
The Circus School of Atlanta - 

--Run away and join the Circus... School!--

"The Imperial OPA Circus" has been and continues to be a part of the circus and variety landscape of today. Our mission, since inception, is doing good through circus in specific, and entertainment in general.
Now, we're onto our newest phase - establishing a permanent home in the wonderful and historic Grant Park, right in Atlanta! 

Entertainment and community is our passion and we want to share that with as many people as possible. We believe circus is a community experience that breaks down walls and builds character. It teaches skills and builds talents that stay with you for a lifetime.
Our mission is to offer everyone the chance to learn these incredible art-forms by way of the air, ground, in-between, and eventually take to the stage! 
We truly believe in building future leaders of circus.  

Our Mission at the Circus School of Atlanta is to train and teach passionate people, offer an affordable performance space for the circus and variety arts, and establish ourselves as a beacon for the resurgence of circus in Atlanta!

Our Vision at the Circus School of Atlanta is to form a welcoming and non-judgmental home for students and guests alike.
A home for those wishing to feel safe in learning and growing, to exude confidence and build character. 
We would like to establish Atlanta as a circus and variety destination and inspire all those around us!

Meet some of our Amazing Circus Team

Tim Mack: Founder and Artistic Director

Tim has managed and ran The Imperial OPA Circus since 2005.
His sincere passion and livelihood are circus arts. From being a Ringmaster at the Smithsonian Folk Life Festival 2017, to traveling with Ringling Brothers and Cirque du Soleil, circus is what inspires him most in life.

Montana DeBor: Lead Aerial Director

Montana comes from Washington DC, where she founded the multimedia circus arts collaborative, Street Light Circus. She hs taught at the Trapeze School New York, DC. She’s performed at the White House, Smithsonian Folk Life Festival, Kennedy Center and as principal aerialist with Sweet Spot Aerial Productions.  She brings with her a long resume of instructor knowledge and leadership.  Her specialties include Spanish Web and aerial fabric along with a wide array of music, visual arts, and show design skills.

Ian "Trick" Harvey: Show Manager

Ian joins us from New York, New York. Coney Island is where he established himself as a sideshow performer and talker. His illustrious background includes stage lighting, sound design, clowning, sideshow and the circus arts.
He will be spearheading rental of the space, along with programming for stage craft, whip cracking, character work, and other physical performance classes.

The Circus School of Atlanta: Details

The Circus School of Atlanta is in the heart of Grant Park and easily accessible by public transit. It features 2,000 square feet, 20’ rigging points, stained glass windows, great energy, and endless potential.

The Stage.

We aim to transform this historic space into a place for any kind of performance.
The stage is 23’ wide and  10’ deep, and elevated about 1.5’ up, and seats a capacity of 200 people.
Oh, the possibilities!

--Current on the left; future plans on the right--

--8 aerial points at 20’ high, soon to expand by 5 points at 30’--

--Wide open spaces for lots of different circus and variety arts - tumbling, stretching, yoga, juggling, and much, much more!--




What We Need

To fully realize this space we need $70,000.
We are currently making use of private loans and our own out-of-pocket investments.

We're well on our way, but we still need your help!

The more equipment and safety gear we have, the more we can offer you. The funds raised through this campaign will enable us to acquire circus equipment, finish building out the space, and get us started on the right (and left) foot!

With your assistance, we can make this space truly magical, fun and circus ready!

What's in it for You?

All your contributions go towards launching The Circus School of Atlanta at its’ best.
Truly, without you, this cannot happen -
We’re here for you *and* because of you!

There are a wide selection of donation levels that allow you to contribute directly to the circus community. From our personal thanks, to hosting your very own circus party, the choice is truly yours! 
If you think of something additional to your donation, (depending on your contribution level), write to us and let us know!
We’re very flexible, and we love to collaborate.

With your contribution, we can bring the circus to kids 1 to 100, professionals and novices, hobbyists or full-time circus artists alike.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that not everyone will be able to support our project financially, but there are other ways to help make our school a reality!

Do you know anyone who might want to support this school? Please share this campaign with your friends and family!

When we get off the ground, we’ll need students. Come take a class or tell your family, friends, coworkers, neighbors, or strangers about our location.

We’d love to see you there!

Above All - THANK YOU!

With all our hearts, we thank you for your support.
Together, we can spark a resurgence of circus in Atlanta, and provide a home for an artform that thrives in the spotlight!

See you on down the road, and as always,

OPA!

story:
THE CAUSE 

CushmanCollected.com has the potential to be the largest electronic collection of theatre criticism by a single writer, and an invaluable record and resource for generations to come. By supporting its creation, you are helping to preserve and pay tribute to decades of achievement in Canadian and British theatre.


THE SITE 

CushmanCollected.com will assemble all of Robert Cushman's critical writing, including his work for The Observer (1973 - 1984), Plays and Players (1966 - 1987), The Globe and Mail (1988 - 1998) and The National Post (1999 - 2017). Through the site, readers will have free access to over 3000 reviews and articles, with the ability to:

  • Read Cushman's critical analysis of some of the most seminal productions of the past 50 years, including world premieres by Stephen Sondheim, Harold Pinter, Tom Stoppard and Andrew Lloyd Webber.  Also will include in depth interviews conducted with major theatre and cultural icons such as Ian McKellen, John Gielgud, Trevor Nunn and Rosemary Clooney. 
     
  • Compare copious reviews of the entire Shakespeare canon, including virtually every production at the Stratford Festival over the past 20 years. 
     
  • ​Navigate this expansive body of work with key search terms that will allow you to read everything Cushman's written on a specific theatre artist, play or company.
     
  • In addition to his theatre reviews, read Cushman coverage of landmark events in popular song, literature, film and television (including his series reviewing every episode of the final season of The Sopranos).   

    And: 
     
  • Read regular new reviews from Canadian theatre's leading critical voice


THE WORK AHEAD

Over the past months, we have been working with a professional archivist to create a comprehensive plan and source material for the site. 

Now, in order to fully realize this unprecedented digital collection, we need to raise $10,000:

  • $5000 for the archivist to convert and index over 3000 articles, spanning a dozen different publications in multiple formats (we've been given a quote of 200 hours, @ $30/hr.).  
  •  $4000 to employ a web developer to design the layout and searchable database infrastructure of the site. 
  • $1000 for the domain start-up costs and monthly hosting fees.  

 

A LIFE IN THE THEATRE 

Robert Cushman was born in London, and educated at Cambridge University. He went from there to the BBC where he worked in radio drama, TV arts programs, and for the World Service. He then directed in the London and regional theatre, and was theatre critic of The Observer from 1973 to 1984. He moved to Canada in 1987, and has been theatre critic of the National Post since its inception in 1999. He has written extensively for other British and Canadian newspapers and magazines, and for the New York Times. He has continued to work in the theatre as an author, director and even performer; the musical "Look to the Rainbow" about the life and work of Yip Harburg, which he devised and directed, was produced in the West End in 1985. He was director of corporate communications for Livent Inc. in 1998-99. He has also been a prolific broadcaster, especially on musical theatre and American popular song; popular series include Book, Music and Lyrics (BBC) and Songbook (CBC) and, as a cabaret performer, he has sung the songs himself.  His book Fifty Seasons at Stratford, a history of the Stratford Festival, was published in 2002; and he is a record eight-time winner of the Nathan Cohen Award for Excellence in Theatre Criticism. He was also named by Intelligent Life, a spin-off of The Economist, as one of the four top theatre critics in the world.
story_txt:
THE CAUSE CushmanCollected.com has the potential to be the largest electronic collection of theatre criticism by a single writer, and an invaluable record and resource for generations to come. By supporting its creation, you are helping to preserve and pay tribute to decades of achievement in Canadian and British theatre.THE SITE CushmanCollected.com will assemble all of Robert Cushman's critical writing, including his work for The Observer (1973 - 1984), Plays and Players (1966 - 1987), The Globe and Mail (1988 - 1998) and The National Post (1999 - 2017). Through the site, readers will have free access to over 3000 reviews and articles, with the ability to:
Read Cushman's critical analysis of some of the most seminal productions of the past 50 years, including world premieres by Stephen Sondheim, Harold Pinter, Tom Stoppard and Andrew Lloyd Webber.  Also will include in depth interviews conducted with major theatre and cultural icons such as Ian McKellen, John Gielgud, Trevor Nunn and Rosemary Clooney.  
Compare copious reviews of the entire Shakespeare canon, including virtually every production at the Stratford Festival over the past 20 years.  
​Navigate this expansive body of work with key search terms that will allow you to read everything Cushman's written on a specific theatre artist, play or company. 
In addition to his theatre reviews, read Cushman coverage of landmark events in popular song, literature, film and television (including his series reviewing every episode of the final season of The Sopranos).   And:  
Read regular new reviews from Canadian theatre's leading critical voice
THE WORK AHEADOver the past months, we have been working with a professional archivist to create a comprehensive plan and source material for the site. Now, in order to fully realize this unprecedented digital collection, we need to raise $10,000:

$5000 for the archivist to convert and index over 3000 articles, spanning a dozen different publications in multiple formats (we've been given a quote of 200 hours, @ $30/hr.).  
 $4000 to employ a web developer to design the layout and searchable database infrastructure of the site. 

$1000 for the domain start-up costs and monthly hosting fees.  
 A LIFE IN THE THEATRE Robert Cushman was born in London, and educated at Cambridge University. He went from there to the BBC where he worked in radio drama, TV arts programs, and for the World Service. He then directed in the London and regional theatre, and was theatre critic of The Observer from 1973 to 1984. He moved to Canada in 1987, and has been theatre critic of the National Post since its inception in 1999. He has written extensively for other British and Canadian newspapers and magazines, and for the New York Times. He has continued to work in the theatre as an author, director and even performer; the musical "Look to the Rainbow" about the life and work of Yip Harburg, which he devised and directed, was produced in the West End in 1985. He was director of corporate communications for Livent Inc. in 1998-99. He has also been a prolific broadcaster, especially on musical theatre and American popular song; popular series include Book, Music and Lyrics (BBC) and Songbook (CBC) and, as a cabaret performer, he has sung the songs himself.  His book Fifty Seasons at Stratford, a history of the Stratford Festival, was published in 2002; and he is a record eight-time winner of the Nathan Cohen Award for Excellence in Theatre Criticism. He was also named by Intelligent Life, a spin-off of The Economist, as one of the four top theatre critics in the world.

story:
The Trifecta Dance Collective (TDC) is excited to enter its third season with a renewed vision of infusing an artistic presence into the communities we serve. 

Since its inception in 2016, the company has collaborated with local organizations to fulfill its mission:

We hope to engage audience members to be educated about the communities they are a part of.

Individuals will be empowered to take action and positively enhance their communities.

The ripple effect will engulf others and expand into a wave of compassion and action.

 

The company has launched itself into the contemporary dance scene with great tenacity. TDC has  performed in several Chicagoland showcases and have brought the mission nationally to New York, Michigan, West Virginia, Oklahoma, Wisconsin, and Minnesota.

What We Need 

  • We are hoping to raise $7,000 to bring the project to life on the stage.  We wish to rent a ballroom and have a big band play to bring this part of the women's history to life.
  • Putting together a collaboration such as this is no small feat. We need support to make our vision a reality.  The theater rental, technical fees, live musicians, artist fees, and marketing fees are necessary to put all of these pieces together as we envision. The TDC directors and collaborators strive to be an artist voice to the communities we serve. This project enables us to inspire the community as we honor the women in the project.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't contribute now? We understand, but would love it if you could do any/ all of the following:

  • Spread the word about In.grained with friends and family.
  • Share this indiegogo!

story:
SAVE THE DATE!

Our show is June 17-19th, 2016 at University Settlement Speyer Hall. Stay tuned for ticketing information!

Short Summary

ANDREW  JANNETTI & DANCERS has been in existence since 1982. Since that time Mr. Jannetti has choreographed over 35 pieces for his company, which has performed throughout the United States and Europe.  In addition, Mr. Jannetti has had his choreography commissioned by the American Ballet Russe of Long Island, The Fort Wayne Dance Collective of Indiana, Dance Designs, American Dance Ensemble, The Moving Company of Newport, R.I., Kids Cafe Festival, Jan Gero, Ed Brodkin, and various summer festivals throughout the metropolitan area.

JESSICA LEWIS ARTS is a modern dance company focusing on historically based modern dance forms and integration with multimedia, interdisciplinary works, theater, and new choreographic endeavors. The company is a collaborative project which is lead by Artistic Director and Founder Jessica Lewis. Jessica Lewis Arts has performed throughout the NYC Metropolitan area and is under the umbrella of Andrew Jannetti & Dancers, with whom she has performed since she was 12 years old.

Andrew Jannetti & Dancers and Jessica Lewis Arts have joined forces to present an evening of new works as well as works from the repertory. This concert features choreography by Andrew Jannetti and Jessica Lewis with original music scores by Marty Beller and Adam Caine, as well as a live musical performance lead by Adam Caine. In addition, guest choreographer Kriota Willberg will be reconstructing one of her solos for Mr. Jannetti.

What We Need & What You Get

We are looking to raise $5,000 to cover our basic production costs. In exchange for your donation there are a number of "Perks" you can receive depending on how much you donate. Check out the "Perks" page. Andrew Jannetti & Dancers has a long history of raising money for concerts and presentations. We are thrilled to have Jessica Lewis Arts join us in this joint venture and look forward to bringing in new donors and audience members to our campaign.

The Impact

Money raised during this campaign is going toward the salaries of the dancers, musicians, and composers. Your contribution will directly effect our ability to insure that these talented artists and performers get paid. You have the satisfaction of knowing that you helped to put these performing artists on the stage.

Risks & Challenges

As with all live performances there are many logistics to put in place and keep track of. Just getting everyone in one place for a group rehearsal can be challenging not to mention coordinating composers, lighting designers, costume designers, set designers, stage managers, back stage help, photographers, graphic designers, and a press representative. Luckily we have years of experience to fall back on and a network of professionals that enjoy working with our companies. Drawing on all of our contacts from young professionals starting out to seasoned performers and artists we are able to put together a team that is truly supportive and works well collaboratively. Our biggest challenge is raising the money to pay for all of this. That is where you, our donors and contributors, come in. Without your support and interest in our work none of this would be possible.

Other Ways You Can Help

You can help in more ways than just donating money. We can always use volunteers to assist backstage, at the box office, distributing flyers, and getting the word out over the internet. So after you make your donation pass this info on to all of your friends interested in performance and at the very least get them to come to our concert in June. It takes all of us working together to create a truly successful performance season.

story:
What is it?

Anna Michael recently directed the show, The Most Massive Woman Wins, which explores women's body image. With Leigh Honigman, they are looking to further explore activism and awareness of issues regarding body image, eating disorders, and the female experience by constructing a performative workshop with eating disordered women. Through this work, they will explore the question:

To what extent can theatre act as an agent of change in a woman’s relationship to her body? 

With the data from this workshop, they will devise their own documentary theatre piece for the purpose of prevention and awareness, that will be staged in the upcoming year.

What We Need

Workshop Space

$1200

 (meeting twice a week for six weeks)


Travel

$450

(commuting to meeting spaces, orchestrating travel for workshop participants)


Research

$350

(access to literature, libraries, and museums necessary to formulate workshop)


The Impact

According to the National Eating Disorders Association, prevention programs can alter knowledge, attitudes and behaviors associated with eating disorders and disordered eating. Through this workshop and subsequent devised piece, they aim to create a dialogue and raise awareness about body image and eating disorders by taking this piece to college campuses and beyond. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please contribute and share!

story:
In occasione dell’importante anniversario dei quattrocento anni dalla morte del creatore del Teatro Moderno, il Teatro Argot Studio e il Teatro Sala Uno nel centro di Roma e il Teatro Comunale Camploy e Casa Shakespeare a Verona, ospiteranno dal 19 al 30 aprile la prima edizione del festival Shakespeare Re-Loaded, realizzato in collaborazione con Casa Shakespeare, Teatro Azione, KIT Italia, Kairos  Italy  Theater,  Sycamore T-Company.

Shakespeare Re-Loaded è un festival dalla forte vocazione internazionale,  importante è infatti il contributo del Globe Theater di Londra che arricchirà la manifestazione con interventi video durante l’evento di apertura - mirato ad approfondire con ospiti di prestigio alcune tematiche legate alla riscrittura delle opere di Shakespeare – previsto per il giorno lunedì 18 aprile dalle ore 19.30 presso il Teatro Sala Uno.

La manifestazione sarà dislocata tra le due città italiane shakespeariane per antonomasia, Roma e Verona, ospitando per la prima volta in Italia due compagnie provenienti dalle scene di New York e di Londra insieme a sette spettacoli prodotti da alcune fra le più interessanti compagnie della scena contemporanea italiana, che da tempo dedicano il proprio lavoro alla rielaborazione di testi shakespeariani.

Abbiamo bisogno del vostro aiuto per sostenere le spese necessarie ad ospitare le due compagnie estere ospitate nel nostro festival che sono i BEDLAM di New York
e il Brite Theatre di Londra e, in mancanza di sostegni istituzionali di qualsiasi tipo, a coprire le spese di organizzazione e promozione del festival stesso. In cambio avrete locandine firmate dagli artisti e pezzi della collezione privata riguardante i maggiori film shakesperiani realizzati, in special modo di Kenneth Branagh e Franco Zeffirelli.

Qui potete trovare il calendario della nostra manifestazione vi ricordiamo che ogni singolo centesimo donato non sarà sprecato, ma utilizzato per la maggior gloria del nostro Amato Bardo..:)

CALENDARIO SPETTACOLI

“Cry Havoc”
Bedlam Company, New York
by K.I.T. Theatre
SALAUNO TEATRO – 19 e 20 Aprile 2016

“Whisper out loud”
Teatro Kabalà

SALAUNO TEATRO - 21 Aprile 2016

“Amore & Shakespeare”
Compagnia Malapassione
di e con Beatrice Zuin e alla chitarra Claudio Moro
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE – 21 Aprile 2016

“Enrico V - conquisterò la Francia”
Sycamore T. Company – Casa Shakespeare
di e con Solimano Pontarollo
SALAUNO TEATRO – 22 Aprile 2016
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE - 30 aprile 2016

“Io non sono come voi”
Compagnia i Demoni di Milano
Drammaturgia Alberto Oliva e Mino Manni
da William Shakespeare
regia Alberto Oliva
con Mino Manni
SALAUNO TEATRO – 23 e 24 Aprile 2016

“Vestimi bene e poi uccidimi” | studio su Ofelia
di e con Federica D’Angelo e Ksenija Martinovic
supervisione artistica: Marcela Serli
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE 19 e 20 aprile 2016
ARGOT TEATRO – 26 e 27 Aprile 2016

“Romeo and Juliet - original language”
Produzione Shakespeare in Veneto
con Giulia Tomelleri, Riccardo Maschi, Giorgia Olivieri, Diane Peters
regia di Solimano Pontarollo
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE – 26 Aprile

“Othello - original language “
Produzione Shakespeare in Veneto
con Giuseppe Savio, Amir Segal, Francesco Martucci, Giulia Bisinella
regia di Solimano Pontarollo
TEATRO CAMPLOY – 28 Aprile

"Richard III, A One-Woman Show"
Di e con Emily Carding
Regia di Kolbrun Bjort Sigfusdottir
by Infallible London
ARGOT TEATRO – 28 Aprile
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE – 29 APRILE

“Shylock”
Compagnia Dei Demoni, Genova
di Gareth Armstrong
Traduzione e adattamento Francesca Montanino
Diretto e interpretato da Mauro Parrinello
CANTINA SHAKESPEARE 23 e 24 aprile 2016
ARGOT TEATRO – 29 E 30 Aprile

story:
The Festival and the Play

The Thespis Festival in New York City has only been around for five years, and is already one of the largest and most highly renowned one-act play festivals in the country.  It was created by a group of playwrights who—after their own experiences having their plays produced in festivals—came together to create the ultimate festival.  It takes place at the Hudson Guild Theatre in downtown Manhattan, a beautiful and well-appointed 99-seat proscenium space.

I’m Jonathan Samarro, and my recently published play, Grandma Serafina’s Famous Tiramisu, has been one of the plays selected for this year’s festival.

The play, itself, is an homage to my grandparents—both Italian immigrants who lived on the outskirts of New York, just across the river in Hackensack, New Jersey. While the play certainly takes great pleasure in celebrating their culture, it also explores how its patriarchal traditions leave little room for people to honor their authentic selves. Through its comedy, the play examines the pain of not being “seen” by one’s family and the pain of surrendering one’s true self to accommodate familial expectations. At the comic center of the play is Serafina, whose lifelong surrender has at long last taken a wicked little turn.

 

What We Need

If you don’t already know, in festival theatre, playwrights act as their own producers, but with the Thespis Festival, playwrights are not only provided with a beautiful theatre space, but also an online ticketing service and access to a wide selection of furnishings, lights, and audio equipment—keeping production costs to a minimum.

To make our show happen at this year’s festival, we need your help to cover some of the remaining production costs—including costumes, props, programs, and renting rehearsal space.  Any donation you can make would be appreciated.

Thank you for your help in making Grandma Serafina's Famous Tiramisu a part of this year’s Thespis Festival.

 

What You Get

Aside from supporting the arts, there are some cool perks that come with donating! These include:

  • A special thank you in our program.
  • A special thank you video from the cast and crew.
  • For donations of $250 or more, you get your own signed copy of the published play.

 

Can't Donate?

Don't sweat it!  There are other ways you can help:

  • Purchase tickets for the production by clicking HERE.
  • Share this page with your friends.
  • Purchase a copy of the play by clicking HERE.
  • Like my page on Facebook by clicking HERE.

story:
Synopsis

A Chinese grandmother, her son, and her granddaughter are confronted with the dilemmas in a rapidly changing world order caused by accelerated global warming. Set 30 years from now, Amber explores daily life in a world irrevocably transformed by climate change. Faced with the prospect of a dismal future, what does hope look like to subsequent generations of people?


Short Summary

Hello! My name is Krys Yuan, a young Singaporean theatre maker who is writing and directing Amber, a play to be presented at Vancouver Fringe Festival 2016 as part of The Only Animal’s Generation Hot. Generation Hot is a series of plays written and directed by young people reacting to the ongoing climate change crisis. My team and I are incredibly excited to see Amber becoming a reality in the making, but it is need of some financial help along the way. 

As young people growing into “Generation Hot”, the impacts of climate change have become the reality that our generation lives with, and the stakes are high. The stories we tell about climate change are as important as the facts and numbers.  One often hears “think of your children!”, but we hardly do because we know that the story of the future is bleak. In the play, a Chinese grandmother, her son, and her granddaughter are confronted with the dilemmas caused by accelerated global warming, but still find hope in each other. What if we can too?

It is through theatre that one can combine empathy and urgency to target the heart of the problem of inaction. By putting Asian voices up on stage, the play also seeks to represent alternative narratives in the climate change conversation. The Fringe is an excellent platform to showcase these perspectives and stories, especially those in a position to make large-scale change happen.

I would like to invite you to contribute to this unique and valuable production with your generous donation.  Every bit matters. Your support for our project goes beyond just monetary compensation - any amount donated gives us greater courage and confidence in our efforts. In return, we are glad to reward you with perks (listed on the side), to show our appreciation for your support.


Thank you so much,

Krys Yuan

On behalf of the cast and crew of Amber:

Wynn Siu, Johnny Wu, Kerensa Cooper, Miranda Sandberg, Joel Grinke, Hannah Cavers, Sydney Burstein



Specific details

Outside of creative, logistical and financial support that The Only Animal provides, the remaining production costs $2000. Currently, this is being sourced from my own income as a research assistant. Any amount that you donate will help recoup my own financial losses, and relieve a strain on my resources.

Your money will go towards:

  • Providing honourariums for the artists involved, reinforcing an ethical standard of treatment towards freelance art-makers.

  • Rental of rehearsal space

  • Production and acquisition of set, costumes, and props

  • Cost of printing

If we don’t reach our target, the money will primarily be channelled towards the provision of honorariums, and rental of rehearsal space. 

Perks: Video recording
The lovely folks at The Only Animal are able to provide videography of the final show, and a copy of the recording for non-commercial use only. This means that the video recording will be uploaded online, and a private link will be sent out to you, once we are ready to deliver the perks!
Perks: Sticker designs
As a way to thank you for your support, our graphic designer Sydney has made some stickers of images related to the show. Below are the designs offered:

1) Chopsticks

Food is the centre of life, and every Chinese family.

2) Pearl + Oyster

"The world is mine oyster, which I with sword will open." - William Shakespeare

3) Fish

"Government officials say that despite the fishing ban...."

4) Koala bear

"WEILING: Always with that teddy bear of yours...
AMBER: It's a koala bear!"

5) Fish + the City


Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute to this campaign, do not fret! Help us by:

  • Buying a ticket to our show! Just $12, and a memorable evening. Bring your friends, your family, your pets!
  • Sharing this via Facebook, Twitter, Whatsapp, or just by word-of-mouth!

If you have any questions or requests, feel free to contact Hannah Cavers at hficavers@gmail.com, or Krys Yuan at krysyuanyj@gmail.com.

SynopsisA Chinese grandmother, her son, and her granddaughter are confronted with the dilemmas in a rapidly changing world order caused by accelerated global warming. Set 30 years from now, Amber explores daily life in a world irrevocably transformed by climate change. Faced with the prospect of a dismal future, what does hope look like to subsequent generations of people?Short SummaryHello! My name is Krys Yuan, a young Singaporean theatre maker who is writing and directing Amber, a play to be presented at Vancouver Fringe Festival 2016 as part of The Only Animal’s Generation Hot. Generation Hot is a series of plays written and directed by young people reacting to the ongoing climate change crisis. My team and I are incredibly excited to see Amber becoming a reality in the making, but it is need of some financial help along the way. As young people growing into “Generation Hot”, the impacts of climate change have become the reality that our generation lives with, and the stakes are high. The stories we tell about climate change are as important as the facts and numbers.  One often hears “think of your children!”, but we hardly do because we know that the story of the future is bleak. In the play, a Chinese grandmother, her son, and her granddaughter are confronted with the dilemmas caused by accelerated global warming, but still find hope in each other. What if we can too? It is through theatre that one can combine empathy and urgency to target the heart of the problem of inaction. By putting Asian voices up on stage, the play also seeks to represent alternative narratives in the climate change conversation. The Fringe is an excellent platform to showcase these perspectives and stories, especially those in a position to make large-scale change happen.I would like to invite you to contribute to this unique and valuable production with your generous donation.  Every bit matters. Your support for our project goes beyond just monetary compensation - any amount donated gives us greater courage and confidence in our efforts. story:
WHAT WE NEED:

Pittsburgh in the Round will use this $3,000 to file a proper LLC, pay for our domain and web hosting renewal, have a functioning marketing budget, acquire security software to protect the site from any potential threats, secure an office space, pay for liability insurance through our fiscal sponsor New Sun Rising, and put us on track to being sustainable enough to pay our staff and writers.


WHO WE ARE:

Pittsburgh in the Round is currently Pittsburgh’s only locally run magazine strictly dedicated to promoting theater and dance in the Steel City. With over 60 theater companies and more than 30 venues, Pittsburgh’s theater community is blossoming and lacks proper resources to compliment this growth. After operating on a volunteer basis for over two years, Pittsburgh in the Round is ready to step into the business world by paying its writers, offering advertising space, and giving its administrators the financial freedom to dedicate the time and energy this project deserves.

Pittsburgh in the Round currently averages 94 views per day, since we rolled over from being The Pittsburgh Stage to Pittsburgh in the Round in November of 2015, and this number is steadily rising. We have achieved this on a shoestring marketing budget, with no office space, run by a staff of two, with a fluctuating writing team. Pittsburgh in the Round offers a lot to the theater community by covering theater and dance events, providing an all inclusive event calendar, keeping up with a directory of theater companies and venues, offering an outlet to those passionate about theater and journalism.


WHAT WE DO:

Pittsburgh in the Round provides comprehensive information about the local theater community to the Greater Pittsburgh area. We promote the diverse and ever-growing theater scene in Pittsburgh; treating every company equally, benefiting artists and audiences alike. What sets Pittsburgh in the Round apart is the specificity of our coverage and belief that no company or show is too small.

Pittsburgh in the Round strictly covers companies and shows produced locally, within a 25 mile radius of Downtown Pittsburgh. We provide readers with tools such as all-inclusive calendars, reviews, and features on local theater events, people,  and companies. It could be a long time subscriber looking for information about a particular company’s upcoming season, or a family visiting from out of state, wanting to take in a show. Our goal is to act as an information center for anyone in the Greater Pittsburgh area with an interest in theater. In addition to audiences and enthusiasts, we want to provide useful information to artists and industry professionals. We distribute information regarding hiring and auditions as well as reviews that provide constructive criticism and praise.


WHAT YOU CAN DO:

If you have a few spare dollars to spend, why not spend them on a worthwhile project? The team here at Pittsburgh in the Round is hardworking and dedicated and we will not let your donation go to waste. Our perks range from a simple shout out or thank you note to a lunch date with the editor or tickets to a show this summer or fall! There's something for everyone on Pittsburgh in the Round. Anyone investing or sponsoring Pittsburgh in the Round is investing in a new generation of a rich cultural history of Pittsburgh.

Even if you can't donate to our cause now, you can share this campaign with your friends on social media and tag us in it! We have a Facebook, a Twitter, and now an Instagram! There are lots of ways to get a hold of us and lots of ways to spread the word!

If you're interested in being a contributor at Pittsburgh in the Round, let us know at info@pghintheround.com!


OUR HISTORY:

After moving back to East Coast upon finishing an internship at the La Jolla Playhouse, Founder Mara Nadolski found herself unsure of how to navigate the close knit theater community in Pittsburgh. While living in San Diego, there were many informational outlets for theater artists such as San Diego Theater World and Actors Access but found that there were no proper directories or all-inclusive event calendars in Pittsburgh. In November of 2013 Nadolski decided that she would do it herself and launched The Pittsburgh Stage with local playwright and former Carnegie Mellon University professor CS Wyatt in January of 2014. Marketing and Development Director Jack Lake joined the team in summer of 2014 as a writer and began brainstorming leading this operation into being a sustainable business.

After operating under the name The Pittsburgh Stage for nearly 18 months, Wyatt supplied TPS with a new webmaster, CMU student James Ormond, and gave Nadolski legal control of the website. The team relaunched and rebranded as Pittsburgh in the Round with a redesigned layout in November of 2015. After operating on a strictly volunteer basis for nearly two and a half years, Pittsburgh in the Round is ready to take this enterprise to the next level.

Pittsburgh in the Round received a fiscal sponsorship from New Sun Rising in May of 2016 and can now start accepting tax deductible donations and apply for grants. For more information about New Sun Rising click here.

If you would like to know more about who we are, what our goals are, or if you'd like to make a donation larger than $500, please contact us at info@pghintheround.com.

story:
The Living Theatre, the longest running experimental theater company co- founded by Judith Malina and Julian Beck in 1947, is about to embark on a three week journey across the United States of America for the Know Your Rites Tour.   

As the US becomes increasingly disillusioned and mired in the election process, with thousands of votes swallowed in the system, with government power based on hate, war mongering and corporate influence, mass murders prompted by bigotry and fear, a flood of refugees from countries the US has destabilized through war, we choose this time to travel through the middle of America to offer another story.

We seek a reawakening of one’s rights and rites.   We will travel to large metropolises as well as small towns to hold mass public rituals in the streets, at corporate headquarters, bank lobbies, fossil fuel sites of destruction.  We will lead non-violent direct action trainings.  We will perform an updated revival of one of the most significant shows in our repertoire, Seven Meditations on Political Sado-Masochism, a piece created by the company after being released from a prison in Brazil focused on the torturous abuses by the Brazilian police.

We take up charge of Judith Malina, an indefatigable source of radical artistry.  In her name and to honor her legacy, we trek across the states offering a version of the Beautiful Non-Violent Anarchist Revolution.


The Know Your Rites Tour begins on August 15, 2016 in New York City.  



THIS IS WHAT WE WILL OFFER:

- Performances of "Seven Meditations on Political Sadomasochism" 

A visceral examination of the social contract between the governed and the government, Seven Meditations was written after Malina and members of the company were imprisoned-and some tortured-by the Médici dictatorship in Brazil in 1973.  Considered one of the company's most significant pieces, the play explores Sacher-Masoch's Six Houses of Bondage: Love, Money, Property, State, War and Death, with a seventh meditation on Revolutionary Change.

- Readings

 Excerpts from "Full Moon Poems", Judith Malina's last published book or from any of her writings.  Including a discussion on the practices of the Living Theatre with the company

- Ritualistic Street Performances 

The company will create these based on the specific needs/ interests of the local community.  We would love to collaborate with you by responding to an immediate injustice and building a "happening" around that issue in a site-specific format.

- Workshops

Non-violent direct action training facilitated by members of the company that may include elements of Living Theatre ensemble movement techniques.

Theater of the Oppressed workshop facilitated by members of the company

Living Theatre ensemble theater exercises facilitated by the company



THIS IS WHAT WE NEED:


DONATE to our IndieGoGo to support GAS and TRANSPORT Expenses:

Total Miles: 7,438

15 passenger van averages 13 miles per gallon

Average gallon in USA- $2.21

Gas Total Cost: $1,265

Vehicle Cost, Insurance, Travel Incidentals: $1,735

TOTAL: $3,000

Fundraising/Transaction Costs (If all $3K Transport Expenses raised): $400

TOTAL FUNDRAISING GOAL:  $3,400 




If you'd like to offer something other than money, we are in need of the following: 

Local Contacts/Information on local issues in each city

Housing 

Food & Meal Donations

Spread the Word: Share our IndieGoGo page and tour event page on FB 

Email us with any suggestions or offerings at info@livingtheatre.org



TOUR SCHEDULE:


Aug 15th - New York, NY at City Hall

                     Albany, NY at the State Capitol Building

                     Buffalo, NY at Subversive Theatre

                     https://www.facebook.com/events/1612545905742805/        



Aug 16th - Niagara Falls 

                     Cleveland, OH

                     Detroit, MI  at Trumbullplex

                     https://www.facebook.com/events/829435433857863/


Aug 17th - Flint, MI

                     Chicago, IL 


Aug 18th - Chicago, IL


Aug 19th - Normal, IL

                     St. Louis, MO


Aug 20th - Wichita, KS


Aug 21st - Denver, CO


Aug 22nd - Salt Lake City, UT


Aug 23rd - San Francisco, CA


Aug 24th - Berkley, CA at Finnish Hall

                      https://www.facebook.com/events/994374780684199/


Aug 25th - San Francisco, CA at The Great Star Theatre & Beat Museum 

                      https://www.facebook.com/events/1147602205262053/



Aug 26th - Big Sur,CA


Aug 27th - Los Angeles, CA


Aug 28th - Las Vegas, NV


Aug 29th - Phoenix, AZ


Aug 30th - Tuscon, AZ

                      Las Cruces, NM


Aug 31st - Houston, TX at Super Happy Fun Land 

                     https://www.facebook.com/events/1720887738183898/


Sep 1st - New Orleans, LA at Art Klub 

                  https://www.facebook.com/events/318996828490554/


Sep 2nd - Birmingham, AL


Sep 3rd - Knoxville, TN at Birdhouse


Sep 4th - Washington D.C.



THANK YOU

In order to make performances and happenings in every scheduled city, we will need your help, encouragement, and participation. Please join us while we are on tour! info@livingtheatre.org

story:
Why this dance?


In brief: this dance is an exploration on the abstract concept of borders. Borders defined not only as lines on maps, but also as separations on terrains like social structures, cultures, bodies, thoughts, and economic systems.


Geopolitical borders are of special relevance in these times given the mass migrations occurring across the world. These migrations are sadly caused not for the enrichment of cross-cultural interactions but by (among others) political and economic conditions. We believe that to comprehend the formation, function and rearrangement of geopolitical borders we have to understand the latent mechanisms that precede and give rise to them.


We therefore present and explore the extension of a border to abstract fields, in particular to mental categories, this is, the arbitrary borders of thought. The structure of the duet allows us to perform and represent physically the dyads that substantiate the current economic and environmental crises, and the borders that define them. In our duet, two bodies dance through the space of the real and the imaginary, the human and the natural, the individually psychological and the socially ideological. The corporeal dimension challenges the concept of a boundary as immovable and proposes investigating the edges (as borders of the established and the possible) as places of action.

Who we are:


Our team is an unexpected collaboration between an artist/choreographer and an engineer/writer.


Paty is a choreographer with an MFA in dance from the University of Michigan. Her research explores environmental issues through various artistic practices which include choreography, improvisation, dance pedagogy, writing, film, and walking. Yes, walking.

http://pattysolorzanodance.weebly.com


Efrén is an Electrical Engineering PhD at the University of Michigan. His research on Artificial Intelligence and Statistical Inference has led him to ask questions regarding the role of technology in an overarching capitalist order.


Together we would like to share our hybrid practice, a practice of two seemingly unrelated disciplines that are connected by sharing a common goal which is looking for an artistic and scientific solution to the political, economic and environmental challenges, and are connected by the philosophical, structural, and conceptual patterns that support these disciplines.


This project is of personal significance and is inspired by Paty’s lifelong encounter with borders. Paty’s experience as an immigrant to the U.S. led her to formulate an artistic vision on what being a foreigner and crossing (or being crossed by) a border means. Paty has also lived in Jerusalem, Israel, yet another site where conflicts surrounding geopolitical borders shape the lives of those who live in and near its edges.


We’re also excited to work with singer, songwriter and composer Ryan Wolfe, who has collaborated with Paty in past projects.

http://www.ryanwolfemusic.com/about.html


Where will the performance be?


We consider our duet an ongoing project, so we want to present our work in places where boundaries are especially prevalent. Our first stop will be the Performática International Dance and Movement Arts Forum (Foro Internacional de Danza Contemporánea y Artes del Movimiento), a biennial international performance forum where dancers and scholars converge to share their research on a particular topic. This year’s theme is Borders/Fronteras, hence our excitement for being invited to participate as performers and workshop leaders.

 http://www.performatica.org/index.php


After performing in Mexico we want to present our work in Detroit, Michigan, where borders of language, race, and money have segregated people for many years. Our goal is to then perform our dance in the US-Mexico border.


Budget


Rehearsal Space Rental: $70

Costumes: $200

Materials/Props/Supplies: $200

Airfare to Mexico for 2: $600

Room and Board:  $300

Per Diem:  $300

Composer Fee: $400

Creator/Choreographer/Dancer Fees: $900

Total: $2,970


Other Ways You Can Help


Spread the word! We understand not everyone can contribute monetarily.  However, this doesn’t mean you cannot help.  Please share our campaign with others through social media, e-mail, and word-of-mouth. Every bit helps us reach our goal!

We believe that to comprehend the formation, function and rearrangement of geopolitical borders we have to understand the latent mechanisms that precede and give rise to them.We therefore present and explore the extension of a border to abstract fields, in particular to mental categories, this is, the arbitrary borders of thought. The structure of the duet allows us to perform and represent physically the dyads that substantiate the current economic and environmental crises, and the borders that define them. In our duet, two bodies dance through the space of the real and the imaginary, the human and the natural, the individually psychological and the socially ideological. The corporeal dimension challenges the concept of a boundary as immovable and proposes investigating the edges (as borders of the established and the possible) as places of action.Who we are:Our team is an unexpected collaboration between an artist/choreographer and an engineer/writer.Paty is a choreographer with an MFA in dance from the University of Michigan. Her research explores environmental issues through various artistic practices which include choreography, improvisation, dance pedagogy, writing, film, and walking. Yes, walking.http://pattysolorzanodance.weebly.comEfrén is an Electrical Engineering PhD at the University of Michigan. His research on Artificial Intelligence and Statistical Inference has led him to ask questions regarding the role of technology in an overarching capitalist order. Together we would like to share our hybrid practice, a practice of two seemingly unrelated disciplines that are connected by sharing a common goal which is looking for an artistic and scientific solution to the political, economic and environmental challenges, and are connected by the philosophical, structural, and conceptual patterns that support these disciplines.This project is of personal significance and is inspired by Paty’s lifelong encounter with borders. Paty’s experience as an immigrant to the U.S. led her to formulate an artistic vision on what being a foreigner and crossing (or being crossed by) a border means. Paty has also lived in Jerusalem, Israel, yet another site where conflicts surrounding geopolitical borders shape the lives of those who live in and near its edges.We’re also excited to work with singer, songwriter and composer Ryan Wolfe, who has collaborated with Paty in past projects. http://www.ryanwolfemusic.com/about.htmlWhere will the performance be?We consider our duet an ongoing project, so we want to present our work in places where boundaries are especially prevalent. Our first stop will be the Performática International Dance and Movement Arts Forum (Foro Internacional de Danza Contemporánea y Artes del Movimiento), a biennial international performance forum where dancers and scholars converge to share their research on a particular topic. This year’s theme is Borders/Fronteras, hence our excitement for being invited to participate as performers and workshop leaders. http://www.performatica.org/index.phpAfter performing in Mexico we want to present our work in Detroit, Michigan, where borders of language, race, and money have segregated people for many years. Our goal is to then perform our dance in the US-Mexico border.BudgetRehearsal Space Rental: $70Costumes: $200Materials/Props/Supplies: $200Airfare to Mexico for 2: $600Room and Board:  $300 Per Diem:  $300Composer Fee: $400Creator/Choreographer/Dancer Fees: $900Total: $2,970Other Ways You Can HelpSpread the word! We understand not everyone can contribute monetarily.  However, this doesn’t mean you cannot help.  Please share our campaign with others through social media, e-mail, and word-of-mouth. Every bit helps us reach our goal!

story:
Hello!  

We are Finger in the Pie. 

We've  been producing some of London’s best known cabaret and burlesque events since 2007. In that time we’ve held an 8 year residency in the world famous Madame JoJo’s, and organised London’s largest showcase of new and established performers. 

We sat on the Judging Panel of the very first London Cabaret Awards, helped organise the first London Cabaret Festival, and launched the careers of countless cabaret and burlesque performers through our nights, workshops and events. 

We also organise shows across London all year round! 

We're about to launch our most exciting show yet: WÜNDERFINGER at the Spiegeltent this August...for 2 nights only!!!

Our dazzling night of twisted, anarchic, badly-behaved late night cabaret is led by the infamous Baby Lame, alongside a line-up of the most bizarre cabaret and acts around - plus a stunning aerialist to boot. The show's taking place at London Wonderground on the Southbank - home to great venues such as The Udderbelly and The Fabulous Speigletent.

We're so excited about WÜNDERFINGER that we wanted to celebrate.
BY GETTING  OUR VERY OWN BRANDED FOAM FINGERS! 

Yes that's right...like you're all in the crowd at Gladiators...it's 1992, and you're as happy as this kid: 

So that's exactly what we're going to do. 

BUT WE NEED YOUR HELP!

Grab your very own foam finger, and come on down to the Spiegletent to get WÜNDERFINGERED!! 

What you can get your hands on:

  • Foam WÜNDERFINGER - branded + made especially for this event
  • Tickets to the show!
  • LUXURY VIP tickets to the show!
  • Customised WÜNDERFINGER crafted by our very own acts!
  • *** Top Perk *** BABY LAME Doorstep FINGERGRAM 

    • We can't wait for the sheer joy of seeing loads of  foam fingers in the crowd for our hotly anticipated cabaret explosion! 

    YOU ( - yes, you -) could be the proud owner of a finger 'creatively' customised by the madly brilliant Baby Lame or our other acts, and you get to keep it FOREVER.

    What are you waiting for? 
    You only have until MONDAY 4th JULY to secure your very own FINGER!

    SO MAKE LIKE MILEY AND GET IN THE FOAM FINGER GROOVE:


    If you can't make it to the show...

    ...but would love a foam finger anyway (and why not?) we're more than happy to send you one in the post. Just select your Foam Finger perk and we'll email you to ask where we should send yours.  Then you can Tweet, Facebook or Instagram us a pic of your finger, wherever you are in the world....Gnaaaaaaw. 

    ...AND FINALLY!

    Don't forget to share our crowdfund with your dazzling friends and networks. 

    Thank you so much!
    All the love,

    FINGER IN THE PIE xxx

story:
OUR ADVENTURE...

The four of us have the amazing opportunity to spend our summer in Plymouth, Massachusetts to intern with Americana Theatre Company. There, we will be taught by professionals in the business while working alongside them to learn about all the different aspects of the world of professional theatre. We will also be traveling to NYC the last week of our internship to perform a showcase for industry professionals for the purpose of future networking. We are so excited about this opportunity...but need your help! We would love our friends and families to partner with us to help us raise the support we need to fund our internship. 
We are all so passionate about theatre and telling good stories to impact the lives of people around the world. We strongly believe that theatre changes lives and that in order to do that, we need to be equipped. Having this experience at Americana will be our first step into the business ourself and will help us all build our skills as well as advance our careers and equip us to share our love of storytelling with others. 
What We Need & What You Get
PLEASE NOTE: When you donate, you will be donating to students at William Jessup University. The contributions will go directly to students and not through William Jessup University. 
We are in need of about $12,000 to make this trip possible. Your financial support will cover registration for the internship class through William Jessup University, our housing fee, flights there and back, food, and shows and food for our trip to New York.
 In order to help fundraise, we are also putting on a huge cabaret: SUMMER NIGHTS BENEFIT CABARET: CELEBRATING 30 YEARS OF BROADWAY'S BEST!  on April 7th at 8 p.m. at William Jessup University. It will be a night of Broadway's best show tunes..singing, dancing, acting, and dessert! We would love to see you there. 
MEET THE INTERNS...

Audrey Wagstaffe is a junior at William Jessup University and is passionately pursuing her Bachelor of Creative Arts degree with a concentration in Theatre. She recently appeared as Susanna Walcott in THE CRUCIBLE and hopes to be in many more shows in the future. Her experiences in theatre are just beginning, so she is thrilled to be working and learning alongside the wonderful people at Americana.

Kevin Nelson Jr. is a sophomore double major in Vocal Performance and Theatre at William Jessup University. Some of his credits include: Bob Wallace (Irving Berlin's WHITE CHRISTMAS), Officer Lockstock (URINETOWN: THE MUSICAL), and Alan (GOD OF CARNAGE). Kevin is thrilled to be on this wonderful adventure and cannot wait to see where it takes him. He would like to thank his family, friends and girlfriend for all of their support. Most importantly, he lifts up his thanks to the Lord, who is the reason for all of this.  
Mary Kantorik is an aspiring stage manager. She is a sophomore at William Jessup University as a Creative Arts major with an emphasis in Arts Management. Although she has loved the time she has spent on stage, she has found her home working behind the scenes. Currently, she is serving as assistant stage manager for William Jessup University's OKLAHOMA! Her biggest passion in life is to encourage, empower, and bring people together. Mary is excited to pursue this passion in the field of stage management. 

Morgan Mena is a freshman at William Jessup University with a major in Creative Arts (Theatre). She hopes that one day she can tour and perform as a professional actor and use the passion that has been placed within her. A couple of her favorite roles have been Mary Warren in THE CRUCIBLE and Shelby in STEEL MAGNOLIAS.  Her dream is to be able to portray characters that show both truth and beauty, as well as leave an audience awakened and revitalized. 

Andres Garcia is a Creative Arts major with a theatre emphasis at William Jessup University . Andres is excited to be joining Americana as an intern in stage management. He hopes that this experience will provide him with a new insight into the inner workings of the industry and will help further his goal of becoming a well-rounded performer. 

MEET THE ORGANIZERS...

Kelly Ann Dunn is a recent graduate of William Jessup University’s Creative Arts Program and has been seen in musicals around the Sacramento area as well as recently appearing as a lead role in a popular Japanese TV show.  Professional Credits: Ensemble in OKLAHOMA!, Constance in THE THREE MUSKETEERS, The Queen in SLEEPING BEAUTY, Eponine in LES MISERABLES. Educational Credits: Amy March in LITTLE WOMEN, Rita in WHITE CHRISTMAS,  Truvy in STEEL MAGNOLIAS. Other Credits: Millie in THOROUGHLY MODERN MILLIE, Rona in THE 25TH ANNUAL PUTNAM COUNTY SPELLING BEE, Rizzo in GREASE, Chava in FIDDLER ON THE ROOF. She is thrilled to be headed back to Americana Theatre Company this summer! 

Payton Gobeille is thrilled to be returning to Americana and is excited for another amazing summer! Currently a senior at William Jessup earning her B.A. in Creative Arts with an emphasis in Theatre, She is glad to have more Californians experience her native Massachusetts. She has been involved in numerous capacities of theatre, both on and off stage, and is pleased to bring this production of Grease to life and tell the story through costumes.


Thank you for partnering with us on our adventure! We are so thankful for you!

story:
La Via Lumina is a new contemporary dance theater based in Pahoa on the Big Island of Hawaii. 

My name is Christina Caputo and I have lived on the Big Island of Hawaii for the last 15 years and have performed in, directed, and produced live theatrical events for 20 years.

We are asking for the resources to help us open the doors of La Via Lumina.


OUR MISSION:

  • Revitalization of the Historic town of Pahoa by offering regular, seasonal theatrical and dance performances
  • Production of a live show for the Hawaii community by the Spring of 2017
  • Facilitation of a much-needed rehearsal space for the performing arts in the district of Puna, Hawaii
  • To serve as a safe, enriching, and artistic environment for children, teens, and adults


THE COMMUNITY NEED:

The district of Puna is the lowest socioeconomic district in the state of Hawaii. It currently lacks resources and a creative space for the performing arts. This area of Hawaii is also notorious for its lack of healthy, safe activities for teens. La Via Lumina would help fill this void.

YOUR IMPACT:

Your support is vital. Donating to the arts is a direct and beautiful way to revitalize any community. You will help provide a creative outlet for teens and adults, build confidence in our community, and aid and inspire talent by catalyzing the inspiration to dream, create, and express. 

It is incredibly demanding to produce a show that involves so many people without the tangible assets and funding to support that vision and bring it to life.

I hope to see the aspiring and dedicated artists, dancers and crew, everyone involved, receive compensation for the heart and soul they put into their work.

I want to see our children grow up and establish themselves in a real, constructive way. And I want our performers and staff to be recognized for their talent and the enjoyment they provide the community.
When you give the gift of theater and dance, you affect everyone. You pave a path of positivity for our kids, our future and our community.


HOW DONATIONS WILL BE UTILIZED:

  • Investing in a professional sound system and equipment
  • Purchasing costumes and materials to make costumes; collecting and creating props 
  • Assembling a professional studio/art center with the proper equipment, including professional mirrors and flooring
  • Marketing and web support. An online presence is beyond mandatory at this stage in the entertainment world. By having communication lines open with the online community, we are able to network and reach our crew and audience
  • Funding to meet our goal to produce a show by the spring of 2017
  • Hiring a grant writer so that we may continue supporting our dream 

If you have a way to help other than monetary contributions, please feel free to contact us.

 
THE VALUE:
The most precious moment in the entire 20 years of doing this work was when a dear friend called me few days after a production In Pahoa.

She was crying with joy...thanking me.
I will never forget it.
She told me that her daughter, who was about 8 years old at the time, had not smiled in six months.
She said that ever since the night they came to our show, her daughter had been singing and dancing around the house nonstop.
That is the greatest gift I can possibly hope to give to this world.

I love to vision and organize community productions, because I know it is through the vision of the artists that we will collectively build a righteous future for our world.

story:
UPDATE!!!

Tickets are on sale now for the Midtown International Theatre Festival at the following link:
https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/cal/27845
For a friends/family discount please use the code 

FRIENDSFAMILY


Short Summary

We are a bunch of Ithaca College students and alumni who love to create fun, new theatre. We're excited to begin The Y2K Play journey for not one, but two summer theater festivals!

This campaign is super important to making this show happen! We need every little bit of help we can get. There are so many elements that have to go into this show in order to make it a success and we simply can't do it without you!

Every little bit helps! Whether it is $10, $1,000, or just reposting our campaign on social media, it is all a huge help and we greatly appreciate it!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need funds for:

  • Sets
  • Costumes
  • Props
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Stipends for Actors
  • Marketing Material
What you get:
  • $10 and up - Huge thank you on social media 
  • $25 and up - Hand written thank you note and producer credit in our program (plus benefits above)
  • $50 and up - Limited addition signed The Y2K Play poster (plus benefits above)
  • $100 and up - Signed script of The Y2K Play (plus benefits above)
  • $500 and up - Private dinner with the cast and creative team (plus benefits above)

The Impact

Your contribution will not only be funding this project, it'll be contributing to the careers of young theater artists! This play is just the start of many exciting projects that we are looking forward to producing and creating so thank you thank you thank you for helping make this happen. Also, please come see the show! We are performing the following days:

Midtown International Theatre Festival (Jewel Box Theatre 312 W 36th Street)

  • July 25th at 6pm
  • July 28th at 8:30pm
  • July 30th at 3pm

Summer Dark fest at The Tank (151 W 46th Street)

  • July 30th at 7pm
  • July 31st at 7pm

Risks & Challenges

  • Everything costs money!
  • Rehearsal space is hard to come by but we're searching!
  • Festivals require a lot of flexibility and creativity, especially with sets and lights so we're looking forward to making magic!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people aren't able to contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us make some noise! Please share this on Facebook, email, and word of mouth!
