story:
Kasuli Francis is a trained and experienced dance performer and an aspiring choreographer. Dancing is her way of living and a great source of energy. Although Kasuli never got the chance to receive training before entering Secondary School, she took the opportunity to watch and practice movements and sequences from dance classes held at former Primary School, Dunrobin Primary, music videos, and social events and performances. She was often times laughed at by many, including her high school dance teacher and dance mates, and even by some of her family members. They poorly believed that she was good at dancing. But with passion, dedication and practice she certainly proved them wrong. Her family was not a big fan of the idea for dancing as a career, but over time they realized how talented she was and how much she could achieve. Kasuli's passion and drive for her craft now inspires her family.

Dancing is only one of the many talents that Kasuli has. She is also talented in numerous areas such as; track and field, hair styling, sewing, drawing, painting, cooking, and singing. Between the ages of seven and thirteen she assisted her father, in his carpentry business. He thought that she would have been an excellent carpenter. In Primary School between the ages of six and eleven, Kasuli had an admiration for her Aunt's career in nursing; who always saw it necessary to assist and care for others.

Kasuli's interest in teaching and choreographing sprung from an early age group. On the weekends she would either play school with her dolls or with the younger children in the neighborhood. At times, she would even compose dance sequences for community events.

Between the year 2002-2007, Kasuli gained her first dance experience at The Queen's School, where she joined the dance team and participated in a number of shows. It was also where she gained her first Latin dance experience; Salsa, Merengue, and Cha Cha Cha. In the final year of her attendance at the Queen's School 2006-2007 a friend introduced her to the Caribbean Regals Entertainment, where she traveled around Jamaica dancing and playing the bass steel pan.

Kasuli Francis is a proud graduate of the Edna Manley College of the Visual and Performing Arts, where she completed a Diploma in Dance Theater and Production between the year 2008-2012. She received the Ivy Baxter award for the most outstanding student in her program. During her study at the College she have participated in numerous events on and off the school campus, such as organizing a Preliminary Qualifying year show in 2009 to show case the year group's talent and to prove that they were ready for the next step, Graduation Production 2009, Dynamix 2010, JARIA 2010, Fusion 2010, Diageo Learning for Life Project Artist Graduation Ceremony 2010, St. Francis Primary Carol service 2011, DanceWorks 2009- 2011, and an appearance in the Digicel “Gimmi Five” television commercial in 2010-2011. In 2011 she choreographed a duet piece for DanceWorks called “The Decision” and a group piece for the Stella Morris Preparatory School Carol service. Kasuli have also made a profound contribution to Graduation Production 2011; where she made her name in the college's history as the first student choreographer for the show.

Media entertainment was never usually Kasuli's main focus. Her main focus is the Theatre. Recently, she has been exploring media entertainment as equal as the Theatre. Kasuli has dance experience in commercials, videos and live performances for Digicel, Suppligen, Sizzla, Orisha Sound, Zhavea and Black as Cole. She also choreographed the opening number for the singers of Protoje and the InDiggnation. This was done for their 2014 summer tour. Kasuli is currently working on other upcoming events.

Kasuli gained other performing arts experiences at various Hotels and Resorts such as the Iberostar Hotels and Resorts 2012-2014, and Riu Club, Tropical Bay and Montego Bay 2009-2010. She had teaching experiences at the Montessori Children's World and YMCA, summer 2011. Her main aim as a teacher is to shape the students mind, bodies, and soul; because within their eyes she saw the future that may assist in the transformation of the Arts in Jamaica. She also taught private dance classes introducing basic Traditional, Cultural and Contemporary Dances.

Additional training was received from the National Dance Theater Company of Jamaica in 2011. Kasuli is currently an apprentice at L'Acadco: A United Caribbean Dance Force.

Kasuli is currently the dance teacher at the Wonderworld Childcare Centre, and is preparing the school for the 2015 JCDC Dance Festival. She is a contestant of the World Championships of the Performing Arts (WCOPA), where she will represent Jamaica in Los Angeles this July 2015. The two categories that she will be competing in is Lyrical Dance and Afro Caribbean Folk.

Kasuli is maintaining focus to be ready for other experiences that are set ahead. "No longer will I sit back and dream, it is time to make my dream a reality! I will not limit myself in the Arts and entertainment; my journey has just begun".

story: You can't parse [X]HTML with regex. Because HTML can't be parsed by regex. Regex is not a tool that can be used to correctly parse HTML. As I have answered in HTML-and-regex questions here so many times before, the use of regex will not allow you to consume HTML. Regular expressions are a tool that is insufficiently sophisticated to understand the constructs employed by HTML. HTML is not a regular language and hence cannot be parsed by regular expressions. Regex queries are not equipped to break down HTML into its meaningful parts. so many times but it is not getting to me. Even enhanced irregular regular expressions as used by Perl are not up to the task of parsing HTML. You will never make me crack. HTML is a language of sufficient complexity that it cannot be parsed by regular expressions. Even Jon Skeet cannot parse HTML using regular expressions. Every time you attempt to parse HTML with regular expressions, the unholy child weeps the blood of virgins, and Russian hackers pwn your webapp. Parsing HTML with regex summons tainted souls into the realm of the living. HTML and regex go together like love, marriage, and ritual infanticide. The <center> cannot hold it is too late. The force of regex and HTML together in the same conceptual space will destroy your mind like so much watery putty. If you parse HTML with regex you are giving in to Them and their blasphemous ways which doom us all to inhuman toil for the One whose Name cannot be expressed in the Basic Multilingual Plane, he comes. HTML-plus-regexp will liquify the n​erves of the sentient whilst you observe, your psyche withering in the onslaught of horror. Rege̿̔̉x-based HTML parsers are the cancer that is killing StackOverflow it is too late it is too late we cannot be saved the trangession of a chi͡ld ensures regex will consume all living tissue (except for HTML which it cannot, as previously prophesied) dear lord help us how can anyone survive this scourge using regex to parse HTML has doomed humanity to an eternity of dread torture and security holes using regex as a tool to process HTML establishes a breach between this world and the dread realm of c͒ͪo͛ͫrrupt entities (like SGML entities, but more corrupt) a mere glimpse of the world of reg​ex parsers for HTML will ins​tantly transport a programmer's consciousness into a world of ceaseless screaming, he comes, the pestilent slithy regex-infection wil​l devour your HT​ML parser, application and existence for all time like Visual Basic only worse he comes he comes do not fi​ght he com̡e̶s, ̕h̵i​s un̨ho͞ly radiańcé destro҉ying all enli̍̈́̂̈́ghtenment, HTML tags lea͠ki̧n͘g fr̶ǫm ̡yo​͟ur eye͢s̸ ̛l̕ik͏e liq​uid pain, the song of re̸gular exp​ression parsing will exti​nguish the voices of mor​tal man from the sp​here I can see it can you see ̲͚̖͔̙î̩́t̲͎̩̱͔́̋̀ it is beautiful t​he final snuffing of the lie​s of Man ALL IS LOŚ͖̩͇̗̪̏̈́T ALL I​S LOST the pon̷y he comes he c̶̮omes he comes theich​or permeates all MY FACE MY FACE ᵒh god no NO NOO̼O​O NΘ stop the an​*̶͑̾̾​̅ͫ͏̙̤g͇̫͛͆̾ͫ̑͆l͖͉̗̩̳̟̍ͫͥͨe̠̅s ͎a̧͈͖r̽̾̈́͒͑e n​ot rè̑ͧ̌aͨl̘̝̙̃ͤ͂̾̆ ZA̡͊͠͝LGΌ ISͮ̂҉̯͈͕̹̘̱ TO͇̹̺ͅƝ̴ȳ̳ TH̘Ë͖́̉ ͠P̯͍̭O̚​N̐Y̡ H̸̡̪̯ͨ͊̽̅̾̎Ȩ̬̩̾͛ͪ̈́̀́͘ ̶̧̨̱̹̭̯ͧ̾ͬC̷̙̲̝͖ͭ̏ͥͮ͟Oͮ͏̮̪̝͍M̲̖͊̒ͪͩͬ̚̚͜Ȇ̴̟̟͙̞ͩ͌͝S̨̥̫͎̭ͯ̿̔̀ͅ

Regex queries are not equipped to break down HTML into its meaningful parts. so many times but it is not getting to me. Even enhanced irregular regular expressions as used by Perl are not up to the task of parsing HTML. You will never make me crack. HTML is a language of sufficient complexity that it cannot be parsed by regular expressions. Even Jon Skeet cannot parse HTML using regular expressions. Every time you attempt to parse HTML with regular expressions, the unholy child weeps the blood of virgins, and Russian hackers pwn your webapp. Parsing HTML with regex summons tainted souls into the realm of the living. HTML and regex go together like love, marriage, and ritual infanticide. The <center> cannot hold it is too late. The force of regex and HTML together in the same conceptual space will destroy your mind like so much watery putty. If you parse HTML with regex you are giving in to Them and their blasphemous ways which doom us all to inhuman toil for the One whose Name cannot be expressed in the Basic Multilingual Plane, he comes. HTML-plus-regexp will liquify the n​erves of the sentient whilst you observe, your psyche withering in the onslaught of horror. Rege̿̔̉x-based HTML parsers are the cancer that is killing StackOverflow it is too late it is too late we cannot be saved the trangession of a chi͡ld ensures regex will consume all living tissue (except for HTML which it cannot, as previously prophesied) dear lord help us how can anyone survive this scourge using regex to parse HTML has doomed humanity to an eternity of dread torture and security holes using regex as a tool to process HTML establishes a breach between this world and the dread realm of c͒ͪo͛ͫrrupt entities (like SGML entities, but more corrupt) a mere glimpse of the world of reg​ex parsers for HTML will ins​tantly transport a programmer's consciousness into a world of ceaseless screaming, he comes, the pestilent slithy regex-infection wil​l devour your HT​ML parser, application and existence for all time like Visual Basic only worse he comes he comes do not fi​ght he com̡e̶s, ̕h̵i​s un̨ho͞ly radiańcé destro҉ying all enli̍̈́̂̈́ghtenment, HTML tags lea͠ki̧n͘g fr̶ǫm ̡yo​͟ur eye͢s̸ ̛l̕ik͏e liq​uid pain, the song of re̸gular exp​ression parsing will exti​nguish the voices of mor​tal man from the sp​here I can see it can you see ̲͚̖͔̙î̩́t̲͎̩̱͔́̋̀ it is beautiful t​he final snuffing of the lie​s of Man ALL IS LOŚ͖̩͇̗̪̏̈́T ALL I​S LOST the pon̷y he comes he c̶̮omes he comes theich​or permeates all MY FACE MY FACE ᵒh god no NO NOO̼O​O NΘ stop the an​*̶͑̾̾​̅ͫ͏̙̤g͇̫͛͆̾ͫ̑͆l͖͉̗̩̳̟̍ͫͥͨe̠̅s ͎a̧͈͖r̽̾̈́͒͑e n​ot rè̑ͧ̌aͨl̘̝̙̃ͤ͂̾̆ ZA̡͊͠͝LGΌ ISͮ̂҉̯͈͕̹̘̱ TO͇̹̺ͅƝ̴ȳ̳ TH̘Ë͖́̉ ͠P̯͍̭O̚​N̐Y̡ H̸̡̪̯ͨ͊̽̅̾̎Ȩ̬̩̾͛ͪ̈́̀́͘ ̶̧̨̱̹̭̯ͧ̾ͬC̷̙̲̝͖ͭ̏ͥͮ͟Oͮ͏̮̪̝͍M̲̖͊̒ͪͩͬ̚̚͜Ȇ̴̟̟͙̞ͩ͌͝S̨̥̫͎̭ͯ̿̔̀ͅ

story:
Welcome to the fundraising page for Fifty Days at Iliam!

WHAT is Fifty Days at Iliam?
Fifty Days at Iliam is a bold new theatre piece set to premiere in the 2015 Philadelphia FringeArts Festival, exploring the final fifty days of The Trojan War as told through the work of abstract expressionist painter Cy Twombly.

It started with a group of artists' shared love of Twombly's famously visceral series (housed in the Philadelphia Museum of Art), Fifty Days at Iliam. We assembled in January, and began to unpack why we were so affected by the work. We delved into the biography of Twombly, and the centuries-worth of dramaturgy surrounding the conclusion of the Trojan War. Since then, we've been devising and workshopping  - and Fifty Days at Iliam has grown into an explosive new theatre piece, combining music, movement and visual projections, drawing on classical mythology and art history, examining the role of the artist in the retelling of violent narratives.


WHO is Fifty Days at Iliam?
We are a diverse ensemble of theatre artists, hailing from all over the United States. We are actors, dancers, playwrights, musicians, martial artists, mask-makers, puppeteers and poets. But mostly, we are all REALLY excited about this project. Full biographies can be found at www.hannahvansciver.com/fifty-days-at-iliam.

Lead Artist/Producer: Hannah Van Sciver
Director: William Steinberger
Cast: Joseph Ahmed, Elizabeth Audley, Jeffrey Casazza, Richard Chan, Mal Cherifi, Amanda Jill Robinson, Hannah Van Sciver
Workshop Members: Joseph Ahmed, Elizabeth Audley, Jeffrey Casazza, Richard Chan, Mal Cherifi, Susanne Collins, Terilyn Eisenhauer, Amanda Jill Robinson, Jahzeer Terrell, Hannah Van Sciver
Sets/Props/Costumes: Sara Outing
Lights: Eric Baker
Sound/Composition: Sarah Van Sciver
Movement Coaching: Nicole Quenelle
Dramaturgy: Kate Herzlin
Production Assistant: Cody Sherman Smith


WHERE will the $$ go?
No matter how you cut it, art costs money. The money raised through this campaign will go towards covering....
-The FringeArts entrance fee
-Performance Insurance
-Performance/Rehearsal space rental costs
-Marketing Costs
-Stipends for Actors and Designers
-Sets! Lights! Sound! Props! Costumes!

THANK YOU THANK YOU. Every little bit helps. Your support means the world to us. (Really. We couldn't do it without you.) See you at Iliam!

story:
Summary

"Phaedra” is a Solo Dance performance. The aim is to deconstruct the classic text of ΄Hippolytus΄ by Euripides, while using pre-recorded sound on stage as well as narration of the Ancient Greek text. This fragmented narration is focused on the female figure and the negative emotions that the main character has been deluged. The dramaturgy and kinesiology are a study of gestures and movements coming straight from Ancient Greek culture and historical statues.

"Phaedra" has been staged and successfully performed in Platform Theatre in London and Conference and Cultural Centre in Patras. We are delighted to announce that "Phaedra" is being accepted in Camden Fringe 2015 at The Cockpit Theatre as well as in the Dansarte Centre  in Patras, Greece and at the UnityGate Festival, Portugal. Furthermore, we are under discussion of touring "Phaedra" in other international venues within autumn/winter for the period of 2015-2016.


The Funding 

The amount of funding we are aiming to raise in 45 days is £1,000 in order to complete and stage "Phaedra" in London Camden Fringe 2015, Patras' Dansarte Centre, UnityGate in Portugal and upcoming performances in different venues internationally. As evidence from the past few months of 2015, we have spent £600 out of our pocket in making the show, rehearsing and touring. The breakdown of the potential spending, so far, is as follows: £250.00 on venue hiring / The Cockpit Theatre, £60.00 on Camden Fringe festival participation, £150.00 on rehearsal space (15hours), £150.00 on sets & props, £100.00 on flyer & posters, £100.00 (approx.) on the operator and lighting designer, £200.00 (approx.) on travel expenses to Greece and Portugal and the rest of the amount to help us in buying advertisments and press release at both festivals. 


Why Crowdfunding?

"Phaedra" is an ambitious project to date in collaboration between Eirini Apostolatou  and Christiana Ioannou. Although, is being truly successful in both London and Greece, all the expenses were covered by us. 

To begin with, "Phaedra" has the possibility to become a big scale piece, due to its content that allows us to make a further development and research on its dramaturgy and kinesiology as a piece. By 'dramaturgy and kinesiology' we refer to bigger sets, more props and extensive rehearsals for research in the movement which is demanded. 

Furthermore, The Camden Fringe festival is a golden chance for us to get exposed as well as promote our performance but on the other hand is a competitive and expensive market to advertise a show. To conclude, "Phaedra" will be touring once again in Greece, Cyprus, Portugal, Spain and according to being successful upon application in other venues and festivals.

                                                                                 


The Team

We are a team considered by a choreographer/performer and a dramaturgist/director. 

Eirini Apostolatou trained at the National School of Dance, Athens, in addition to the acrobatics (gymnastics champion of Greece, 1998-2003). After her graduation joined Jasmin Vardimon for the Professional Development Certificate (JV2). She has collaborated and performed for many different choreographers and directors, internationally.

She is currently based in London working with companies as a dancer and a performer. She parallel teaches, and now, beginning her own choreographic work.

Christiana Ioannou trained as a Theatre Designer at Trent University, Nottingham. She is a recent graduate in MA Performance Design and Practice at Central Saint Martins, which led her to experiment with Dramaturgy and Directing for experimental performances.  
She is making performances via her platform Praxis: Theatre and Performance Collective in London and Cyprus.   

Other Ways You Can Help

Any level of donation, large or small is greatly appreciated, but if you can't make a cash donation, you can still help:

  • Get the word out and share this campaign to your social media network on Facebook, Websites, Youtube etc.. 
  • Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools, and let us know what else you need to spread the word effectively.
  • Reach out to your friends who can afford to make a financial pledge.  We actually DO believe that people want to  be asked to help.

Even if you cannot contribute monetarily, please share my Indiegogo campaign with anyone you may know, friends and family. Word of mouth is a valuable tool in becoming prominent and well known, and I would be continually grateful for that. 

 Thank you so much in advance for any help you can offer!


Other Links

  • http://www.camdenfringe.com/detailact.php?acts_id=390
  • https://www.facebook.com/eirini.apostolatou
  • https://www.facebook.com/unmasked.performance
  • http://apostolatoue.wix.com/apostolatoueirini
  • http://www.christianaioannou.co.uk/
  • https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCervRkKxmEVZ7lGC4HqpE5Q/videos

Extracts from Platform Theatre, London, 28 May 2015

story:
Mission statement

*We are dedicated to education and performance with a mission of social change. We strive to invite new artists to communicate the change they want to see in the world through performance and personal story. We use nontraditional performance spaces to offer a venue that is accessible to all; inviting community to view, share, and converse. We seek to achieve professionalism and openness while supporting and guiding artists on their own journey to change, always with the intent that social change starts in our own backyards. We are all we've got, is introducing a new form of performance that allows the audience to stop the action at anytime and ask questions or have a discussion about that is being seen. We are calling this technique "stop, think, go" and asking the audience to involve themselves in the story. We believe this technique will allow the audience and company members to grow as artists and community members; by letting go of ego and allowing different perspectives on story. Think town hall within a play. 

WE NEED YOUR HELP.

If you have already donated as much as you are able, thank you.  Please consider sharing the campaign with your friends or on Facebook.  We are proud to have you in our ranks.  Truly this is both a donation and an investment and I thank you for your consideration.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


We are a collection of artists growing from the creative arts therapies. We wanted to find a way to work toward social change while allowing the community to have a voice. We are: 

  • Holly Brewer, theater artist and drama therapist
  • Kate Ryan, theater artist and founder of Jakku House
  • Michael Buchert, artist and art therapist
  • Tannar Brewer, musician and grant writer
  • Cheryl Robinson, visual artist
  • Alicia Delk, Marketing 


What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise $4,000.00 to begin our collaboration with Shunpike and file for non profit status. This will allow us to have more events and workshops to teach and explore our technique of performance. We have created a unique set of perks for our contributing members. 

The Impact

  • Through your contribution you will be involved in helping the community have a voice in social change while learning how to share emotional reactions to events within a safe environment led by licensed creative arts therapist. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please share on Facebook or any other social media. 

                           After all "We are all we've got"!

story:
“Sanctuary"

A New Play Written & Performed by Susanne Sulby

Directed by Stephen Stahl

Will Play a Festival Circuit followed by a limited Off-Broadway engagement at The Lion Theatre, Theatre Row

I am asking you to help me change the world one theatre audience at a time. Please fund this powerful project that gives voice to a woman's perspective of war and the possibility of sanctuary from it! The $5000.00 I am asking for will fund the development of the technical aspects of the play and help fund the staff. We need new video projection and qualified technicians to run the show at the highest quality. 

We truly can make a difference, each in our own small way. We will be so grateful for your help! Even $10.00 will help. Let it begin with our own actions, one step at a time, protecting our soldiers, living bravely and compassionately.

Here is a detailed description of the show and how it began for me. I hope you'll read it. Visit our website, www.sanctuarytheplay.com, find us on Facebook and twitter. Like and Share! We are the evolution we seek

Using actual emails from soldiers in Iraq, news footage, the poetry of Rumi, poetry from soldiers Sanctuary, a new play written and performed by theater and film actress Susanne Sulby, will play a theatre festival circuit followed by an Off-Broadway run. Staged by veteran Off Broadway director Stephen Stahl, the play will intrigue theatre audiences with a poignant and touching look on the impact of war on women over the centuries. The multi-character play features a suburban housewife, a TV news reporter (inspired by CNN correspondent Christiane Amanpour), and a P.O.W.  in Kosovo -- among other characters.   Having been particularly moved by the Serbo-Croatian conflict in the 1990‘s and the 9/11 tragedy, Sulby was inspired to write Sanctuary from her relationship with television news and its ability to bring the journeys of those surrounded by war into her home. The heart-felt stories made her question her own various roles as a woman in these conflicts --- as the observer, victim, mother, and wife. She watched, from the comfort of her Pennsylvania home, a passive participant, as its horrors unfolded. “I was compelled to watch but struggled to understand the bleak absurdity of this slaughter. Although I was mesmerized by the news coverage, I initially felt impotent to respond. I searched so I could find my own path to sanctuary, simply put action, however small,” says Sulby.An established actor, designated Linklater voice instructor, dialect coach and voiceover artist, Ms. Sulby has performed for over 20 years. Favorite roles include Gertrude in Hamlet with Rev Theatre, Aunt Bobbie in American Sligo with New City Stage Company, Yelena in Black Russian with InterAct Theatre , Molly Bloom in A Dublin Bloom based on James Joyce’s Ulysses , directed by Gregory Doran of the Royal Shakespeare Company and Queen Elizabeth in Richard III with Novel Stages. Her first film role was playing opposite Billy Crudup in the 2000 award-winning Evenstar feature film, Jesus’ Son. Her film credits as dialect coach include the recent feature film, Silver Linings Playbook (nominated for 8 Academy Awards) directed by David O. Russell, starring Bradley Cooper, Robert DeNiro and Jacki Weaver.Fresh from having penned and staged last season’s Off Broadway hit musical “Lady Day” starring Dee Dee Bridgewater, Stephen Stahl comes to Sanctuary as a seasoned writer and director. His production, directorial and industrial credits include numerous professional stage shows, award-winning films and a decade of writing, producing and directing the Philadelphia Music Awards. Mr. Stahl has directed, written for, produced and worked with Billy Joel, Bill Cosby, Patti LaBelle, Kathy Sledge, Sandy Duncan, Jason Bateman, Phyllis Hyman, Kitty Kallen, Hall & Oates, Grant Shaud, Julie Gold, Clint Holmes, Bobby Rydell, Divine, Peggy King, Teddy Pendergrass and many others.

Sanctuary will play the following schedule July at The Capital Fringe in DC, https://www.capitalfringe.org, Edinburgh Fringe Festival, https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on - q=sanctuary and the UnitedSolo Festival in New York, http://unitedsolo.org/us/sanctuary-2015/For more information about the Off-Broadway production log onto: www.sanctuarytheplay.com .  

Why did I write this?

This project began for me many years ago when I was watching coverage of the conflict in serbo- croatia. As it unfolded I was shocked and appalled that this could be happening. I couldn’t believe that after the tragedy of the Holocaust that the world could still tolerate ‘Ethnic Cleansing.’ I couldn’t understand how this could happen.What does it take for a group of people to decide to slaughter each other.What do the dissenters do ? How do the women react? And of course conversely I was aware that it appeared the only way to stop this violence was to use even greater force.Which seamed incongruous. Many years later my own life has unfolded, I have children, I have experienced 9-11 and the following wars, I have experienced CNN,ABC,CBS, NBC,BBC, CNBC, etc. and what seems like a constant barrage of horrors in the world. I have become fascinated with news coverage and the question of how a reporter remains impartial. In those many years I still had not figured out what to do to make the world a better place. I felt completely and utterly impotent. When 9-11 happened I decided I had to do something, anything. I began small, donating money or used clothing or shoes, helping at food banks, I said yes to as many things as I could. None of these things had a direct link to 9-11. It did not matter to me. I was learning that every small thing makes a difference. I was beginning to have faith in humanity again. I was walking toward my sanctuary. I sealed the envelope, affixed the stamp and mailed my application to the Fringe Festival.When I did that the gears were set in motion and opportunities, allies and teachers were put in my path. I began to believe in synchronicity again.This has been a big step. My purpose is to say out loud, we need to do better.We can do better.We are obligated to support Iraq and rebuild and we should be obligated to caring for our own as well.We can do both. Peace is inevitable. I will keep saying that otherwise it will never happen. My goal is to leave the world a little better than when I found it.

I hope I have not misled you, I am actually asking you to do something. Help me. Help us. One small thing at a time. Do something, any thing, just begin.

of war on women over the centuries. The multi-character play features a
suburban housewife, a TV news reporter (inspired by CNN correspondent
Christiane Amanpour), and a P.O.W.  in Kosovo -- among other
characters.   Having been particularly moved by the Serbo-Croatian
conflict in the 1990‘s and the 9/11 tragedy, Sulby was inspired to write Sanctuary from
her relationship with television news and its ability to bring the journeys of
those surrounded by war into her home. The heart-felt stories made her question
her own various roles as a woman in these conflicts --- as the observer,
victim, mother, and wife. She watched, from the comfort of her Pennsylvania
home, a passive participant, as its horrors unfolded. “I was compelled to watch
but struggled to understand the bleak absurdity of this slaughter. Although I
was mesmerized by the news coverage, I initially felt impotent to respond. I
searched so I could find my own path to sanctuary, simply put
action, however small,” says Sulby.An established actor, designated Linklater
voice instructor, dialect coach and voiceover artist, Ms. Sulby has performed
for over 20 years. Favorite roles include Gertrude in Hamlet with Rev Theatre,
Aunt Bobbie in American Sligo with New City Stage Company, Yelena in Black
Russian with InterAct Theatre , Molly Bloom in A
Dublin Bloom based on James Joyce’s Ulysses , directed by Gregory
Doran of the Royal Shakespeare Company and Queen Elizabeth in Richard
III with Novel Stages. Her first film role was playing opposite Billy
Crudup in the 2000 award-winning Evenstar feature film, Jesus’ Son.
Her film credits as dialect coach include the recent feature film, Silver
Linings Playbook (nominated for 8 Academy Awards) directed by David O.
Russell, starring Bradley Cooper, Robert DeNiro and Jacki Weaver.Fresh from
having penned and staged last season’s Off Broadway hit musical “Lady Day”
starring Dee Dee Bridgewater, Stephen Stahl comes to Sanctuary as
a seasoned writer and director. His production, directorial and industrial
credits include numerous professional stage shows, award-winning films and a
decade of writing, producing and directing the Philadelphia Music Awards. Mr. Stahl
has directed, written for, produced and worked with Billy Joel, Bill Cosby,
Patti LaBelle, Kathy Sledge, Sandy Duncan, Jason Bateman, Phyllis Hyman, Kitty
Kallen, Hall & Oates, Grant Shaud, Julie Gold, Clint Holmes, Bobby Rydell,
Divine, Peggy King, Teddy Pendergrass and many others.
Sanctuary will play the following schedule July at The Capital
Fringe in DC, https://www.capitalfringe.org,
Edinburgh Fringe Festival, https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on
- q=sanctuary and the UnitedSolo Festival in New York, http://unitedsolo.org/us/sanctuary-2015/For
more information about the Off-Broadway production log onto: www.sanctuarytheplay.com .  

Why did I write this?This project began for me many years ago when I was watching coverage of the conflict in serbo- croatia. As it
unfolded I was shocked and appalled that this could be happening. I couldn’t believe that after the tragedy of
the Holocaust that the world could still tolerate ‘Ethnic Cleansing.’ I couldn’t understand how this could
happen.What does it take for a group of people to decide to slaughter each other.What do the dissenters do ?
How do the women react? And of course conversely I was aware that it appeared the only way to stop this
violence was to use even greater force.Which seamed incongruous. Many years later my own life has unfolded,
I have children, I have experienced 9-11 and the following wars, I have experienced CNN,ABC,CBS,
NBC,BBC, CNBC, etc. and what seems like a constant barrage of horrors in the world. I have become
fascinated with news coverage and the question of how a reporter remains impartial. In those many years I still
had not figured out what to do to make the world a better place. I felt completely and utterly impotent. When
9-11 happened I decided I had to do something, anything. I began small, donating money or used clothing or
shoes, helping at food banks, I said yes to as many things as I could. None of these things had a direct link to
9-11. It did not matter to me. I was learning that every small thing makes a difference. I was beginning to have
faith in humanity again. I was walking toward my sanctuary. I sealed the envelope, affixed the stamp and mailed
my application to the Fringe Festival.When I did that the gears were set in motion and opportunities, allies and
teachers were put in my path. I began to believe in synchronicity again.This has been a big step. My purpose is
to say out loud, we need to do better.We can do better.We are obligated to support Iraq and rebuild and we
should be obligated to caring for our own as well.We can do both. Peace is inevitable. I will keep saying that
otherwise it will never happen. My goal is to leave the world a little better than when I found it.

						I hope I have not misled you, I am actually asking you to do something. Help me. Help us. One small thing at a
time. Do something, any thing, just begin.

story:
OVERVIEW

“American exceptionalism gone interstellar”

Giant Leap is a punchy, fast-talking, foul-mouthed comedy-drama. Set in a top-secret subterranean room, we join three writers, a secretary, a psychotic hollywood producer and a colonel as they spar and fret over a script integral to the hoaxing of the 1969 moon ‘landing.’

This production examines the stories we tell ourselves to justify our actions, the role of myth in a nation’s conception of itself, and the powerful narcotic that lies in promising each individual their own American Dream. Featuring brutally funny dialogue and starring internationally acclaimed comedians Phil Nichol and Tom Stade, GIANT LEAP needs to be seen at this summer's Edinburgh Fringe.

Fresh from the recent critical and popular success of their British Independent Film Award nominated debut feature GREGOR (www.gregormovie.com) starring Matt King (PEEP SHOW), GIANT LEAP represents writers Mickey and Konrad’s first project for the stage -  a unique moment in the creative life of these rising talents. 

After a spell working for the Royal Shakespeare Company as Assistant Director on West End hit play OPPENHEIMER, GIANT LEAP will be a significant independent production for young director Alexander Lass. 

WHAT WE NEED

Bringing new plays to life is difficult, and bringing them to life amongst the crowded passageways of Edinburgh is even harder.  We need your help to make this play happen!

We hope to raise enough money to cover the costs of the production, and be in a position to offer an honorarium to all six cast members. We feel very strongly that no theatre-artists should have to work for free, let alone at a deficit, just because the production is for the fringe.  Your generous support will go towards the following specific areas:

-Cast remuneration

-Accommodation

-Marketing and PR

-Show budget (set, costumes, props etc)

 WHAT YOU GET 

We appreciate all of your help bringing Giant Leap to the Fringe, and as a thank you, we are offering a selection of goodies in return for your generous donations:

- Personal thanks on the show website and across social media

- Posters signed by cast

- Pair of tickets to a preview in London

- Exclusive access to rehearsals

- Early draft of the script with handwritten edits

- Pair of tickets to the show in Edinburgh

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that some of you will be unable to help financially BUT there are many other ways you can help!

- Share the campaign on your social networking sites

- Tell EVERYONE  about the show 

- Come and see us at the Edinburgh Fringe 

- Use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you for your support!

story:
Short Summary

Finding Margo, Losing Gus draws its inspiration from the work of bestselling author John Green, whose Young Adult novels portray teens struggling to make sense out of life and answer the big questions – from learning to empathize and “imagine others complexly” to dealing with tragedy and loss and the unromantic realities of life. Green is best known for his novel “The Fault in Our Stars,” which deals with sixteen-year-old cancer survivors confronting their own mortality and attempting to love and support each other with the little time they have left.

Throughout all four of Green’s bestselling novels run the themes of love and loss, the intricate reality of relationships, and the complex emotions that go along with them. Finding Margo, Losing Gus investigates these themes further, jumping into the space between the novels to explore both the similarities between characters and the diversity of relationships, with particular focus on the un-romanticized reality of so-called “romantic” relationships, and the idea that being there to support your partner in everyday problems is sometimes more important than physical attraction.

Dates: Saturday August 8th at 8 pm, and Sunday August 9th at 2 pm

Location: Monroeville Public Library, 4000 Gateway Campus Blvd, Monroeville PA 15146

Suggested Donation: $15 (will be split between Geeksdanz and the Monroeville Library)


What We Need & What You Get

To make this performance really special, we need a larger budget. We've got more costume pieces and props than usual, and we've upped our publicity game with custom-designed bookmarks handed out at local bookstores. We're also on a longer time frame, which means higher compensation for the dancers. Plus, we have an assortment of beautifully-creative original music selections that were composed for us by a full half-dozen independent composers – all fans of John Green's work – and they need to be compensated for their amazing work as well. Over three-quarters of our goal is dedicated to performer compensation. Once we pass the $700 mark all of our necessary production costs will be covered, and every penny donated past that mark goes towards our performers – the more you donate, the more these amazing people get paid!

In return, you'll get to choose from an incredible selection of awesome perks – check them out in the sidebar! Perks include cool souvenirs like T-shirts, signed posters and DVDs of the show, and exciting events like a coffee chat with the Artistic Director, an invitation to a private rehearsal, or dinner with the whole company! At several reward levels you can also receive the special honor of having officially sponsored a dancer or fulfilled a specific production need, such as paying for our costumes or our promotional materials. There's something for everyone – check them out and choose your favorite!

The Impact

Geeksdanz’s mission is to introduce dance to audiences that would not normally be drawn to it, and to illustrate the universality of dance as a means of emotional expression. Geeksdanz achieves this by systematically applying the context of dance to an enormous variety of topics and interests, and targeting performances towards the specific audiences who share those interests.

In April of 2013, we presented Challenge Mode, a concert about video games, to an audience comprised of both dance patrons and gamers.  As part of our mission, we presented an excerpt of Challenge Mode at Tekkoshocon X-2, a Japanese Pop Culture convention, and Artistic Director Ellen Deutsch led a discussion panel titled "An Artist's Views on the Games-As-Art Debate." Our second feature work, "Up to Chance," was a real-time dance interpretation of a live Dungeons and Dragons game, which we presented at the Pittsburgh Fringe Festival in May 2014.  In anticipation of our Halloween concert each year, we present excerpts from our storytelling shows at the Ghost Stories concert at the Three Rivers Storytelling Festival. All of these works continue our mission to introduce dance to other audiences.

In anticipation of Finding Margo, Losing Gus, we presented an excerpt at the Carnegie Library's 2015 Summer Reading Extravaganza. Our performance sparked interest in our work among the reading enthusiast community, and we're looking forward to an audience of avid readers in addition to avid dance patrons.  Your contributions will help us broaden our audience yet again, and encourage even more people to consider dance as an exciting evening's entertainment.  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute, don't sweat it!  Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word on facebook, twitter, tumblr, etc. and make some noise about our campaign!

  • Tell all your friends, especially those who live in Pittsburgh, and encourage them to come see the show!

  • Come to the show yourself!

story:
In 2013, the League initiated a program to offer member companies and artists heavily-subsidized rehearsal space.

The cost of insurance for this program has gone up, but we want to continue to provide this service to the Independent Theater community. We're looking to raise the money we need to ensure another successful year with the subsidized insurance program.

Several times a year, we grant access to our subsidized rehearsal space to help theater companies develop new work without the high hourly cost of renting their own space.

Join with us to help ensure that this program continues.

Here are all the companies we have helped so far. Please help us grow this list!


Collaborative Town

Flux Theater Ensemble

Lesbian Love Octagon

Tin Drum

Bommerang

Clancy Productions

Elephant Run District

The Assembly

YaYa Productions

Up and Down Theatre Company

The Hive

terraNOVA

New Ohio

No. 11 Productions

Ego Actus

underground zero

Peculiar Works

Slightly Altered State

NY Madness

Pull Together Productions

Messenger

Roi Escudero

Funny Sheesh

Hamlet Isn't Dead

story:
About the Show

Let It Come Down portrays the relationship between therapist and patient as a seductive love more powerful and volatile than any romance and unmasks a doctor who attempts to destroy her patient in order to save herself. Rachel is a vivacious yet distraught young woman exploring her family secrets and fears about children with her maternal therapist Marilyn. But when Marilyn faces questions in a lawsuit for abruptly terminating Rachel’s treatment, she paints her as violent. Is Rachel dangerous as her therapist claims? Or is the doctor hiding her own emotional and ethical violations? Inspired by actual deposition transcripts, this tale of betrayal ignites a dialogue about the dynamics of therapy and the blurry line between obsession and love.

Background

Let it Come Down will premiere at Theater for the New City's Dream Up 2015 Festival for five performances in September (9/8, 10, 12, 13, 16) on the heels of a reading there in March and a workshop at Dixon Place.  The play was also shortlisted for the Tangent Theatre Company’s New Plays Festival and the Landing Theatre Company’s New American Voices series.

EVE LEDERMAN’s (playwright) essays have been featured in The New York Times and she has told stories on stage at The Players Club, The Bryant Park Reading Room and the Museum of Jewish Heritage. Her memoir Letters From My Sister: On Life, Love and Hair Removal was released by Skyhorse Publishing last year.

What We Need

Your donations will directly fund: 4 actors, director, casting director, stage manager, publicist, rehearsal space, theater participation fee, sound design, set design, lighting, costumes, marketing material. The festival appearance is our next step towards a full production.

    Our Team

    JANA ROBBINS (Lead actress) covered Tyne Daly as Mama Rose starring in  Broadway's "Gypsy" and appeared opposite Valerie Harper in the national tour of "The Tale of the Allergist's Wife." JanaRobbins.com

    ADAM GALE (Producer) was one of the producers of the Broadway revival of “Godspell.” He also produced the Off-Broadway musical “Eat, Drink & Be
    Merry” (Minetta Lane Theatre) and was a consultant on the Off-Broadway musical “Rooms” (New World Stages). Gale holds a J.D. from the University of Pennsylvania Law School and practiced as an entertainment attorney for 30 years.

    FRANK M. CALO (Producer) brings more than 20 years of industry experience. His critically acclaimed film "The Believer" starring Ryan Gosling won the Grand Jury Prize at the 2001 Sundance Festival.

    HOLLY ROSEN FINK  (Associate Producer) has produced the annual "Listen to Your Mother" at Symphony Space and "The Best of Everything" at HERE. She also marketed "Almost Home" at the Director's Company.

    KATHERINE M. CARTER (Director) is the founding Artistic Director of The Other Mirror, and the co-founding Artistic Director of The MITTEN Lab. She is a two-time director in the Directors Company Adaptations for the Stage Workshop, the 2011-2012 Playwrights Horizons Directing Resident, a Drama League Rough Draft Fellow, and a guest director at NYU's Stella Adler and Atlantic Schools.
    If you'd like to make a front money investment or tax-deductible donation through our fiscal sponsor Theater Resources Unlimited, please contact Adam Gale at argocommunications@gmail.com.

    Thank you for your generous contribution and please help spread the word!

story:
Help Create the Best in New Radio Drama

By contributing to this campaign, you're helping build a production company dedicated to producing the best in classic radio revival!

  • Spencer Richardson here! For quite some time now, radio drama has been a huge personal creative outlet. In the past three years I have written/ produced/ starred in over eight productions, and been a member of three different production companies, including Play it by Ear, Raider Radio, and my own production company, Richardson Revival Radio.
  • Having completed our academic careers, our production team, and resources are no longer available to Richardson Revival Radio. In order to continue to deliver the best stories we can across the web, we need all new recording equipment!
  • Contributing to this campaign will ensure the continued output of fantastic radio drama for years to come.

What We Need & What You Get

Here's a breakdown of what we need:

  • All of the funds contributed to this campaign will go towards new recording equipment, including the following:
  • Recording mic.
  • Audio interface.
  • XLR cable.
  • Mic stand.
  • So what do you get? We have some very enticing perks for our most loyal fans, and newcomers as well! Posters, signed scripts, even a special place in our credits. You could even snag a flash drive loaded with our shows!
  • Even if we don't reach our goal, the money we do make will go towards making sure we can get back on the air.

The Impact

  • The art of radio drama is wonderful, and deserves to live on beyond  the golden days of broadcast. We work our hardest to bring interesting stories to listeners young and old, across a digital platform tailored for todays audience.
  • This isn't our first rodeo! Richardson Revival Radio is responsible for four (and counting) outstanding radio dramas, including the hugely popular BioShock series radio adaptation.
  • Just take a look at some of our past projects: https://www.youtube.com/user/onerichardson/videos

Risks & Challenges

We know that audio recording can be a complicated and tricky process, but fear not!

  • All of the equipment required has been used and mastered in past productions, so we know exactly what we're handling, no technical issues or surprises here! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help to spread the word! The more people who know about our campaign, the more successful we can be! Whether its $1 or $100, every little bit makes a difference!
  • Remember, you can share this campaign right from Indiegogo to all your favorite social media sites with just a few clicks!

We work our hardest to bring interesting stories to listeners young and old, across a digital platform tailored for todays audience. This isn't our first rodeo! Richardson Revival Radio is responsible for four (and counting) outstanding radio dramas, including the hugely popular BioShock series radio adaptation. Just take a look at some of our past projects: https://www.youtube.com/user/onerichardson/videos
    Risks & Challenges  We know that audio recording can be a complicated and tricky process, but fear not!  All of the equipment required has been used and mastered in past productions, so we know exactly what we're handling, no technical issues or surprises here!     Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:  Help to spread the word! The more people who know about our campaign, the more successful we can be! Whether its $1 or $100, every little bit makes a difference! Remember, you can share this campaign right from Indiegogo to all your favorite social media sites with just a few clicks!

story:
FUND US! 

Highland Springs High School is a public High School located in historic Highland Springs Virginia.  First opened in 1907, it is among the oldest schools in Henrico County, outside of Richmond VA.  

Kyla Zabala came to HSHS in 2011 as a full time Drama and English Teacher.  Matt Atkinson and Kyla Zabala have taken the defunct Theatre program at HSHS and created a thriving theatrical family at HSHS.   

This past June, HSHS Drama was asked to perform the school musical,  IN THE HEIGHTS,  at FIREHOUSE THEATRE in Richmond,  Va.   

With this funding we hope to keep alive the tradition of Theatrical excellence at HSHS. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking for $800 to fund our production of A RAISIN IN THE SUN.   This backing will help create Highland Spring's production of Lorainne Hansberry's A RAISIN IN THE SUN by financing set production, programs and the royalties for the show.   
* Rights $430 
*Programs $200
*Set $300 
If we do not reach our goal the funds will be allocated to the rights for the performance first. 

PERKS! 

 By donating $5- Travis Level -You will receive a shout out in the program.   
$10- Beneatha, you receive a HSHS DRAMA Bumper Sticker and a shout out in the program. 
$20- Walter Lee, you receive a shout out and two tickets to the evening of your choice (Must be reserved in advance by emailing ktzabala@henrico.k12.va.us)
$50 -Ruth, you receive a shout out, two tickets to the evening of your choice (Must be reserved in advance by emailing ktzabala@henrico.k12.va.us), and a signed program.  
$100- Lena - You get a shout out in the program, a HSHS Drama bumper sticker, two free tickets to the show on the date of your choice, a signed program, and an HSHS Drama T-shirt.

Risks & Challenges

Our main challenge is lack of backing and financial support.   While our cast and crew are more than willing to help where they can, our school is situated in a low income district.   We currently have 65% of our students on Free and Reduced Price Lunch.   Many of our students need the support of extra curricular activities to avoid the constant social pressures of living in their community.   

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate to our fund today, please forward it on to your friends and family and ask for their support.   It is a tax deductible donation.   

Also, if you are in the local RVA area, we are always looking for new volunteers, please contact Josh at jdbillion@gmail.com

story:
Help us provide opportunities for youth at risk in Western Australia.

“Suicide is an enormous problem in the Kimberley. An 18-year-old Indigenous male is seven times more likely to die by suicide compared to his non-Indigenous peers” - Advances in Mental Health (2012)

Dreamtime Dancers is a community engagement  project for young people in Broome, Western Australia, delivered through the medium of contemporary Aboriginal dance. 

The project is a direct response to the vulnerabilities of at-risk young people in Broome, promoting Indigenous culture and heritage, encouraging creativity and physical exercise and building self-confidence.

We’re now hoping to embark on our most ambitious project to date – a whole new dance known as Nyul Nyul Traditional Stories. In order to do this we need to employ a dance choreographer from Perth (circa $4,000), secure a rehearsal studio (circa $2,000), and create new costumes (circa $4,000). The plan is for the troupe to travel over 2,000km and perform the dance at the Perth International Arts Festival in 2016. If we’re successful, we hope to tour it nationally in 2017 and internationally in 2018, and any funds we raise over the $10,000 goal will go towards making this a reality. 

Director Robert Dann is an Indigenous Australian and Nyul Nyul man, recognised in Australia and internationally as a dancer, choreographer and didgeridoo player. He promotes Indigenous culture and heritage wherever he goes. Dreamtime Dance Project workshops are open to any young people who wish to participate. We’ve performed at more than a dozen events and over 40 students now frequently attend our workshops. A number of our dancers have gone on to join Bangarra Dance Theatre, the Western Australia Academy of Performing Arts in Perth and NAISDA Dance College in Sydney.

Why Dreamtime Dancers Is Important

A recent survey on the social and emotional wellbeing of Indigenous young people in the Broome region found that young women are just as vulnerable to mental health problems as men – problems that include but are by no means limited to suicide and suicidal ideation. As the report concludes, the importance of fostering strong, positive and supportive environments cannot be overstated. Robert Dann aims to develop just such an environment in and through the Dreamtime Dancers Project.

Workshops in contemporary Aboriginal dance are delivered on Thursday and Friday afternoons. The workshops are free of charge and provide young people with an opportunity to come together and dance, learn contemporary Aboriginal dance technique and choreography, develop a repertoire of work, and perform together at events and festivals in the Broome area. In and through that process, students are encouraged to dance without shame (and to support each other in that), to become aware of themselves and others as creative agents, and to see themselves as an important part of something larger than themselves, whether that be the nascent dance troupe or the broader community.

While the project has principally been developed and implemented for Aboriginal young people in Broome and, even more specifically, for those whose circumstances and/or behaviour means that they are subject to heightened levels of risk, the workshops are open. Irrespective of culture or personal circumstance, if you are a young person and you want to participate, you are welcome.

The underlying idea is that in and through common endeavour – in this case, a shared practice in dance and the gradual development of career pathways – differences can be celebrated and divisions overcome. And it is through such a shared endeavour, and through its engagement with the broader Broome community (through the medium of performance and the living web of mutual effort and care that underwrites the project), that Dreamtime Dancers will foster a strong, positive and supportive environment.

The direct costs of the project are prohibitive of salaries (except in the case of budgeted involvement from guest teachers and/choreographers) and, consequently, the project is fuelled by the pro bono work of Robert, his sister Cecelia and the project team, the in- kind contributions of Burdekin Youth in Action (the importance of whose much needed assistance transporting students to an from the workshops cannot be overestimated), and the generosity of volunteers.

At present, Broome lacks a cultural dance troupe and it is anticipated that the performances will eventually generate a small but symbolic income for the project (to be reinvested in the project) and, in the process, will enrich the Broome community. 

Despite the generosity of our patrons, the project is underfunded. There are direct costs associated with the engagement dimension of the project, including but by no means limited to the provision of transport to and from the workshops, adequate support and supervision during the workshops and development of future events.

In terms of student participation, the response to the project has been overwhelming. Attendance fluctuates from week to week but the workshops are frequently delivered to over 40 students (an attendance rate that combines both younger and older students). In terms of enjoyment, the response is evident in the peals of laughter during workshops, the focus that students bring to the dances, and reports from families that their children speak with pride of their dancing.


Perks

We’ve been lucky enough to receive support from various local Broome businesses, who’ve donated everything from boutique accommodation at Lord McAlpine House, to car hire, plus an authentically crafted original didgeridoo, Aboriginal art and jewelery made from locally harvested Broome pearls.

We’re working together with Loving Earth, a chocolate company from Melbourne, who have provided us with lots of prize packs which you can claim as perks in exchange for your donation. Our connection with them is due to Gubinge, a native Australian superfood and highest percentage Vitamin C plant in the world, which they use in their chocolate and other snacks. Robert’s tribe, the Nyul Nyul, have been working with Loving Earth to wild harvest the Gubinge Fruit since 2008. His cousin Bruno is our primary organiser in the Kimberley.

For our top prize, we’re offering one donor the chance to be flown out to Broome and experience the Nyul Nyul way of life in the Kimberley, one of the world’s most remote wildernesses - full accommodation and board provided!


The Project Director

An Indigenous Australian and Nyul Nyul man, Robert Dann is recognized in Australia and internationally as a dancer, choreographer and didgeridoo player. He promotes Indigenous culture and heritage wherever he goes.

Robert’s journey in dance started with the Modern Dreamtime Dancers, a local dance troupe in Broome that dissolved with the rezoning of CDEP. He later studied Choreography, Aboriginal Dance Development and Aboriginal Theatre at the Aboriginal Centre of Performing Arts in Perth. He has travelled extensively since then, collaborating and performing with the likes of Bangarra, choreographing dances for theatre productions and film, and developing his own work for smaller independent troupes, as when he led the Ninjlm group on an 8-week tour of Europe. Recently he performed ceremonial dances at the Vatican for the canonization of Australia’s first saint, St Mary McKillop.

Robert is deeply committed to the Dreamtime Dancers project. In the longer term, he aims to develop a permanent not-for-profit dance school and performance troupe in Broome with strong affiliations with the Aboriginal Theatre Arts course at the Western Australian Academy of Performing Arts.

If you can’t donate yourself, and even if you can, we would love to see you share our story as far and wide as possible! Tell the world and help us provide opportunities for youth at risk in Western Australia.

story:
The Actors Table of Eugene is a labor of love for all involved - a small showcase production company, we offer 4- 5 showcases performances per year, featuring local actors and actresses performing pieces of their own choosing.  It is a labor of love for our founder, who started the program in honor of her late sister, and to give back to the Eugene theater community.  It is also a labor of love for all of the actors and directors and writers who give their time for free.  Since our very first show, we have been hosted by Tsunami Books.  Donations are given by audience members at the events, and Tsunami and T.A.T.E. split that pot.  


Those donations have been (almost) sufficient to help T.A.T.E. sustain its costs (printing of programs, posters, and refreshments for the audience), but have never covered the costs that Tsunami sustains in staying open extra hours to host the shows.  Tsunami Books is  known for its dedication to supporting the arts in this community, and it is important to us at T.A.T.E. to assist Tsunami in doing so.  We would like to be able to increase our annual budget enough to actually reimburse Tsunami and the staff for their costs, and cover our costs 100%.  An additional $1,000 would do that for us, and for Tsunami.


There are some who support the arts no matter what it costs them, personally or  professionally, and we at T.A.T.E. feel that we should do everything we can to reciprocate for the incredible support Tsunami has given to our program.  Please help us to show them that we appreciate the work they do for the arts in this community by helping us to pay them their actual costs for hosting our shows.  


If our full amount is not raised, all funds raised will be used for T.A.T.E. production costs, with paying a reasonable rent to Tsunami Books as first priority, 


For those who help us, we are offering a variety of perks, from professionally made buttons supporting T.A.T.E. and our partner company, Found Space Theater, to tickets to Found Space’s next production, Talking With, to gift certificates for a night on the town.  


If you can’t contribute funds, or want to do more to help, you can also help us considerably by:

  • Getting the word out via social media - share our campaign on Facebook, Twitter, everywhere!

  • Send emails to your friends with a link to our campaign.

  • use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign anywhere - send it to your friends and family, and share it as OFTEN as you can on social media!! The more exposure we get, the more likely we are to be successful!  Thanks so much!


BACKGROUND:

In the 1980s and 1990s, a talented young actress in Seattle, Washington founded an itinerant performing group she called “The Actors’ Table.” Following auditions and performances, she and her theater colleagues frequently gathered at a local tavern called “The Comet” to discuss theater, performances, and simply to be together. They always sat at the same table, near a stage in the back room, which the owners began to call “The Actors’ Table.” One evening, when no performance group was scheduled, the actors got up and began to perform short pieces for the gathered crowd, and, before long, it became a regular “event” at The Comet, drawing large crowds every time. That actress was Jean Marie Kinney, a long-time Seattle stage presence with experience on Broadway and in film. 

 Ms. Kinney passed away unexpectedly and tragically in 1998, and, shortly thereafter, her sister, Judith McKenzie, moved to Eugene and became involved in the local theater community. Always in the back of her mind was the notion of the energy and passion that her sister had brought to her performance group, and the energy and enjoyment those events brought to the Seattle crowds. Ms. McKenzie, recently retired from a faculty position at Lane Community College, wished to do the same thing for her theater colleagues and the Eugene community. In 2012, having gathered backing for the events and the participation of a committed group of actors, she founded The Actors’ Table of Eugene.

story:
LAKE VICTORY

I'm Ethan Fishbane, the writer and director of "A Presentation by the People of Lake Victory for Our Leader".  This is an expanded, full-length production that I've been working on for the past few years, and I am so excited to present its 15-performance run at The Gym at Judson Memorial Church here in NYC from July 13-August 2, 2015! This piece works to explore the interactions and lifestyle of the people of Lake Victory, my own vision of the last true communist state on earth.  Lake Victory is an imagined village where rules dominate and love is reserved for one great man who rules over all.  The show first debuted in 2014 at The Assembly at Judson Church to an extremely positive response.  With the wonderful creative playground that is Judson, we have worked to bring this show to life again in an even greater way.

We are working with a top-notch cast and crew, but this show can't happen without you!

We need to raise money to make Lake Victory become more than just words on a page.  Aside from the ideas and the script, we need to pay for the theatre, rent rehearsal space, make costumes, purchase properties, assemble promotional materials, and of course pay our incredibly talented cast and creative team!  And the list goes on!

With your assistance, we not only get to put on this show, (which I am so excited to share), we also get to keep asking questions about people, governments, and how we see the world.  You can become a part of this dialogue and all it takes is a small contribution!

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise money for the theatre, costumes, set, rehearsal studio rentals, space rentals, properties, lights, sound, and to pay the team making this world come to life!

We have some really exciting perks that should pump you up about donating! From an exciting new poster designed by Denny Khurniawan (as well as the original Lake Victory artwork), to some amazing original music by Eric Namaky, to dinner and drinks!  Everyone gets to be a part of the fun!

The Impact

In 2013, I brought my show "ASBA: The American Suicide Bomber Association" to South Africa.  I raised funds through a similar campaign and was so lucky to meet my goal and tour my show to Johannesburg.  Without the kindness and assistance of the global citizens who contributed along the way, I wouldn't have been able to create the discussion I lent way to in South Africa as I did here in NYC.  

Let's all be part of this conversation!

My performances are about more than the show itself.  I want to inspire conversation and new understanding of the world.  By donating to this project, you are donating to a book that is just opening.  The impact may not seem outwardly effective, but the impact you are making will be tremendous! 

By donating, you are sharing in this process with all of us!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign!
Share "A Presentation by the People of Lake Victory for Our Leader" on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter!
Share your experiences with the performance or performers!
Share in the performance itself!

We can't wait to see you there, and in the meantime we will be working hard!

All the best,

Ethan Fishbane

your assistance, we not only get to put on this show, (which I am so 
excited to share), we also get to keep asking questions about people, 
governments, and how we see the world.  You can become a part of this 
dialogue and all it takes is a small contribution!   What We Need & What You Get We need to raise money for the theatre, costumes, set, rehearsal studio rentals, 
space rentals, properties, lights, sound, and to pay the team making this world come to life!We have some really exciting 
perks that should pump you up about donating! From an exciting new poster 
designed by Denny Khurniawan (as well as the original Lake Victory artwork), to some amazing original music by Eric Namaky, to dinner and drinks!  Everyone gets to 
be a part of the fun!
  The Impact
In 2013, I brought my show "ASBA: The American Suicide Bomber 
Association" to South Africa.  I raised funds through a similar campaign
 and was so lucky to meet my goal and tour my show to Johannesburg.  
Without the kindness and assistance of the global citizens who 
contributed along the way, I wouldn't have been able to create the 
discussion I lent way to in South Africa as I did here in NYC.  
Let's all be part of this conversation!My
 performances are about more than the show itself.  I want to inspire 
conversation and new understanding of the world.  By donating to this 
project, you are donating to a book that is just opening.  The impact 
may not seem outwardly effective, but the impact you are making will be 
tremendous!  By donating, you are sharing in this process with all of us!
  Other Ways You Can HelpShare this campaign!Share "A Presentation by the People of Lake Victory for Our Leader" on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter!Share your experiences with the performance or performers!Share in the performance itself!We can't wait to see you there, and in the meantime we will be working hard!All the best,Ethan Fishbane

story:
Who We Are

The San Diego Asian Artists Ensemble is a faith based organization on a mission to create opportunities for San Diego Asian Artists to write and express their stories through theater, new media, TV and film.  Dedicated to creating thought provoking, entertaining moving pictures through theatre, new media and film.  Giving voice to our local Asian community's experiences and life stories. Exploring themes relating to family, love, friendship, sex, interracial dating, cultural differences, generation gaps, and mundane experiences.  SDAAE aims to celebrate diversity and create non-stereotypical, multi-dimensional characters that reflects truth in our community.  

Our inaugural production, San DiAsians is a titillating presentation of sketch comedy and monologues with a splash of music, dance and martial arts featuring some of the most talented Asian Artists in San Diego.  Celebrating cultural differences while provocatively poking fun at racial stereotypes and pop culture.  Hosted by one of America’s all time favorite Asian actor and martial artist. Written by the San Diego Asian Artists Ensemble. Directed by Founder & Artistic Director, Kiki Yeung. Kiki's Website & Bio

The Ensemble

Ikaika Patria - Comedian, Martial Artist, Musician, Actor, Writer  Facebook 
Isak Allen - Comedian, Musician, Actor, Writer  Facebook
Chip Nicholson - Comedian, Actor, Writer  Website
Aneissa Adame - Dancer, Actor, Writer  Facebook
Nikki Hsueh - Actor, Writer  Facebook
Chuck Ng - Musician, Writer  Facebook
Paul Lim - Musician, Writer  Website
Eduard Cao - Writer  Facebook / Youtube

What We Need 

Producing theater cost money and we need your support!  Your contributions whether $10 or $500 are greatly appreciated.  Your money is sowing a seed into making the dreams of these artists come to life!

*To pay for application, production, rehearsal, tech and performance venue fees at San Diego Fringe Festival and Hollywood Fringe Festival 2016.  

*To pay for our marketing campaign & publicity materials (posters, postcards, banners, ads, etc).

*To pay our actors, technical crew & designers.

*To cover the cost of filming equipment, set, costumes and props. "So we can produce a high quality production!"

*Funds to jump start our 2016 season production of "San DiAsians."  


What You Get

From a heartfelt THANK YOU to one on one acting and stand up comedy coaching sessions.  We will even write a song in your honor, film it and send it to you for bragging rights!



Other Ways You Can Help

Like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter and other social media sites.  Spread the word!  Forward the Indiegogo Link to people you know who would support our cause!  COME SEE SAN DIASIANS!

story:
The 19th Annual IRNE Awards

The Independent Reviewers of New England proudly present the 2015 IRNE Awards.  Once again, we host the biggest party of the year for greater Boston’s theater community for an evening of celebration and appreciation of a year in the theater.  There are nominees in 54 categories, recognizing the companies, directors, playwrights, actors, designers, and choreographers who strive to keep Boston’s audiences enthralled with vibrant, exciting and challenging theater.

See this year's nominees on our Facebook Page at this link: The 2015 IRNE Award Nominees.

On April 13, we gather again to present the awards at the Cyclorama at the Boston Center for the Arts (doors and the cash bar begins serving at 7 pm, awards presentations begin at 7:30 p.m.).  All are invited and for the 19th consecutive year, we insist it’s FREE to attend, no ticket required.  All are welcome to celebrate the theater community.

The IRNE Committee is comprised of theater critics dedicated to celebrating the extraordinary talent in Boston Theater Community. No individual on the IRNE Committee receives any compensation and once again we’re reaching out to friends to lend some assistance in throwing one heck of a party.

What We Need & What You Get

It’s central to our mission that attending the IRNE Awards is free and open to all and that the whole world knows about it.  We are generously hosted again this year by the Boston Center for the Arts, but this year we need some additional assistance for some logistics like chair rentals, bar set up, and sound equipment.

We plan to celebrate those that help make this party happen, and this is where you come in.  All contributors will be recognized at the party – traditionally attended by well over 500 theater artists, supporters, and friends.  Let them know you appreciate their work, and that all their work, nominated or not, is a critical part of Boston’s cultural landscape.

Make no mistake – the nominees and the winners are the star of this show and we are gathered to thank and appreciate them and all who strive to bring magic to the stage.  But we all benefit from their contributions to art of theater, their talents, and their exploration of humanity on our stages. 

It is a community that works hard and all too frequently for few rewards beyond applause.  The IRNE Award is a small way to celebrate the achievements of some, but the impact of all.  Please join us in making this celebration worthy of their work.

The Impact

Contributions will be dedicated to practical things like rental of a sound system (so everyone can hear who the winners are), an audiovisual show (so everyone can see what the nominees look like), something to eat, places to sit and to promote what is the BIGGEST theater awards program in New England. 

Contributions at any level will be appreciated and recognized at the event. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We’ll confess – it’s been suggested we just sell the tickets.  We refuse.  All are welcome.  No ticket required. 

Many in the theater community work hard often for little or no pay, some even spend their own money on shows and give it their all.  Whether nominated or simply wishing to applaud their colleagues, we refuse to charge anyone an entrance fee. It’s their party.  It’s your party.

If you are not in a position to contribute, please share this campaign with any who’d like to help us celebrate, or forward to a business who might wish to reach this audience through a program ad.  A share on your Facebook page, a Tweet, and email to a few friends – every bit helps and we thank you.

story:
The Cause

The Nashville Sexual Assault Center (NSAC) and KB Productions Presents: Extremities by William Mastrosimone

April 3rd, 4th at 7:30pm, 5th at 5pm, and 9th, 10th, and 11th at 7:30pm at the Darkhorse Theatre in Nashville, TN.

April is Sexual Assault Awareness month, and KB Productions has teamed up with SAC to produce the play Extremities as a part of the Center’s month of events to raise funds for their facility, and provide an artistic outlet of expression for sexual assault survivors.


THE PLAY

A young woman, Marjorie, is attacked in her home by a would-be rapist, Raul, and manages to turn the tables on him, tying him up in her fireplace.  Threatening to set him on fire, she finds that he has been stalking her and watching her house for weeks.  Marjorie’s roommates come home to discover the attacker bound with cords, belts and other household items and imprisoned in the fireplace. Marjorie wants to kill him, thinking he will play the victim in court and will walk free to attack her another day. Terry and Patricia, the roommates, express different points of view about the assailant and rape in society. One roommate has always had faith in the justice system and wants to turn him in, and the other fears Marjorie will be will be in trouble with the law if she admits to defending herself. Leaving the friends divided, yet connected on the fate of Raul and Marjorie.


What We Need & What You Get

  • We are asking for $2,225 to cover costs for rights, crew, props, scenery, costumes, and advertising for our production of Extremities so that it can be the most professional, polished and exciting show that it can be. Any money not used and raised over the goal will go to the SAC.

  • The perks of donating to our campaign include:

  • Tickets with Reserved seating.

  • A show poster signed by the cast.

  • A shout out in the show program.

  • Passes to Cast Party with open bar (3 drink pass with ID)

  • Become a show or season sponsor for KB Productions, and have your business seen by lots of people!

  • The satisfaction of donating to the arts and seeing a great show.

  • Knowing your money will provide a healing and cathartic outlet for sexual assault survivors.

The Impact

Tickets will be $12, and each ticket is split with the theatre were we will be performing. So all money not going to pay the theatre will go to the SAC, provided we reach our fundraising goal.
If we sell out every night at $6/person, the show has the potential to raise $5,292 in ticket sales alone for SAC.
We could just ask you for money rather than putting on a play, but as artists, activists, and survivors ourselves, we need the audience to understand that we are creating a work to provoke, empower, educate, and heal.  
This will be challenging and cathartic to everyone, as we all know at one person who has been a survivor of sexual violence.  

Risks & Challenges

This is a small cast, so we need everyone to spread the word and not assume people will show up because it's for a good cause.

We want to raise money with our show. We need everyone to see one performance, to donate, and help us raise money for the Nashville Center.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Attend our shows!

  • Share the Facebook event.

  • Follow SAC and KB Productions on Facebook

  • Attend SAC events in April

  • Donate to SAC

story:
The video above is an outreach example from 2014's LES MISERABLES.



RENT in 2016

There's no day but today.  Help Hysterical Productions put on a production of RENT with the size, scope, outreach and educational depth of 2014's LES MISERABLES.

  • Hysterical Productions aims to inspire and inform all ages through fun, unique, dynamic productions and events, as well as workshops and classes.
  • It is our belief that a story inspires and moves through the people it presents. By bringing those people, fictional and/or historical, to life in a dynamic and creative way the stories of our past, present and future will take on new meaning-and inspire change within one's self, our community and society. It is Hysterical Production's goal not only to put breath into people and stories in unique ways, but also to train others in carrying on the tradition.

Your contribution here aids in the awareness and acceptance of many facets of the Oshkosh, and Fox Valley, communities!


What We Need & What You Get

At the moment:

  • We need to secure the rights for the production, a cost rounding $7,000
  • This funding for the project goes to securing the rights for the show.  Once the rights are secured we'll begin the casting and rehearsal process, as well as the community outreach, for the production.

The Impact

HP will use the love and lessons of RENT to raise awareness about:

  • LGBTQ acceptance and rights
  • AIDS and HIV protection and testing facility awareness
  • Connections and lessons from "La Boheme," the opera RENT draws inspiration from.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you just can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about this campaign.
  • Help us by using the Indiegogo share tools!
