story:
Hi, I am DADO. My stage has been stolen. The Doorway Cabaret is gone...

Over the Christmas holidays someone broke into my 1966 Toyota Coaster Bus that we had stored at the mechanics in Adelaide. They smashed the back window open and stole what they believed to be just another surf board.  Inside that surf board bag was my 1 and only stage and curtain, The Doorway Cabaret.

They stole the whole bag and rode off with it on my bike! They took; my outdoor stage, the curtain, the lights, the mic stand, the iPad holder, the battery, the power cables, the whole sha-bang.

But you can help, I am meant to be performing on the 22nd of January in Perth at the Fringeworld Festival with The Doorway Cabaret. But now I have no stage, no Doorway Cabaret.

For me to be ready to entertain and do shows on the 22nd I now have to; first find the money to rebuild, then find the people to help me rebuild. I am in Germany now and fly to Perth on the 16th. We will be arriving ready to hit the ground running, prepare for the show and start.

When you donate you will be helping me rebuild The Doorway Cabaret and giving me the ability to continue entertaining 1,000's of people just like you. Being a Fringe performer is not about the glamour (there is none) or making buckets of money (none of that either), it's about being able to share my work with everyone. The "Doorway Cabaret" is the only way for me to make money daily to cover  the expenses of being at the Fringe.

HOW to help and What we can do for YOU

To make it happen;

We need to re-build the Doorway Cabaret, buy the velvet for the curtains, the golden tassels and all the black material for the backing. Find a wonderful person to sew it all together and create the magic (pay them for their mad skills).€$800

We need to buy all new staging (the supports that go under the stage) and have it shipped from Melbourne to Perth. €$600

We need to buy new lighting so that you can see the show at night (batteries to run the lights and the cables to plug it all in). €$400

New poles (4) to support the curtain on the stage.€$180

We need a new mic stand so you can hear the show and an Ipad holder so that I can play the sound track.€$130

New Surf board bag to carry it all in.€$120

Once all this magic is put together I can do the shows that you all love and can continue to spread the laughter.

I have come up with some great perks that will include you in the magic. When you support me and this rebuild I will include you in the show, FB video shout out's from my audience, tickets to see my other indoor shows in Adelaide and Perth, Skype 1-on-1 instructions with me, a swag bag of clown happiness and much more.


All the funds from this project will be put directly to the rebuild. Every penny and dollar will help me accomplish this major goal.

The Impact

When we reach the goal it will give me the ability to hit the ground running and get the "Doorway Cabaret" back up and ready for Perth Fringeworld so no one misses a day. The "Doorway Cabaret" is the only way for me to cover my expenses at these fringe festivals with out it I am stuffed.

For the last 4 years I have been at the Perth Fringeworld Festival entertaining audiences with the "Doorway Cabaret". It's become a favorite and something that people are excited to see each year. The same in Adelaide. I have been supported by the crew of Gluttony at the Adelaide Fringe over the last few years. The connection that has been created with return audiences has been the best for me. I feel blessed to share my work with new audiences each year.


This year because I am also performing my indoor show I have invited other performers to be with me on the "Doorway Cabaret" stage in Perth and Adelaide. I hope that with your help we wont all be left hung out to dry. The Fringe festivals are a challenge when you are on-top of your game, but with this challenge there is no way I can make it with out your help.

    Risks & Challenges

    It's no joke that the clock is ticking. We have only a few days to get this solved. We fly out of Germany on the 16th of January and arrive in Perth on the 18th. Luckily I have some good connections in Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne.  Hopefully with these connections and people like you we will make it happen.

    The most important thing is to get the curtain built first so that at a bare minimum I can be ready to do shows on the opening night of the Perth Fringeworld Festival (Jan.22).

    Luckily being an artist I have some artist connections and other great artists that can help. I just need to find them, and get the money to pay them for the materials and their skills.


      Other Ways You Can Help

      Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

      Of course sharing this information with all of your friends would be super. Use the Indiegoo share tools.

      Have a look-out if you live in Adelaide, maybe you will find the stolen "Doorway Cabaret" and save the day. Indiegoo has created some wicked share tools.

      Maybe you know someone with a 1966 Toyota Coaster who has an extra back window? That would do us a world of good as they are as hard to find as hen's teeth.

running and get the "Doorway Cabaret" back up and ready for Perth 
Fringeworld so no one misses a day. The "Doorway Cabaret" is the only 
way for me to cover my expenses at these fringe festivals with out it I 
am stuffed.
For the last 4 years I have been at the Perth Fringeworld Festival entertaining audiences with the "Doorway Cabaret". It's become a favorite and something that people are excited to see each year. The same in Adelaide. I have been supported by the crew of Gluttony at the Adelaide Fringe over the last few years. The connection that has been created with return audiences has been the best for me. I feel blessed to share my work with new audiences each year.


This year because I am also performing my indoor show I have invited other performers to be with me on the "Doorway Cabaret" stage in Perth and Adelaide. I hope that with your help we wont all be left hung out to dry. The Fringe festivals are a challenge when you are on-top of your game, but with this challenge there is no way I can make it with out your help.     Risks & Challenges  
It's no joke that the clock is ticking. We have only a few days to get this solved. We fly out of Germany on the 16th of January and arrive in Perth on the 18th. Luckily I have some good connections in Perth, Adelaide and Melbourne.  Hopefully with these connections and people like you we will make it happen.
The most important thing is to get the curtain built first so that at a bare minimum I can be ready to do shows on the opening night of the Perth Fringeworld Festival (Jan.22). 
Luckily being an artist I have some artist connections and other great artists that can help. I just need to find them, and get the money to pay them for the materials and their skills.

    Other Ways You Can Help Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:
Of course sharing this information with all of your friends would be super. Use the Indiegoo share tools.
Have a look-out if you live in Adelaide, maybe you will find the stolen "Doorway Cabaret" and save the day. Indiegoo has created some wicked share tools.
Maybe you know someone with a 1966 Toyota Coaster who has an extra back window? That would do us a world of good as they are as hard to find as hen's teeth.

story:
Our Mission

Lovers of fine art are looking for something completely different―something that
cannot be found anywhere else. Paul Vigil's unique style of performance art can be found only where he happens to be. He performs his original pieces of magic and mind reading in some of the most exclusive theaters in the world, and it is our mission to bring the memorable moments he creates to a more permanent location: a home base for Paul to further develop his art and a theatrical attraction that will bring in audiences from all over the globe.

Contributors will receive items from our selection of memorabilia. The funds generated by this campaign will finance four shows at The Olympic Collection Banquet, Conference and Entertainment Center in Los Angeles on the evenings of October 23 and 24, 2015. Performances begin at 7:30 PM & 9:30 PM.

Seats will be limited to approximately 50 spots per show to ensure that everyone has an ideal vantage.


The Art of Legerdemain

While magic is the world's oldest art form, the performance of expert, artistic magic is still very rare. There may be a lot of comedy, many “tricks,” lots of fanfare, and hype, but there is little in the way of true astonishment, especially of the kind delivered with class and style right before your eyes. Paul Vigil, who has trained with some of the great masters of the 20th century, is one of the few artists in the world who performs this scarce form of theatrical conjuring.

The art of legerdemain (French for "lightness of hand") is also known as "prestidigitation." In its modern form, this art is only about 100 years old. As a practitioner of this style, Paul invites everyone in the audience to look as closely as they can. Even if you don't have a literal front-row seat, you feel as if you do.

Paul performs in front of a table, using ordinary objects, from playing cards and dice to cocktail olives and lemons, to playfully manipulate the viewers' perceptions. he can also use an assistant with a roaming camera to blast his manipulations onto large screens that can be seen from the back of the theater, if needed.

No matter the size of his audience, Paul somehow connects with each person's mind on an individual level. This is especially true when he transitions into the pure mind-reading portion of his performance. Even someone in the last row could be called upon to participate, perhaps by thinking of the contents of her purse or even a dream she's been having. Paul, despite the distance between them, can tell her exactly what her thoughts are.


Contributions for the Purposes of the Show 

  • To finance research of the performance space(s)-30% 
  • To fund construction and other production expenses-15% 
  • To pay for ticketing and promotional expenses-15% 
  • To fund payroll for stage crew members-10%
  • To spread real magic and performance art culture to the world -15%
  • To develop a strong show for television broadcasting and Off-Broadway in the near future-15%

About Two-time Merlin Award Winner Paul Vigil 

Paul Vigil is an American magician and mentalist. He is also an inventor, writer and lecturer, who has twice won the Merlin Award from the International Magicians Society. A specialist in sleight of hand and perceptual manipulation, he focuses on close-up and intimate magic and mind reading. His shows are designed to take discerning minds on a wild intellectual ride where fantasy and reality become indistinguishable.

Magic's cognoscenti have awarded “Magic Trick of the Year" to Paul numerous times. One such effect, "The Ladybug" was recently performed by Penn & Teller on The Tonight Show starring Jimmy Fallon. Paul's recent book on theatrical magic, Classic Fantastic, which was limited to 500 copies, virtually sold out the moment it was offered to the magic community.

Paul first discovered the magical arts when he was around six years old. Strolling around the local library, he stumbled upon Greater Magic by John Northern Hilliard, a tome that featured the magic of some of the greatest artists of the  1920s and 30s. During his ten years behind the counter as a demonstrator at Showplace Magic he gained a scholarly knowledge of classical magic and honed his performing chops.

Paul would go on to study with some of the 20th century's greatest magical thinkers, including Johnny Thompson, Channing Pollock, and Eugene Burger.

For several years, Paul performed his evening show at The Mirage Hotel & Casino to rave reviews:

"… Better than even Copperfield… In fact, were we feeling hyperbolic, we’d go all out and say this was the least cheesy, most mystifying, and definitely the most satisfying magic experience that we have had in Vegas. 

"We’re going to re-introduce you to the finest entertainment deal on the strip. Paul Vigil performs only one hour a week, to a very limited audience . . . It's still the best hour of mystery you’ll see on your trip."

- Vegas Chatter

"If you love illusion, magic, mystery and just enjoy witnessing amazing feats of mysticism, go see Paul." 
- Yelp (5 Stars)

"Paul Vigil is one of the most engaging, original, and provocative close-up performers of the 21st century."
- Johnny Thompson, aka The Great Tomsoni

"Paul Vigil is soft-spoken and humble, but behind that compelling demeanor is a diabolical mind. He is one of the best magicians working today!"

 ― Lance Burton, Master Magician

"I have been around magic and great magicians all my life. I can appreciate and respect good magic. I can be amused. I can be compelled. But I have never before been completely blown away . . . Paul Vigil blew me away."

― Jason Alexander, Tony-Award Winning Actor and co-star of Seinfeld

story:
Story

The performance tackles female genital mutilation (FGM) and its effect on women who are suffering as a result of this practise.

The project is aimed at the mainstream theatre audience and local urban communities to expose the issue and bring support to the victims.

The plot focuses on Cleo, a young woman in London who has been living with type 3 female genital mutilation since she was 7. Scarred by her husband in a brutal sexual assault, she finds the strength to seek a reversal surgery at the African Women’s Health Clinic in London. Her family oppose the decision and send her to stay with her aunt Winnie in an attempt to force FGM as a “gift”. On the journey of healing she meets Eve, a fellow victim who is instantly drawn to her.

https://www.parktheatre.co.uk/whats-on/bullet-hole

 

More About us

Naiad Productions Ltd

www.naiadproductions.com 

Freedom Tongues

www.gloriawilliams84.wixsite.com/freedom-tongues

 

What We Need 

To produce this show we need a minimum of £ 37000

A good share has been  support in kind as the co producers will be wearing different hats, unpaid, to cover roles which will otherwise increase the expenses.

SET AND COSTUME= £ 2020

MARKETING= £ 2250

COMPANY WAGES= £ 11822

MANAGEMENT = £ 8098

VENUE RENTAL £ 12960

If we manage to fill a 40% capacity of the theatre, we will have broken even.

Anything below will be a loss and anything above will be redistributed amongst cast and crew to suit an equity pay, where feasible. Also, a portion of the extra box office will also be placed for charity on the FGM.

 

The FGM Reality

Several charities and activist organisations have ongoing campaigns to end FGM. The problem has not been resolved and therefore more government, social and artistic activities should continue to present this dangerous reality. It is a crime, an act against human rights/ women's equality and it cannot be silenced.

 

Related Show activities:

  • Our Dress rehearsal will be open and free of charge for disadvantaged local residents who cannot afford a ticket
  • There will be two evenings of post performance Q&A with lead representatives and the writer about FGM support and physical risks
  • We plan on creating portrait exhibition on FGM survivor that will provoke the audience. It will be hosted at Park Theatre for 1 month in the front of house , accessible to the audience in the foyer. The idea will touch the themes of identity , oppression and the struggle to voice out FGM.
  • The show printed programme will have help and support contacts
  • Schools will be invited to matinee group tickets in order for the message to spread out to the younger ones from middle school to universities (FGM can be enforced from the age of 5)

 

Our Artistic Professional Growth and Project Risks

Professionally the production will strengthen our connections with theatre practitioners, reviewers, partners and more affiliate theatres.

This is the first off west end high profile show done and we target taking the production to the next level while increasing our audience demographics.

With a lack of funding we will have to rely on tempting to find loans. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If your are unable to help, you can always spread the information out there, share this campaign link on FB- TW- INST and invite to the show!

https://www.parktheatre.co.uk/whats-on/bullet-hole

 

For Updates

To get updates about the project, join the newsletter, FB page and Twitter

EVENT PAGE:  https://www.facebook.com/events/478209012599292/

https://www.naiadproductions.com/contact

https://www.facebook.com/NaiadProductions/

https://twitter.com/Naiad_Prod

story:
WHY THE BIG EVENT?

Because three plays about politics, drugs, Elvis, Nixon, Coca Cola, the Watergate break-in, the JFK assassination and football should be seen all at once. Well, maybe it's not necessary but it sure is a cool and sexy thing to pull off.  It will be an huge treat for those brave souls who dare to see all three shows. It's not vital to see them all, as each stands on their own, but these plays work very well together and those who see more than one will be rewarded by the connections. Christian Levatino's writing and characters are rich and extremely satisfying. Plus, you will learn something about three seminal moments in American history. 

This is a process that started five years ago at the 2013 Hollywood Fringe Festival. SUNNY AFTERNOON was performed 12 times in a workshop production. It went through many edits during those 12 performances. Like the bionic man, it grew stronger. Months later we had the pleasure of doing a fully staged production of SUNNY that ran 5 months. It was very successful and received much critical praise for its writing, directing and acting.

In the summer of 2015 KING DICK began its workshop run at the Hollywood Fringe with 8 performances and various awards bestowed. A few months later and with characters changed or deleted the script grew stronger in a writing workshop at The Rouge Machine Theatre. KING DICK went through further alterations at the The Great Plains Theatre Conference in Omaha, Nebraska. The conference is “one of the most important clearinghouses and way stations for serious theatre­makers from all over the country.” Now its ready and rarin' to go. And damn, it's a wild ride.  

 

MEANTIME AT HOJO'S recently ended it's maiden workshop performance series at the 2018 Hollywood Fringe and got called back for extra encore performances.

These plays have been audience tested, ran through the wringer and got tighter, leaner, funnier and ready to have your eyeballs and earholes. We know these plays will invigorate and titilate your brains and senses. 

Since these plays take place in the past ( 1963, 1970 and 1972) we need props, costumes, and set dressing that will transport the audience to the particular time. One scene takes place in Richard Nixon's Oval Office. Now we don't plan to recreate Nixon's office but we do need to design a set that will work for three plays with various and specific needs. Costumes for 30 characters? Lots of time and energy go into that element. Production design can make or break a show. Imagination is free but the effort and materials needed to bring the imagination to stage requires many resources and most have to be purchased or rented . We will steal and barter what we can but...well, you know the score.

 

 

 

actors, designers, producers, and a few others you might recognize make up THE BIG EVENT team. As we continue to grow the project more team members come aboard.

We know not everyone can give but any amount ($5, $10, $20) would get us closer to bringing these plays to the stage. And if you can't give, please help us spread the word. Word of mouth is the greatest form of advertisement we have. Thank you for taking the time to read our pitch. We thank you for your support and we hope to see you at the theatre this Fall.

story:
HEDDA GABLER (2020)

Unhappily married, fearing her future, Hedda dreams to escape a nightmare.

The Tesmans have returned from their honeymoon to a country in chaos; amidst a climate of political violence and civil disorder, a war on terror grips West Berlin. Their house is too empty to be a home, yet Jorgen Tesman (Paul Shilling) believes the chance of promotion will turn his luck around - and rescue his failing marriage to the enigmatic Hedda Gabler (Alina Ben Larbi).

 

About Hedda Gabler

This staging of Hedda Gabler uses the 2015 adaptation by Patrick Marber, originally performed at the National Theatre and directed by Ivo Van Hove. This production aims to capture the beauty of Ibsen’s original text and the style of Marber’s adaptation, placing the tragedy of Hedda Gabler in a fresh context; West Germany, 1977 - at the height of the terror attacks by the Red Army Faction (Baader-Meinhof Gang). By setting this piece in a climate of anxiety that mirrors the text itself, Hedda Gabler takes on new meaning to a modern audience living through a similar war on terror.

This staging of Ibsen’s classic is directed by Jack Reid (Frame 34), a recent graduate of the University of the Highlands & Islands and is produced by Laura Walker (Much Obliged, The Grimm Tale of the Huntsman), current honours student at the University of the Highlands & Islands.

 

Our Goal

We are looking to raise £1000 to contribute towards our tour budget. This money will be raised in conjunction with private sponsorship from local businesses and grants we can obtain. We also intend to make use of the existing arts infrastructure in the Highlands to get in-kind support. By donating to this campaign you are supporting the growth of arts in the north of Scotland, ensuring actors can be paid for their work.

story:
My Story   

          My name is Keyon Woods and I am a rising senior at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. It is there that I study Costume Design in the School of Design and Production. LaMaMa Umbria International have invited me to take part in two programs this summer. The "Directorial Symposium" and "Playwright's Retreat" which takes place in Spoleto, Italy. LaMaMa Experimental Theatre Club is a Tony Award® winning outlet for theatrical artists. It brought up many notable artists changing the face of theatre today. To be accepted into these programs has been humbling. I know that going will deepen my understanding of myself as an artist and the craft of storytelling. To get there I must raise $7,000. This will cover the cost of the program, traveling expenses, and other fees for Spoleto this summer.

Here are links to more information on LaMaMa's programs.

Directorial Symposium--http://lamama.org/directors_symposium/

Playwrights Retreat--http://lamama.org/playwright_retreat/

I have, from a very young age , been interested in dramatics and storytelling. I was born and raised in Kansas City, Missouri into a very supportive family that allowed me to freely explore. I majored in Technical Theatre at Paseo Academy of the Fine and Performing Arts. There, I was encouraged to follow the urges to create and produced work in many mediums. I was a painter, costume designer, choreographer, and Actor. I am now attending the University of North Carolina School of the Arts where I am supported by an incomparable group of working professionals as faculty. It is with their support and the encouragement of my family that I pursued my itch to study directing for the stage. 

I have been longing to create effective and meaningful work for the theatre for many years yet have never felt that I had the time or constitution to do so. Many times I have let fear get in the way of doing something that I know I am meant to do. Putting in an application to LaMaMa was my vow to never let fear get the best of me. As a playwright it is my goal to explore and create work on race relations in America, Sexuality, religion, loneliness and the artistic journey. As a director I hope that my background as a visual artist will translate to creating images for the stage. I am determined to become an admirable theatrical artist and going to Italy this summer is a step in the right direction.  I will be taking two unfinished plays that I have written to Italy to work on and get feedback. Help me to get there this summer and in return I will show you my appreciation of your contributions. Check out the perks for making a donation! Thank you to my family, friends and educators who continue to support my dreams. 

 

Supporters

Rosemary Harris Ehle-- Tony Award® Winning Actress, Academy Award® nominee, seen on Broadway in Lion in Winter (1966) and The Merchant of Venice (1973). Seen in films Tom and Viv and as “Aunt May Parker” in the Spider-Man trilogy. 1986 inductee into the American Theatre Hall of Fame.

 

Wesley Taylor-- Broadway veteran, seen in Rock of Ages, The Adams Family, the NBC© series Smash, and currently starring as Sheldon Plankton in SpongeBob SquarePants the Broadway Musical. Theatre World Award© Winner.

 

Nathan Yungerberg-- Playwright based in Brooklyn whose plays include Esai’s Table, Sons of Dawn and Seven Pools of Lebanon and Isosceles. Nathan’s work has been developed or featured by Cherry Lane Theatre (2017 Mentor Project with Stephen Adly Guigis), Roundabout Theatre Company, The National Black Theatre, and The Dramatist Guild. He is the winner of Ken Davenport’s 10- Minute Play Festival.

 

Krisha Marcano-- Actress and Dancer who has danced with both Martha Graham Dance Company and The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theatre. On Broadway she was seen in AIDA, Motown the Musical, and originated the role of “Squeak” in The Color Purple. Assistant Professor of Musical Theatre Dance at The University of North Carolina School of the Arts.

 

Issac Cole Powell-- Actor currently starring on Broadway as “Daniel” in the revival of Once on this Island.

 

Héctor Flores Komatsu-- International theatre director, actor, and translator working primarily in the United States and México, and recurrently in the countries of France and Brazil, among others. Héctor is artistic director of Makuyeika: Indigenous Theatre Collective, project born after a year-long exploration of Mexico conducted as an inaugural member of the Julie Taymor World Theatre Fellowship.

 

Pam Knourek--  Costume Shop Manager and Technician. Co-Director of the UNCSA Costume Technology and Costume Design programs, and a faculty member in both the BFA and MFA Costume Technology programs.

 

Ellen Rosenberg PhD-- Actress and academic whose focus has been on the creative process: in her classes, for her students, and in her own creative work. BA, MFA, MA, PhD. Professor of theatre history, playwriting and dramaturgy at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts.

 

 

Dorothy Austin-Harrell--  Costume Designer for Theatre, Film and Opera. Recent credits include Rossini’s La Cenorentola, Arthur Miller’s After the Fall, and Bizet’s La Tragédie de Carmen which won 1st place at The National Opera Association.
story_txt: My Story             My name is Keyon Woods and I am a rising senior at the University of North Carolina School of the Arts. It is there that I study Costume Design in the School of Design and Production. LaMaMa Umbria International have invited me to take part in two programs this summer. The "Directorial Symposium" and "Playwright's Retreat" which takes place in Spoleto, Italy. LaMaMa Experimental Theatre Club is a Tony Award® winning outlet for theatrical artists. It brought up many notable artists changing the face of theatre today. To be accepted into these programs has been humbling. I know that going will deepen my understanding of myself as an artist and the craft of storytelling. To get there I must raise $7,000. This will cover the cost of the program, traveling expenses, and other fees for Spoleto this summer.Here are links to more information on LaMaMa's programs.Directorial Symposium--http://lamama.org/directors_symposium/Playwrights Retreat--http://lamama.org/playwright_retreat/I have, from a very young age , been interested in dramatics and storytelling. I was born and raised in Kansas City, Missouri into a very supportive family that allowed me to freely explore. I majored in Technical Theatre at Paseo Academy of the Fine and Performing Arts. There, I was encouraged to follow the urges to create and produced work in many mediums. I was a painter, costume designer, choreographer, and Actor. I am now attending the University of North Carolina School of the Arts where I am supported by an incomparable group of working professionals as faculty. It is with their support and the encouragement of my family that I pursued my itch to study directing for the stage. I have been longing to create effective and meaningful work for the theatre for many years yet have never felt that I had the time or constitution to do so. Many times I have let fear get in the way of doing something that I know I am meant to do. Putting in an application to LaMaMa was my vow to never let fear get the best of me. As a playwright it is my goal to explore and create work on race relations in America, Sexuality, religion, loneliness and the artistic journey. As a director I hope that my background as a visual artist will translate to creating images for the stage. I am determined to become an admirable theatrical artist and going to Italy this summer is a step in the right direction.  I will be taking two unfinished plays that I have written to Italy to work on and get feedback. Help me to get there this summer and in return I will show you my appreciation of your contributions. Check out the perks for making a donation! story:
I am Amelia Eisen. I was born and raised in Nevada City, California. I am a 2008 graduate of Nevada Union High School's Theatrical Dance Department and grew up training at Sierra Dance Institute, a local Nevada County studio. I went on to further my professional training at Alonzo King’s LINES Ballet in San Francisco, Alambrado Danza in Florence/Trieste Italy and Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company in Northern Israel. I later added to my training, a Health Coach Certification from the Institute for Integrative Nutrition in New York City; this lead me to work closely with dancers on maintaining a healthy lifestyle and to build new opportunities for dancers to share their craft.

 Currently, I have my base as a Freelance Dancer, Choreographer, Teacher and Holistic Health Coach in Mannheim, Germany. I am the curator of "Mingle Me Home" 2018. I am eager to bring an assortment of international contemporary dance to my hometown.

Nevada City is the county seat of Nevada County in Northern California. The city is a total of 2.2 square miles and was first settled in 1849 during the California Gold Rush. As of 2016, the population in Nevada City is 3,145. With its unique history, charm and nature, Nevada City is a beautiful and inspiring place. The goal of "Mingle Me Home," is to enhance the development of artistic global networks and  to strengthen the creative diversity of the local community. 

“Mingle Me Home” will take place in Nevada City on December 20th and 21st, 2018 at The Miner’s Foundry Cultural Center. This year's festival will bridge dance communities from throughout the United States and Germany. It will celebrate varieties of different roots and experience. Included in these two evenings will be dance companies as well as individual dance artists from Germany, Seattle, San Francisco, Chicago, Ohio and Nevada County. The selected performers received their professional training from Alonzo King's LINES Ballet (San Francisco), The San Francisco Conservatory of Dance, Kibbutz Contemporary Dance Company (Israel), Dance Professional Mannheim (Germany), Amsterdam Academy for Theater and Dance, California State University Long Beach, Lou Conte Dance Studio (Chicago), Hope College (Michigan), Ohio State University and the College Conservatory of Music at  University of Cincinnati. These performers have a powerful movement language and each their own unique approach to contemporary dance. We are thrilled to include them in "Mingle Me Home" 2018!

In order for "Mingle Me Home" to reach fruition, we invite you to join us in bringing the artists together and making it all possible. The goal is to raise $7,000 to help cover the following costs:

*Travel to Nevada City
*Performance Stipends
*Lodging
*Publicity
*Performance Space
 

ANY AMOUNT HELPS!

By contributing to this goal, you will make the festival happen. In return, you can receive a variety of exciting perks including the chance to connect personally with the performers to learn about their backgrounds, creative processes and artistic visions. Additionally, we will give you public shout-outs, special 'behind the scenes' rehearsal footage, festivals tickets and business promotion.



THIS YEAR'S PERFORMING ARTISTS INCLUDE:



* Amelia Eisen & Kirill Berezovski - MANNHEIM, GERMANY

* 'Garden of Others' - dance short film by performing artist & producer, Pascal Sangl - STUTTGART, GERMANY
 http://www.pascalsangl.com/

* Fullstop Dance Company - SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA
 http://fullstopdance.weebly.com/

* Valerie Grabill - SEATTLE, WASHINGTON

* Stephanie Rankin - CHICAGO, ILLINOIS 

* SEABUS Dance Company's Kelly Hurlburt & Josh Hines - COLUMBUS, OHIO
http:// https://www.seabusdance.com/

* Andrea Amdall - NEVADA CITY, CALIFORNIA

 

 

If we don't achieve the goal, all funds still will go directly to the festival costs and this will mean a low-budget event. If we make our goal or shoot past it, FANTASTIC! We then can up the quality and conditions of the festival and it can happen again next year! 

Proper funding for the arts is not easy to obtain so your contribution and overall support is deeply valued.

Please make some noise about "Mingle Me Home" by spreading the word with your communities and networks!

HEARTFELT THANK YOU FOR JOINING US! 

Sincerely,


Amelia Eisen 
https://ameliaeisen.com/

&

The Miner's Foundry
https://minersfoundry.org/

story:
**note: in my crowdfunding video I say the play is premiering in February, but that was before it got pushed back due to the pandemic! Apologies for any confusion!

 

Hi everyone, 

My name is Ben Parkhill, I'm currently a senior at the University of Southern California studying English and film. Two years ago I wrote a play called "The Catamite," for a playwriting class at USC. It told the story of a young high schooler named Paul who lives with his mother, Laura, on a farm in Oshkosh, Wisconsin. Paul and his mother are struggling financially and he has his eyes set on a running scholarship that will hopefully lift him, and his family, out of poverty. In the weeks leading up to the scholarship's announcement, though, Paul learns one of his much wealthier teammates is applying for the scholarship, too. Because of a secret Paul is keeping related to this teammate, he begins to fear his choice to apply for the scholarship is the beginning of some kind of revenge plot. 

 

In the spring of 2020, "The Catamite" was selected to be one of 15 plays in the Broadway Bound Theater Festival's 2020 season. BBTF is an annual theater festival that takes place in Theater Row on 42nd Street, an off-broadway venue in NYC. Due to the global pandemic, the festival was pushed back to September of 2021. This will be both the premiere of the play, and my off-broadway debut, and I'm simultaneously so excited and a bit nervous.

 

I'm from Illinois originally, and the play was partially inspired both by my experience being a distance runner for most of my life, and coming out as gay in high school. I wanted to tell a story that put the audience in the perspective of a teenager who is lying both to his friends, family, and himself, that captured the psychology of someone grappling with what is real for him and how that clashes with how the people he cares about perceive him. The play is meant to be funny at times, shocking at others, and a wholly surreal experience for the audience. I'm very proud of it and can't wait to see it performed on a stage! 

 

The festival is an opportunity for me to get an audience in a well-known theater, but the actual production of the play is my responsibility. I have to rent out rehearsal spaces, pay actors (there are going to be eight), my director, stage manager, and buy props and costumes. I'm hoping to crowdfund $10,000 for the play, and any additional money I receive will either be divided between the actors and crew, or donated to LGBTQ+ centered charities.  

 

I'm so excited to bring this play to life, and I can't emphasize enough how much your support for the project would mean to me.

story:
Short Summary

Nine years ago I began my journey as a Kathak teacher - taking an ancient art form that I had been practicing for over two decades, and passing it on to the next generation of Indian-Americans. They were only six or seven years of age, and out of the dozens that I taught, these five remained true to their commitment of the art form. 

Antara Asthaayi Dance proudly presents its first generation of Kathak dancers - featuring the debut performances of five extraordinary dancers who embark on their first milestone performance in a lifetime of learning, performing, and eventually teaching. 

An art form that was once traditionally passed down through the patriarchy from father-to-son, now is predominantly upheld and preserved by women. A dance form that was once outlawed in India by the British, now thrives 10,000 miles away here in the United States. 

What We Need

In order to realize this dream, we are reaching out to our amazing community of artists and dance lovers across the globe to help generate the necessary funds for Anokhi Ada. Most people are unaware that ticket sales only comprise of 10-20% of the cost of putting on a show like this. 

Antara Asthaayi Dance needs to raise $5,000 to help with production costs as we present at the prestigious Mountain View Center of Performing Arts - right in the heart of Silicon Valley, home of Google! This includes hiring a professional lighting designer, a sound technician, production manager, and stage hands to help load & unload all our equipment. 

What You Get

Tutorials, postcards, jewellery, tickets, our eternal thanks, free hugs, and more!!

 

The Impact

"Anokhi Ada" is the debut performance of a new generation of Kathak artists, trained by Antara Bhardwaj, disciple of Pandit Chitresh Das. Your contribution helps directly in preserving this art form, so that the next generation can pass this on with integrity to the future generations. The work we present in this one evening is 9 years in the making - and your support will help bring this to the stage - just as this art form was meant to be shared. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar counts, and so does every share! Please post this campaign on your social media, and share with like-minded folks. And those of you local - please don't forget to come watch the show! 

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
Short Summary

 

Hello!

My name is Avinoam Silverman.  I am presently a freelance choreographer and ballet teacher and a former National Ballet of Canada soloist.  I am excited to tell you about “Waiting for the Fall” a new dance creation for my company.   This new work is multifaceted.   The original idea first came to me from an allegory I encountered in a book describing a leaf falling down from a tree and suggesting how beautiful and simple the leaf is in “being” itself completely. The author compares this falling leaf to human beings who all too often do not see the simplicity of ‘just being’ in themselves.  

This idea opened up a lot of questions in my mind about what it means to be human, and how can we find peace in all this complexity?   A year ago I suffered a great loss of a very dear person in my life.  I was devastated and it took me a long time to come to terms with this great loss.  In this new work l explore the ways we confront the loss of people we love and possible ways to move forward from it.  

This work will also explore how our close relationships affect us as we grow up, and contribute to whom we become as adults.   This theme will focus mainly on selected interpersonal episodes that took place in my nuclear family. This theme will be addressed by a collage of some decisive situations and moments from my life that had a considerable impact on me as a child. Moments of dance in its purest form as an expression of joy and freedom will be intertwined into this collage.   

I approach this work in ways through which to articulate that movement in life isn't always linear.   As adults we sometimes go back in time and analyze certain moments and situations that happened to us as children that still have an emotional hold on us today.  This process helps us bring more clarity to our inner emotional state and ultimately frees us from our past.  It allows us to create the story that we choose for our life.    

The main underlying theme in this work is this journey of examining our past, seeing it clearly, and then moving into freedom with limitless possibilities.   Although this work is deeply personal it's themes are very universal. It's a work about all of us. It’s about hardships and how we fall while choosing  to get back up – sometimes, against all odds.  By supporting this project you will help us bring this work to life from an idea to concrete physical reality. We can’t do it without you!  Please help us make this happen. We will be forever grateful to you.

 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to make this happen we need the following:

Compensate Dancers and Choreographer

Compensate Stage Manager 

Compensate Lighting Designer 

Compensate Costume Designer 

Compensate Videographer 

Pay for rehearsal space 

Pay for the rental of theatre

Pay for Props (mainly a  Ping Pong table our biggest piece of scenery)

 

We have some really great Perks for you! including: Tickets for the show, Live rehearsal footage, Private dance lessons and more...

 

The Impact

 Both in 2015 (Diversion dance film)  and 2017 (A full evening of dance) I used Indiegogo in order to fund these projects . Both of the campaigns were successful thanks to the generosity of all our backers. We truly couldn't have done it without them!  All our hard work paid off and we were able to complete our projects with all expenses covered.  Now the dance film exists and we can share it with everyone.  It also was accepted into several film festivals. Here is the link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poiiapWKc8E,   Anvil 18 and Shedding Eve the works I created for the full evening in 2017 went on to be performed in Dance Ontario Weekend and in Spotlight on Israeli Culture Festival.

This time around we are preparing another live evening for the stage.  I am excited to venture into a work that is deeply personal yet very universal where people can relate it to their story and come out of the show with a fresh perspective on their own life.  This work will offer an opportunity to look deeper into the intricacy and majesty of life to explore the complex nature of our relationships  and the wide spectrum of our emotions in an artistic and creative way.   Hopefully it will lend a fresh perspective on how we can learn from the past in order to move forward with more freedom into new paths.   Your help will bring to life an exciting evening of dance.

We would be most grateful for your support.

  Risks & Challenges

As we are living in uncertain times due to the Covid-19 pandemic as we move forward with the rehearsals for this project there is a chance we might have to change the dates around according to the situation at hand both for rehearsals and the shows.  Yes,  Covid-19 could create more challenges on the way but we believe there  is nothing like a live performance and we are looking forward to sharing it with people! We will take all the necessary precautions on the way,  Our priority is peoples safety first!   If it does turn out to be the case that there are safety protocols in place that force us to postpone our shows we will do so and reschedule the dates to when it is safe again.   But you can be rest assured the shows will take place when it is safe to do so!

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help us out monetarily,  your spreading the word about our campaign using the indiegogo share tools will be very much appreciated!

Thank You for visiting our campaign.

My name is Avinoam Silverman.  I am presently a freelance choreographer and ballet teacher and a former National Ballet of Canada soloist.  I am excited to tell you about “Waiting for the Fall” a new dance creation for my company.   This new work is multifaceted.   The original idea first came to me from an allegory I encountered in a book describing a leaf falling down from a tree and suggesting how beautiful and simple the leaf is in “being” itself completely. The author compares this falling leaf to human beings who all too often do not see the simplicity of ‘just being’ in themselves.  
This idea opened up a lot of questions in my mind about what it means to be human, and how can we find peace in all this complexity?   A year ago I suffered a great loss of a very dear person in my life.  I was devastated and it took me a long time to come to terms with this great loss.  In this new work l explore the ways we confront the loss of people we love and possible ways to move forward from it.  
This work will also explore how our close relationships affect us as we grow up, and contribute to whom we become as adults.   This theme will focus mainly on selected interpersonal episodes that took place in my nuclear family. This theme will be addressed by a collage of some decisive situations and moments from my life that had a considerable impact on me as a child. Moments of dance in its purest form as an expression of joy and freedom will be intertwined into this collage.   
I approach this work in ways through which to articulate that movement in life isn't always linear.   As adults we sometimes go back in time and analyze certain moments and situations that happened to us as children that still have an emotional hold on us today.  This process helps us bring more clarity to our inner emotional state and ultimately frees us from our past.  It allows us to create the story that we choose for our life.    
The main underlying theme in this work is this journey of examining our past, seeing it clearly, and then moving into freedom with limitless possibilities.   Although this work is deeply personal it's themes are very universal. It's a work about all of us. It’s about hardships and how we fall while choosing  to get back up – sometimes, against all odds.  By supporting this project you will help us bring this work to life from an idea to concrete physical reality. We can’t do it without you!  Please help us make this happen. We will be forever grateful to you.
 
What We Need & What You Get
In order to make this happen we need the following:
Compensate Dancers and Choreographer
Compensate Stage Manager 
Compensate Lighting Designer 
Compensate Costume Designer 
Compensate Videographer 
Pay for rehearsal space 
Pay for the rental of theatre
Pay for Props (mainly a  Ping Pong table our biggest piece of scenery)
 
We have some really great Perks for you! including: Tickets for the show, Live rehearsal footage, Private dance lessons and more...

 
The Impact
 Both in 2015 (Diversion dance film)  and 2017 (A full evening of dance) I used Indiegogo in order to fund these projects . Both of the campaigns were successful thanks to the generosity of all our backers. We truly couldn't have done it without them!  All our hard work paid off and we were able to complete our projects with all expenses covered.  Now the dance film exists and we can share it with everyone.  It also was accepted into several film festivals. Here is the link: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=poiiapWKc8E,   Anvil 18 and Shedding Eve the works I created for the full evening in 2017 went on to be performed in Dance Ontario Weekend and in Spotlight on Israeli Culture Festival.
This time around we are preparing another live evening for the stage.  I am excited to venture into a work that is deeply personal yet very universal where people can relate it to their story and come out of the show with a fresh perspective on their own life.  This work will offer an opportunity to look deeper into the intricacy and majesty of life to explore the complex nature of our relationships  and the wide spectrum of our emotions in an artistic and creative way.   Hopefully it will lend a fresh perspective on how we can learn from the past in order to move forward with more freedom into new paths.   Your help will bring to life an exciting evening of dance.
We would be most grateful for your support.
  Risks & Challenges


As we are living in uncertain times due to the Covid-19 pandemic as we move forward with the rehearsals for this project there is a chance we might have to change the dates around according to the situation at hand both for rehearsals and the shows.  Yes,  Covid-19 could create more challenges on the way but we believe there  is nothing like a live performance and we are looking forward to sharing it with people! We will take all the necessary precautions on the way,  Our priority is peoples safety first!   If it does turn out to be the case that there are safety protocols in place that force us to postpone our shows we will do so and reschedule the dates to when it is safe again.   But you can be rest assured the shows will take place when it is safe to do so!
Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't help us out monetarily,  your spreading the word about our campaign using the indiegogo share tools will be very much appreciated!
Thank You for visiting our campaign.

story:
To Our Community:

After a three-year development process, Dohee Lee Puri Arts is months away from premiering our new performance, MU/巫: 9 Goddesses, May 21-23 @ Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco, after which we’ll head to REDCAT, LA and then EastSide Cultural Center, Oakland in the Fall.

We have been granted $13,000 by the East Bay Community Foundation to support the completion of MU/巫 – rehearsing, building the set, paying artists’ fees, community participation fees, Puri Arts administration and more.

But there’s a catch! East Bay Community Foundation will only give us the $13,000 if we can match it dollar-for-dollar in donations.

Raising these funds are essential for us to premiere and tour MU/巫 and to keep Puri Arts thriving into the future. If we cannot raise these funds, we may not be able to finish the performance and we’re facing the possibility that Puri Arts may cease to exist. At this moment, everything depends upon our ability to pay the artists to make this performance.

We believe that art is integral to the fabric of society and that we can transform people’s lives through art. As artists, we serve as vessels for people to discover and connect to their roots. We dedicate our lives to this vision. We are reaching out to you, our community, because we believe the work that Dohee is doing on the stage and in the community is vitally important. More than ever, the voices and actions of artists are needed. However, less resources than ever are available to support artists’ work. So, as in traditional times, we turn to our urban village to seek the resources to keep teaching and making work for the community. Without this support, we cannot keep doing our work.

The good news is, not only do you get a tax write off for your donation (via our fiscal sponsor, Dancers’ Group) but also, every dollar you are able to give will be doubled. At this moment, even a small donation will have an outsized impact.

One of the ways you can support our work is by pre-purchasing a new collection of music by Dohee Lee and Adria Otte, which will be released at the MU/巫 premiere in May. If that’s something you might have purchased anyway, this is a moment where that money can be DOUBLED and make a big difference in sustaining the very existence of Dohee Lee Puri Arts.

Additionally, there are some rare and valuable experiences (check out the “perks”) that Dohee is humbly offering at higher levels of donation. 

Stay tuned for more project updates soon and thank you so much for your support!

story:
BECOME A PATRON OF OPS FEST

Please support our efforts by making a monetary gift to WIL Festival. Our performers step into the shoes of 16th century professionals and walk miles in them all summer long, discovering how Original Practice succeeds in the 21st century.

If you’re ready to give, check out the sidebar to the right of your screen and find a level of giving that matches your means and your corresponding gift. If you want to learn more, read below!

HOW YOU CAN GIVE...

Our shows are always admission free. To pay our bills and our actors in this year's WIL Festival will cost approximately $2,500! We need your help to make that happen!

Help us raise $2,500 - a substantial portion of our operating budget, symbolic of mounting the WIL Festival!

Of course we don't expect all our supporters to be substantial contributors. When you join us in the park, we'll ask you to drop a small contribution into a post-show bucket (our version of passing the hat), and if you are able to give more than spare change or cash on hand, we gladly accept a check or credit card on site. THANK YOU to everyone who has given and continues to give. We simply cannot do it without you.

...AND WHAT YOU WILL GET

Patrons of Shakespeare's company were known to favor individual actors, sometimes directly supporting them with personal tips or gifts or voting with their wallets in other ways: expanding an actor's wardrobe, perhaps in turn helping him win larger, more impressive roles.

We've taken some inspiration from the older economic structure in designing your perks:

SPONSOR AN ACTOR and you have the option to have a creative exchange over a role, perhaps inspiring the kind of character, costume, or behaviors you'll see on stage.

BUSINESS OWNER? Shakespeare's plays are notoriously referential - his audience was used to hearing jabs at rival playwrights, shout outs to favorite taverns, or send ups of contemporary political figures.

FIND A LEVEL OF SUPPORT THAT WORKS FOR YOU! (See the full list of perks and levels of giving to the right.)

YOUR IMPACT

Many of our performers have begun to master the combination of text analysis, vocal and physical athleticism, and improvisation skills that cue script performance demands. Through a combination of training and rigorous experience, impossible to recreate without a viable company.

With the help of Ronni Lacroute, as well as The Swinford Family Foundation, Starseed Foundation, and Many Horses Productions, we've been able to hire professional actors at competitive rates and find a home in the local theatre community.

We keep costs low so we can expand the reach of our season into more neighborhoods. Relative to the modern tradition of massive set construction and architectural verisimilitude, our universal set is lightweight, compact, and reusable. Our tents, costumes, weapons, and minimal properties are available on-location via our spectacular trailer, so we are able travel the Portland metro area and beyond!

We need you! This Indegogo campaign must earn $2,500. If you can help us meet our goal, we’ll be on track for next summer's festival, able to recruit and retain experienced actors, and staffing 12-hour production marathons. Come see for yourself why folks of all ages make our seasons an integral part of their summer!

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP!

Attend a show!

Share This Campaign! (Use the Indiegogo share tools to help us promote our goal for next season.)

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT, TIME AND GENEROSITY.

story:
Humanity Play Project is committed to creating performance with purpose. Our current project is an interactive Theatre for Young Audiences play entitled #Right2Recess. #R2R follows a group of third graders who find out their new principal is threatening to take away recess time. Our play creates space for kids in the audience to practice standing up and speaking out for what they believe in. Actors perform scripted scenes and improvise with the audience, using techniques in civic dialogue and conflict resolution, to move the #R2R story forward.

The American Alliance for Theatre & Education (AATE) accepted our proposal to present #R2R at the 2018 conference in Minneapolis. Our session will include a performance and a post-show conversation with a focus on Theatre for Young Audiences as Civic Dialogue. This conference experience will give us an opportunity to present our show to colleagues and community members and receive feedback, while providing professional development and fellowship in the field of educational theatre.

As a genre, Theatre as Civic Dialogue is essential as our nation faces social, economic and political changes. It is necessary for our young people - and their grown ups – to practice conversation, reflect on current issues, and participate in hands-on learning as artists, activists and citizens.

Thank you for your support of Humanity Play Project and our journey to Minneapolis.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Tosinger. I am a Singer/Storyteller/Actress who creates and promotes African art, music and culture through events and concerts which contributes immensely to cultural knowledge and entertainment in the Americas. Currently in pre-production stage is an African theatrical one woman musical in collaboration with world renowned Cameroonian Guitarist, Franck Biyong, from Paris as the music composer and arranger. This project will be taking place in the summer (June/July) and/or fall (Oct/Nov) of 2019 touring two cities – New York and Atlanta respectively and other cities based on request.

It is obvious that more people are being sensitized to the diversity and relevance of the continent of Africa especially since the release of the Black Panther movie, there has been a growing admiration of the aesthetics of the arts, music and culture of Africa.  Although it's a fictional movie, some reality topics were insinuated but not distinctly addressed.  This project aims to use the art of authentic oral theatrical African storytelling to sonically and dramatically trigger and evoke emotions to confront the elephant in the room, it will address deep issues that come from a place of misinformation and ignorance; using stories and music to draw from the past to affect the present about the relationship between African immigrants and African Americans and the black diaspora.

This one-hour stage production performance through monologue, devising collaborations, singing and live band musicians on an aesthetically appropriate stage. It will also be on a recorded format for entertainment, educational and informational purposes.

What We Need & What You Get

We (my team and I) need some head start financially to kick this off the ground that is why we’re cordially inviting you to partner with us to make this a reality by becoming a contributor.  Our needs include Venue fees, Sound and Light System, Musicians, Music production, travel and accommodation, Rehearsal space, Costumes, Stage and Tech Professionals, Photography and Videography, Advertising, Media and Marketing personnel; Hospitality, Food and Beverage; Graphic Design and Printing. We realize how important our sponsors are to an event's success that is why we have made the benefit options simple and value worthy, which include marketing exposure for your business, product or service in our event brochure and if you are an individual, there are awesome perks as can be seen on the right hand side for different levels and of course our heartfelt expression of gratitude through recognition.

The Impact

It is a cultural production that a lot of people will want to see and connect to having had the Black Panther sensitization to all things African. People want to see more creative work that expresses more of this and this production aims to address meaningful issues as it relates to cross diaspora experiences. There is a void in the artistic discourse and conversation between Africa and Black America that we MUST fill, and this is what IYA OBA aims to do.

Culturally Innovative - The entire production concept aims at presenting a modern performance that reinvents and recreates a traditional authentic African expression of music and storytelling.

Emotionally Affective - It is an opportunity for the audience to travel in time and space and connect with ease to the stories through music and vocals. It will also highlight the issues of the nuances of the African and African American inter-relations.

Socially Impactive - A civic and social impact is achieved by providing a "healing" process through Art. This piece will sensitize the audience to the multi-dimensionality of the world in which we live in

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help us get the word out and make some noise about the campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

THANK YOU SO MUCH FOR HELPING US MAKE THIS PROJECT A REALITY!

story:
• I am Tom Blumenfeld, author, actor, comedy writer, standup comic and playwright, in ascending order of importance. Most important of all at the moment, I find myself in the position of producer.
  • My play, A Shot of Rhythm and Blues, has been accepted into the prestigious New York Summerfest. The performance dates are in mid-September, so there is some urgency to the matter of funding.  
  • I believe this show, and the people who bring it to life, stand a good chance to attract considerable interest due to the subject matter. It is a comedy/mystery involving  a fictional Liverpudlian rock and roll group in the early '60's. The Beatles, on whom I modeled this group (and then melted the wax into grotesque distortions to which only a Lovecraft could do justice), have demonstrated an appeal that has stood the test of time and cut across generations.
  • The production shall need 11,000 dollars.
  • As I am not a musician, and have written only the books and lyrics, I hired a composer, Taylor Ryan, best in a field of five applicants. His fee is 1,700 dollars.
  • We are cutting costs wherever we can. For instance, we are recording the instrumental passages rather than have a live band. It will be necessary to rent a guitar and bass which look authentic for the period. 
  •  
  • Here is a breakdown of our projected expenses:
  •  
  • Composition and recording                                                                                                       $1,700
  • Cast salaries       $115 per person per performance   x 6 persons x 3 shows                2,070
  • Stage manager      100 per performance                                                                                       300
  • Marketing        
  •                                      Cartoon poster                                                                                                   125
  •                                       Photographic poster                                                                                        175
  •                                        Printing                                                                                                                345
  •                                        Listings                                                                                                                 300
  • Rehearsal Space      $30/hr.    2 1/2 hour average x 38 days                                                2,850
  • Props
  •                                         Imitation Vintage Epiphone acoustic guitar  rental                            150
  •                                         Imitation Vintage Fender bass rental                                                      150
  •                                         Walther PPK (German Police Pistol)                                                          30
  •                                          Carl Gustav submachine gun                                                                        75
  •                                           Bar                                                                                                                        250
  •                                           Rotary phone                                                                                                        55
  •  
  • Transportation
  •                                          UHaul Highland Park, NJ - Manhattan  $89/day   2 days                   178
  •  
  • Videographer                                                                                                                                                
  •                                            Shooting                                                                                                              300
  •                                             Sound Mixing                                                                                                       50

  •
story_txt:
I am Tom Blumenfeld, author, actor, comedy writer, standup comic and playwright, in ascending order of importance. Most important of all at the moment, I find myself in the position of producer.
My play, A Shot of Rhythm and Blues, has been accepted into the prestigious New York Summerfest. The performance dates are in mid-September, so there is some urgency to the matter of funding.  
I believe this show, and the people who bring it to life, stand a good chance to attract considerable interest due to the subject matter. It is a comedy/mystery involving  a fictional Liverpudlian rock and roll group in the early '60's. The Beatles, on whom I modeled this group (and then melted the wax into grotesque distortions to which only a Lovecraft could do justice), have demonstrated an appeal that has stood the test of time and cut across generations.


The production shall need 11,000 dollars.
As I am not a musician, and have written only the books and lyrics, I hired a composer, Taylor Ryan, best in a field of five applicants. His fee is 1,700 dollars.
We are cutting costs wherever we can. For instance, we are recording the instrumental passages rather than have a live band. It will be necessary to rent a guitar and bass which look authentic for the period. 
 
Here is a breakdown of our projected expenses:
 
Composition and recording                                                                                                       $1,700
Cast salaries       $115 per person per performance   x 6 persons x 3 shows                2,070
Stage manager      100 per performance                                                                                       300
Marketing        
                                     Cartoon poster                                                                                                   125
                                      Photographic poster                                                                                        175
                                       Printing                                                                                                                345
                                       Listings                                                                                                                 300
Rehearsal Space      $30/hr.    2 1/2 hour average x 38 days                                                2,850
Props
                                        Imitation Vintage Epiphone acoustic guitar  rental                            150
                                        Imitation Vintage Fender bass rental                                                      150
                                        Walther PPK (German Police Pistol)                                                          30
                                         Carl Gustav submachine gun                                                                        75
                                          Bar                                                                                                                        250
                                          Rotary phone                                                                                                        55
 
Transportation
                                         UHaul Highland Park, NJ - Manhattan  $89/day   2 days                   178
 
Videographer                                                                                                                                                
                                           Shooting                                                                                                              300

Costume                                                                                                                                                        1050 Hair and makeup                                                                                                                                           150

Programs                                                                                                                                                         120                                                                                                                                                      
We have loads of entertaining perks for you; it's possible we shall have more, courtesy of our golden-throated actors.
Remember, if you can't contribute monetarily, do so by spreading the word about NY Summerfest and A Shot of Rhythm and Blues.   Thank you, ladies and gentlemen.

story:
Overview

Leaves Are Falling Fast Productions is proud to present the latest version of June's story, Forget Me Not, at the renowned Edinburgh Festival Fringe. Hard work behind the scenes has garnered monies to get the production team and actors to and from the festival.  Remaining funds raised will ensure a successful staging while contributing to meals, publicity, fees and insurance.

Our Team and Plan

Our team has been preparing this play to share, from the premier at The Kavinoky Theatre in Buffalo, NY, last June, to the reimagined version that will travel over the pond to Edinburgh this summer.

We are launching the newest festival version at the Buffalo Infringement Festival at the Andrew's Theatre July 25 and 26 before shipping out to Edinburgh where this compelling story will be performed from August 3 - 10, 2019.

Please join us in telling this important story of the past, while striving inspire us in the present. Not only can you help by funding, sharing June's story on social media is just as important. 

With gratitude,

  • Diane Almeter Jones, (June's granddaughter), Playwright
  • Kristen Tripp Kelley, Director
  • Anne Roaldi Boucher, Actor playing June
  • Zachary Bellus, Actor playing Harry
  • Nick Stevens, Actor playing Francis
  • Brittany Bassett, Actor playing Diane 
  • Michelle Eisen, Stage Manager
  • Anna Jones, Assistant Stage Manager
  • Jessica Wegrzyn, Costumer 
  • Harry Jones, Marketing

Anne Roaldi Boucher/ JUNE

Zachary Bellus/ HARRY

Nick Stevens/ FRANCIS 

 Brittany Bassett/ DIANE

Our Current Expense Budget Breakdown

story:
Dads Dancing? What's the Big Whoop?

Oh really? You must be formally trained. Well, we're not. We're just four dads dancing like nobody's watching! I guess we're hoping to change that so when we dance, everyone's watching! Or, at least more dads are dancing!

We like to think of our "style" as a blend of improvisational and inspirational! Paired with some fresh beats, it's quite the combination. And, we hope that you'll catch the vision and help us raise money for some pretty remarkable organizations. 

 

 

What This Is All About

F.R.E.E. International & Water Wells for Africa are just two of the organizations that we're focusing on raising funds for. A little more about them:

  • F.R.E.E International is working to abolish sex and labor trafficking primarily in the U.S. with innovative collaborations through public and private partnerships. (more info)
  • Water Wells for Africa installs water wells in the rural African villages and promotes community development by providing sustainable water sources and reducing health risks associated with contaminated water. (more info)

People should not have to live under such opression, and should have access to some of their most basic needs being met to live life where they're at.

We can help by making sure we're doing our part in our communities, but there are such simple ways we can help encourage organizations like these to continue with their mission of freedom and empowerment. Consider donating.

 

Your Donations + More MA$KDAD$ = Meaningful Change!

 Any donation you're willing to make will go towards helping two very important causes. Plus, Indiegogo makes it very easy to contribute.  So, consider: 

  • Converting one of your daily lattes, or scones, to a contribution towards the MaskDads campaign. 
  • Contributing $2, $3, $5, $25... heck, how about $500? Your generosity will help in a big way and we'll continue to put out content that will inspire all generations! Sounds dramatic, but our dancing is dramatic! Also, be sure to follow us at our social channels to keep updated on what we're up to. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell others about us! Get the word out and make some noise about our campaign. Maybe you can't contribute financially. That's okay! Just help us spread the word like wildfire!

Thank you so much for your part in supporting these life changing organizations. And, for giving a few dads a reason to cut a serious rug!

story:
Our Story

The Story takes place in 2010, Essex County, NJ. When Denitra loses the charter school lottery for her daughter, she must find another way to escape from their underperforming neighborhood school. The answer seems like a risk well worth taking, but may end up requiring a bigger sacrifice than she ever could have imagined. Set over a half-century after Brown Versus The Board of Education, Lines in the Dust questions how far we've come and more importantly, where we go from here. 

The Team

Cast
Tasha R. Arroyo, Dr. Beverly Long, Ed.D., Principal
Kerry Vivian Mantle, Denitra Morgan
Thomas Grube, Michael DiMaggio, P.I.

Production:
Cheryl Katz, Director
Olga Levina, Artistic Director of JCTC and Producer
Beth Cope, Managing Director of JCTC
Nabi Abdurakhmanov, Stage Manager
Eden Tayar, Costume Designer
Sarah Rae Murphy, Lighting Designer
Donald Stark, Sound Designer
Grigory Gurevich, Set Designer
Laia Cabrera, Projection Designer
Isabelle Duverger, Projection Designer
Fernando Ayres, Tech Hand
Shaun Hardrick, Video Producer
Taylor Jackson, JCTC Intern

Marketing:
Timothy Herrick, Publicity 
Bang Chau, Graphic design, Photography
Melida Rodas, Marketing 
 

Who We Are?

Jersey City Theater Center, Inc. (JCTC) – a 501c3 not-for-profit organization was founded in 2006 by Olga Levina, a theater/dance professional and Ben LoPiccolo, an award-winning real estate developer.  We are committed to inspiring conversations about the important topics of our times through innovative and progressive performing and visual arts that embrace the diversity of Jersey City, bringing its community closer together and enhancing its quality of life.

www.jctcenter.org
 

Why We Need Your Support

We seek $15,000 in funding for our main stage production of Lines in the Dust.

Funds raised go towards cast and production team costs, buying set materials and costumes, and marketing. Part of our mission is to bring the Jersey City community closer together. We strive to keep our tickets prices affordable for every resident of Jersey City. Your support can help us do this!

Expense summary:

Artistic team for director, actors/actresses, set designer, set construction crew, costumer designer, lightning designer, sound designer, projections designer, stage manager - $15,944

Production costs for sets, props, costumes, lights, music, food/drink, projectors, and miscellaneous -  $1,250

Marketing budget for flyers, postcards, programs, and social media marketing - $1,520

 

 

Come Support and See the Show!

Location:
Jersey City Theater Center, Merseles Studios
339 Newark Ave, Jersey City, NJ 

Dates:
Friday, October 18, 7:30PM
Saturday,October 19, 8PM
Sunday, October 20, 4PM
Thursday, October 24, 7:30PM
Friday, October 25, 7:30PM
Saturday, October 26, 8PM
Sunday, October 27, 4PM
Friday, November 1, 7:30PM
Saturday, November 2, 8PM
Sunday, November 3, 4PM

* Doors open 30 minutes prior to the show

Tickets:  General Admission: $25 / Student and Senior: $15 on sale here.

Lines in the Dust on Tour! 
November 7 - 9
Westside Theatre, New Jersey City University
285 West Side Ave, Jersey City, NJ

Follow Us: 
Instagram, Facebook, Twitter @jctcenter
