story:
Karlovsky & Company Dance would love your support for our 3rd Season!

We are excited to present these upcoming performance projects:

  •  Dine on Dance: 12th Annual Lunchtime Performances
  • A Minneapolis tour to perform the Crossing Rivers Concert at Patrick’s Cabaret in collaboration with the Christopher Watson Dance Company
  • Our season concert of Crossing Rivers at the Edison Theater in St. Louis
  • About Dance: Our new educational program

We open our season with the 12th Anniversary of Dine on Dance Lunchtime Performances featuring professional contemporary and site-specific dance and live music. These free lunchtime performances take place at Noon, on September 18, 2015 at Strauss Park (Grand and Washington) St. Louis 63103, and September 24, 2015 at the Old Post Office Plaza (9th and Locust) St. Louis 63101.

Next, Karlovsky & Company Dance is thrilled to present Crossing Rivers, a collaboration concert and exchange with the Christopher Watson Dance Company of Minneapolis. Crossing Rivers features original choreography of contemporary modern dance by both company's artistic directors, Dawn Karlovsky and Christopher Watson.  With this exchange, Karlovsky & Company Dance will share the stage with the Christopher Watson Dance Company in these two Crossing Rivers Concerts:

  • October 2 & 3, 2015 - 7:30pm at Patrick’s Cabaret in Minneapolis
  • Saturday, March 19, 2016 -2pm and 8pm at the Edison Theater at Washington University in St. Louis


(photo by: Gerry Love)

ABOUT US:
"Dawn Karlovsky is one of St. Louis' most intriguing choreographers,"
~ Alive Magazine

"Stunning, Stunning, Stunning!" ~ Margie L. of St. Louis

Karlovsky & Company Dance is a St. Louis based contemporary modern dance company dedicated to exploring and nurturing the art of dance with innovative choreography that celebrates the human experience.  Founder and choreographer, Dawn Karlovsky, develops movement that stems from conceptual, emotional, and physical elements to generate dances that are visceral, poignant, and thought provoking.  Through close collaboration with a diverse group of musicians, visual artists, and choreographers, Karlovsky & Company Dance performs vibrant, original works that articulate and illuminate, through movement, the relationships and experiences that reveal our humanity.
Karlovsky & Company Dance is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization.

Dawn Karlovsky (MFA, BA Dance/Choreography) is the Founder and Artistic Director of Karlovsky & Company Dance.  Her thought provoking, athletic, and emotionally candid dances have been commissioned and presented by universities and modern dance / theater companies worldwide.  Karlovsky teaches Modern Dance and Somatic Studies at Washington University and in the Department of Dance at Webster University in St. Louis.  Dawn is an AmSAT certified teacher of the Alexander Technique presenting workshops in the Alexander Technique for Musicians and Dancers and maintaining a private teaching practice working with students one-to-one.

 Dawn Karlovsky has been making dances for over 20 years with a successful career that includes creating, directing, and presenting eight full evening concerts of her choreography in multiple cities in the U.S.  Karlovsky's choreographic work receives grant support by the Missouri Arts Council, a state agency, the Regional Arts Commission, and the Employees Community Fund of the Boeing Company St. Louis.     


WHAT WE NEED:

Karlovsky & Company needs to raise $7,000 to support our 2015-16 Season Performance Programs!

Our overall need is $10,000 for the season, however for this campaign, we are asking for help in raising $7,000 as we anticipate additional funding to be received from tickets sales and other fundraising efforts.

Any amount is greatly appreciated and will help us reach our goal!

Your contribution will help with these costs:

Artists’ Per Diem for travel and Salaries for performance events = $4,000

Travel expenses for Minneapolis tour = $1,000

Theater and rehearsal space rental = $2,000 (partial amount)

WHAT YOU GET:

  • That good feeling of knowing that you have made a difference! All of money raised will go towards the Artists’ salaries, per diems, travel expenses, and theater rental needed for the completion of our programs.
  • Our sincere THANK YOU and mention in our concert program.
  • Complimentary ticket(s) to our March 19, 2016 performance at the Edison Theater, St. Louis for gifts of $75 or more.
  • A Company letter to recognize your donation as a tax-deductible contribution to Karlovsky & Company Dance.

IMPACT:

Our company is growing! The opportunity to travel and perform in other cities helps to bring our work to new venues, strengthen our company visibility, deepen our artistic connections, and build audiences. 

The opportunity to present our work in the Edison Theater takes our company to a whole new level! This beautiful theater has a long history of serving professional touring artists and local productions.

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT US:

  • Use social media to share this campaign - Facebook, Email, Tweet, Instagram, text, tell friends about it! 
  • Like Karlovsky & Company Dance on Facebook to see what we’re up to!
  • Gift Matching Programs – see if your employer takes part in Matching Gifts programs and your contribution will double! 
  • Come see us perform!!  
Saturday, March 19, 2016 – 2:00pm and 8:00pm        
The Edison Theater (at Washington University)
6445 Forsyth Blvd, St. Louis, MO 63130
(314) 935-6543
www.edison.wustl.edu/events/
 
To see more about us, visit our website: www.karlovskydance.org

Contact us at: karlovskyandcompanydance@gmail.com

WE ARE MOST GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

(photo by: Gerry Love)ABOUT US:"Dawn Karlovsky is one of St. Louis' most intriguing choreographers,"~ Alive Magazine"Stunning, Stunning, Stunning!" ~ Margie L. of St. LouisKarlovsky & Company Dance is a St. Louis based contemporary modern dance company dedicated to exploring and nurturing the art of dance with innovative choreography that celebrates the human experience.  Founder and choreographer, Dawn Karlovsky, develops movement that stems from conceptual, emotional, and physical elements to generate dances that are visceral, poignant, and thought provoking.  Through close collaboration with a diverse group of musicians, visual artists, and choreographers, Karlovsky & Company Dance performs vibrant, original works that articulate and illuminate, through movement, the relationships and experiences that reveal our humanity. Karlovsky & Company Dance is a 501(c)3 not-for-profit organization.

Dawn Karlovsky
(MFA, BA Dance/Choreography) is the Founder and Artistic Director of Karlovsky &
Company Dance.  Her thought provoking, athletic, and emotionally
candid dances have been commissioned and presented by universities and modern
dance / theater companies worldwide.  Karlovsky teaches Modern Dance and Somatic Studies at
Washington University and in the Department of Dance at Webster University in
St. Louis.  Dawn is an AmSAT certified teacher of the Alexander Technique
presenting workshops in the Alexander Technique for Musicians and Dancers and
maintaining a private teaching practice working with students one-to-one. 
 Dawn
Karlovsky has been making dances for over 20 years with a successful career
that includes creating, directing, and presenting eight full evening concerts
of her choreography in multiple cities in the U.S.  Karlovsky's
choreographic work receives grant support by the Missouri Arts Council, a state
agency, the Regional Arts Commission, and the Employees Community Fund of
the Boeing Company St. Louis.     




WHAT WE NEED:

Karlovsky & Company needs to raise $7,000
to support our 2015-16 Season Performance Programs!
Our
overall need is $10,000 for the season, however for this campaign, we are
asking for help in raising $7,000 as we anticipate additional funding to be
received from tickets sales and other fundraising efforts. 
Any
amount is greatly appreciated and will help us reach our goal! 
Your contribution will help with these
costs: 
Artists’
Per Diem for travel and Salaries for performance events = $4,000
Travel
expenses for Minneapolis tour = $1,000
Theater
and rehearsal space rental = $2,000 (partial amount)
WHAT YOU GET:
That good
feeling of knowing that you have made a difference! All of money raised will go
towards the Artists’ salaries, per diems, travel expenses, and theater rental
needed for the completion of our programs.
Our sincere
THANK YOU and mention in our concert program.

Complimentary
ticket(s) to our March 19, 2016 performance at the Edison Theater, St. Louis
for gifts of $75 or more.
A Company letter
to recognize your donation as a
tax-deductible contribution to Karlovsky & Company Dance.
  

IMPACT:
 Our company is
growing! The opportunity to travel and perform in other cities helps to bring
our work to new venues, strengthen our company visibility, deepen our artistic
connections, and build audiences.  
 The opportunity
to present our work in the Edison Theater takes our company to a whole new
level!  
This beautiful theater has a
long history of serving professional touring artists and local productions.  
OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT US:

Use social
media to share this campaign -
Facebook, Email, Tweet, Instagram, text, tell friends about it!  


Like Karlovsky
& Company Dance on Facebook to see what we’re up to!

Gift
Matching Programs – see if your employer takes part in Matching Gifts programs and
your contribution will double!  
Come see us
perform!!  Saturday,
March 19, 2016 – 2:00pm and 8:00pm 
      The Edison Theater (at
Washington University)
6445 Forsyth Blvd, St.
Louis, MO 63130(314) 935-6543

www.edison.wustl.edu/events/
 To see more
about us, visit our website: www.karlovskydance.org
Contact us at: karlovskyandcompanydance@gmail.com
WE ARE MOST
GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

story:
EagerRisk loves Collaboration, Giving Opportunites to Young Professionals and Underrepresented Minorities in Theatre, and Community Outreach, educating and giving people shows, who would otherwise not have the opportunity to see Theatre!


About EagerRisk Theater

As R. Admiral Grace Hooper famously said, "A ship in port is safe, but
that is not what ships are built for." Eager Risk Theater, a New York-based
company founded by three alumni from the Ira Brind School of Theater
Arts at the University of the Arts, applies this motto in every venture,
proving in theatre, there is no ruin among the risky. Headed by Artistic
Director and actor/playwright Annie R. Such, Eager Risk Theater dedicates
itself to producing and supporting young, eager, and risky theatre.
Committing itself to predominately new, original work, and rich, rare
revivals, Eager Risk Productions cultivates the artist as well as the art by
incorporating multiple medias with live performance. With cultural and
thematic specific seasons, Eager Risk Theater integrates each program
with a different visual art movement or artist, exemplifying the theatrical
components and educating audiences with poignancy and truth. Eager
Risk Theater seeks to find beauty in not only the winsome, but also the
grotesque aspects of human nature, by challenging conventional
aesthetics with the highest form of new, inventive theater.

Eager Risk Theater formed in 2012 as the YeuxVeuxBelle Collective,
producing their first collaborative, multi-media play The Artists’ Women in
the Philadelphia Fringe Festival. Under the guidance of
Producer/Marketing Director Jarrod Markman, and after receiving the Ira
Brind Alumni Grant, The Artists’ Women opened to mass acclaim, and
sold-out shows for the entirety of the run. Reviewer Alaina Mabasco said
of the production, “The cast brims with as much physical and emotional
passion as the script. Such packs the play with sensual imagery and ripe,
time-honored artistic dilemmas, and she also contributes a digital
slideshow, projected on the set’s backdrop, which peppers the stage with
images of the characters’ most famous art. The artists’ women suffer the
sublime pain of coming second to their lovers’ genius, or watching their
own talents consumed by a male-dominated world, where they’ll be
remembered by history not for what they did, but for who they loved….
This new acquaintance with the artists, their long-suffering lovers, and the
imagined muse behind it all will leave you wanting to revisit the
masterpieces themselves.”

Since 2012, Eager Risk Theater has continued to create dialogue among
theatre-goers, with successful productions of My Generation Festival, a
series of short plays commenting on the Millennial Generation from the
perspectives of both Generation Y playwrights and Generation X/Baby
Boomer playwrights, Down With Love, a Valentine’s Cabaret, showcasing
the young talent of Philadelphia, and Crumble: Lay Me Down Justin
Timberlake by Sheila Callaghan, Eager Risk Theater’s NYC Debut!
The 2015/2016 season marks Eager Risk Theater’s inaugural full season in
NYC, and  will involve collaborations with other small companies!
The Season of Magical Realism will integrate conceptual design inspired
by Joseph Cornell, and is organized to be self-sustaining for an entire year.


EagerRisk marries all art forms together!

Each Season is inspired by an artist or art Movement, marrying concepts and principles into theatrical direction and design, expanding audiences appreciation of not only live performance, but also fine art. Learn more about This Season's Inspiration, Joseph Cornell:

Joseph Cornell (December 24, 1903 – December 29, 1972) was
an American artist and sculptor, one of the pioneers and most celebrated
exponents of assemblage. Influenced by the Surrealists, he was also
an avant-garde experimental filmmaker.

Cornell's most characteristic art works were boxed assemblages created
from found objects. These are simple shadow boxes, usually fronted with a
glass pane, in which he arranged eclectic fragments of photographs
or Victorian bric a brac, in a way that combines the formal austerity
of Constructivism with the lively fantasy of Surrealism. Many of his boxes,
such as the famous Medici Slot Machine boxes, are interactive and are
meant to be handled.

Cornell often made series of boxed assemblages that reflected his various
interests: the Soap Bubble Sets, the Medici Slot Machine series, the Pink
Palace series, the Hotel series, the Observatory series, and the Space
Object Boxes, among others. Also captivated with birds, Cornell created
an Aviary series of boxes, in which colorful images of various birds were
mounted on wood, cut out, and set against harsh white backgrounds.[2]
In addition to creating boxes and flat collages and making short art films,
Cornell also kept a filing system of over 160 visual-documentary "dossiers"
on themes that interested him; the dossiers served as repositories from
which Cornell drew material and inspiration for boxes like his "penny
arcade" portrait of Lauren Bacall. He had no formal training in art,
although he was extremely well-read and was conversant with the New
York art scene from the 1940s through to the 1960s.


How Your Donation Helps

The money raised for the Season of Magical Realism goes towards Actor Salaries, Rehearsal Space, Costumes, Props, and Set! As a young and small company, EagerRisk knows how to make the most out of a budget, bringing beautiful productions to life on a shoestring budget. It's part of the fun and learning of the young professionals involved.

There is no donation too small. Your generosity will help EagerRisk bring theatre to those who would be otherwise unable to see theatre.

Donations also help fund the EagerReads:

EagerReads is a New Play Development Effort by EagerRisk Theater to support and gain exposure for new, eager, and risky playwrights, showcasing work in an inviting and professional atmosphere. All readings are staged at John DeSotelle Studio, by generous donation, and are lightly catered.



SEASON DETAILS

The 3nd Annual Shoebox Theatre Festival
Magic in the Shoebox
September 3rd-6th
WINNER: RICH ORLOFF'S "A Stranger Here Myself"
After the success of the My Generation Shoebox Theatre Festival, Eager
Risk mounts another short play festival to start off the season, selecting
very specific works around the theme of “Magical Realism”. This September, the festival opened to wild acclaim, uniting  theatre artists across the city bringing the impossible to the stage.
Pieces of Magic: Courtney Self created a Universe on stage with Aaron Weissman's "Dust to Dust to Dust"!

Life is a Dream
by Calderon
Newly Adapted by Annie R. Such
Directed by Christina Ashby

First published in 1635 (or possibly early in 1636), Life is a Dream is a philosophical allegory regarding the human situation and the mystery of life. The play has been described as "the supreme example of Spanish Golden Age drama". Astrological omens predict that if King Basilio's son Segismundo is crowned, he will become a horrible tyrant who will bring destruction to his kingdom. Basilio imprisons Segismundo for life, but decades later he decides to let his son prove his ability to defy the stars. Allowed to rule the palace, Segismundo wreaks bloody vengeance on the kingdom, confirming the prediction of the stars, and the prince is returned to his prison. Newly adapted by Internationally produced playwright Annie R. Such, this production will incorporate multiple medias in storytelling, and provide the highest form of drama, in the intimacy of a transformed blackbox theater.

Piece of Magic: Bringing shadows and shadow puppetry to life and help tell the story. Loads of Weaponry needed for AWESOME fight sequences.


Roadkill Confidential by Sheila Callaghan
Director Daniel Roberts and Phoebe Foss – March 2016
A possibly rogue g-man stalks a stalled-out artist with a suspicious affinity
for accident victims. Traps are set, traps are sprung, and everyone gets
caught. Roadkill Confidential tackles, with style, humor and high
theatricality, mediated violence and the numbness it produces, and,
whether in art or in global politics, the ends can justify the means.
"Roadkill Confidential, a new work by Sheila Callaghan, is intriguing to
watch...it's a sick sitcom, it's a thriller, it's a parody, it's a commentary on
the art world, it's a - this one's borrowed from the script's title page - 'noirish
meditation on brutality.'" – The New York Times
"This multi-media spectacle...ransacks familiar pop-cultural genre
conventions to deliver a smart and stylish cautionary tale of an artist who
gets caught up in the savagery of her own art." – Variety
"Sheila Callaghan, like many playwrights, operates best when she's
angry...dry her out with a nice, warming rage, and her work
crackles...Callaghan parodies brilliantly..." – Time Out New York

Help us bring this multimedia production to life! Interspersing live theatre with short Noir films, and puppetry, this hilariously creepy play will transport audiences beyond their wildest dreams!

Piece of Magic: Short Noir films throughout the play to help tell the story, and puppetry to make Animals sing!


Alice in Wonderland-- A New Immersive Experince
Director Christina Ashby and Caiti Lattimer – June 2016
Follow Alice through her adventures in wonderland, with a found space, transformative characters, and an all new look into a child's imagination. Perfect for all ages! Plans to tour to children's cancer wards and schools, with a portion of proceeds donated to St.Judes cancer research.

Piece of Magic: Transforming a Victorian house into Wonderland, with the literal flick of a switch!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute now, there are so many other ways you can help! Please spread the word, see a show, share on social media. Help us make theatre possible for young artists!

story:
Naked and open truth about the Soviet occupation in Lithuania – spoken by the children of the Freedom generation – in Lithuanian performance “The Land of Rain” – Opening Night in US coming soon

Lithuanian theater of young actors and directors OPEN CIRCLE, founded in 2006, consists of 11 actors, who have finished Lithuanian Music and Theater Academy and got Master‘s degree in Acting (the course led by theater actor Vladas Bagdonas and director Aidas Giniotis). The young theater creators particularly warm and professionally analyze nowadays reality, playing with tales and stories, write and realize the dramaturgy themselves. Within 9 years of existence theater OPEN CIRCLE has created 17 performances: autobiographical improvisations „Open Circle“ (in 2005 received Golden Stage Cross, the main award in performing arts in Lithuania, for the best performance for youth), „Escape to Acropolis“ (the play by actress and playwright Marija Korenkaite), „Good-bye, idiots!“ (the play by actor Justas Tertelis), “Antigone (not a myth)” directed by young theatre director Ieva Stundzyte, mono performances “Freeing Jane” directed by Ieva Stundzyte and PRA written and performed by Justas Tertelis, satirical agitation “Winged Matas” by Kazys Binkis works, biographical improvisations “Land of Rain”. In 2012 theatre created three performances: “Dear Teacher” (directed by Ieva Stundzyte), “1/3 of life” (playwright and director Justas Tertelis), “Ophelias” (written and directed by Ieva Stundzyte). As well theatre produced two performances for children: “DiViDukas” and “Grandma’s tale” (it received Golden Stage Cross for the best performance for children). In 2013 theatre presented a new performance for children “About love, war and wood sorrel”  (directed by Aidas Giniotis), the same year Aidas Giniotis staged “Love for Three Oranges” by Carlo Gozzi. In 2014 theatre presented performances “About a man, who killed a swan” (directed by Aidas Giniotis) and “Va Banque!” (directed by Ieva Stundzyte).

THE IDEA OF OUR THEATER:

When someone dares to talk, it's the same as confession. By confessing one can know himself. By knowing himself one can know others. By talking about ourselves we talk about our generation. It’s an endless way from self-actualization to knowing others. It's like vicious circle. Our goal is - to open the circle, to start talking in straight theatre language, by using it’s unique rules. We are ready to talk about the others and ourselves, to heal and be healed by theatre. 

WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT WE ASK FOR:

It is the first time when theater OPEN CIRCLE is coming to USA. We are very excited about this tour and we are looking forward for the meeting with American audience and presenting our performances. We have scheduled performances in Chicago, where we will show the biographical improvisations „The Land of Rain“ in Chopin theater (two performances will be played with simultaneous translation into English, and it is the unique and rare opportunity for US audience to see Lithuanian professional theater abroad performing in English). Besides scheduled performances in Chicago, we have invitations to come to Washington DC and New York too. But we lack some funding for this, therefore we are addressing to you with the request to help us to come there. We are in the need of support for the following:

- Travel expenses (we intend to rent two minivens (12 people on tour) Chicago – Washington DC– New York – Chicago

- Accommodation in Washington DC and New York (12 people x 4 nights)

- Per diems or catering in Washington DC and New York (12 people x 4 days)

WHAT YOU WILL GET:

Any kind of your support and contribution is very valuable and precious for us, and it will help us to fulfill our dream and to show you the unique and genuine performances of Lithuanian theater. Therefore we want to express big thanks for your support and offer you the following gratuity for your contribution:

10$ - badge with theater Open Circle logo

20$ - tea/coffee coaster set with theater Open Circle logo

30$ - linen bag with theater Open Circle logo

50$ - T-shirt with theater Open Circle logo (size S, M, L, XL)

75$ - 2 tickets to selected performance in Chicago (except Opening Night) Performance dates: 14 October, 7.30 pm – in Lithuanian language, 21 October, 7.30 pm. – with simultaneous translation into English

100$ - 2 tickets to the Opening Night in Chicago, Chopin theater (13 October, 7.30 pm) + poster of the performance with signatures

200$ - 2 tickets to selected performance in Chicago (including Opening Night) + poster of the performance with signatures + linen bag with theater Open Circle logo + T-shirt with theater Open Circle logo (size S, M, L, XL)

ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE „THE LAND OF RAIN“:

„Those  who cannot remember the past, are condemned to repeat it.“ (George Santayna)

The performance „Land of Rain“ is created of biographical improvisations, based on true life stories of the people sitting in circle. Interwar and postwar events related these life stories, which affected everyone personally. The original play “The Land of Rain” tells several stories of Lithuanians just before and during the outbreak of the Second World War and the following occupation of Lithuania by the Soviet Union. All characters in the play and their stories are based on and composed from the authentic life stories of actor’s grandparents’, parents’, uncles’ and aunts’ lives that are told throughout the performance as a personal biography of the actor in character. In order to strengthen the sense of authenticity, actors are given a great deal of freedom to improvise during each performance. In this way, the play is only finalized on-stage by actors during each performance.

Theater Open Circle elaborated their own personal attributes and uniqueness during years of studies. The base of their performances was their own life, i.e. they began to tell stories of their own, based on their own private biographies and their own very individual experiences. “The Land of Rain” was based on the same principle: the stories about Lithuanian history were taken from the life of their own and their parents or grand-parents. So the method they invented themselves is based on a big research of their own and other people’s real experiences, not on already written plays or novels. In such a way the big narrative of Lithuanian history became very individualized.

Through oneself – about the others. About the past living today, but thinking about the future.

Directed by Aidas Giniotis

Cast: Giedrius Kiela, Vytautas Leistrumas, Ieva Stundžytė, Jonas Šarkus, Justina Smieliauskaitė, Justas Tertelis, Benita Vasauskaitė, Judita Urnikytė.

Set and costume designer Ramunė Skrebūnaitė

In 2012 the performance won the viewer’s prize for the best small stage performance at the Spring of Lithuanian Theatres’12 festival.

In 2012 the performance was nominated for the Golden Stage Cross, the most prestigious performing arts award in Lithuania, for the best national dramaturgy.

In 2013 received the prize as the Best national dramaturgy performance in the Professional theaters festival of Dalia Tamuleviciute.

HERE ARE SOME REVIEWS ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE “THE LAND OF RAIN”:

It turns out, that nothing more is needed to create the theatre, devouring and thrilling the audience. Those few things that actors bring to the scene, they are the symbols of the experiences of their heroes. Family photo, letter, handmade cutlery from the camp – these are only remains, fragments, but the whole history of human life lies there, objects causing many memories  and testifying the authenticity of the words.

Karolina Matuszewska  / Nowa Siła Krytyczna 

The attendance here couldn‘t restrain the tears, succumbed to emotions and  briefly went back to the youthful experiences and dramas of their parents, grandparents and relatives. 

Julia Kiško in Brussels, www.delfi.lt

In „Land of Rain“ actors sit in a circle in order to tell the experiences of their grandparents, parents, neighbors or total strangers. The feeling of community not only persists, but also takes purity.

Rūta Oginskaitė, www.lrytas.lt

Everything seems insignificant, but extremely precious. You are a part of the same pattern. The dweller of the same „Land of Rain“. The generations of your tribe, already gone or still live, loved likewise. Your home closet may still keep your mothers and grandmothers dresses, similar to the ones weared by the actresses of „Land of Rain“ .

Rūta Oginskaitė, www.lrytas.lt
story_txt: Naked and open truth about the Soviet occupation in Lithuania – spoken by the children of the Freedom generation – in Lithuanian performance “The Land of Rain” – Opening Night in US coming soonLithuanian theater of young actors and directors OPEN CIRCLE, founded in 2006, consists of 11 actors, who have finished Lithuanian Music and Theater Academy and got Master‘s degree in Acting (the course led by theater actor Vladas Bagdonas and director Aidas Giniotis). The young theater creators particularly warm and professionally analyze nowadays reality, playing with tales and stories, write and realize the dramaturgy themselves. Within 9 years of existence theater OPEN CIRCLE has created 17 performances: autobiographical improvisations „Open Circle“ (in 2005 received Golden Stage Cross, the main award in performing arts in Lithuania, for the best performance for youth), „Escape to Acropolis“ (the play by actress and playwright Marija Korenkaite), „Good-bye, idiots!“ (the play by actor Justas Tertelis), “Antigone (not a myth)” directed by young theatre director Ieva Stundzyte, mono performances “Freeing Jane” directed by Ieva Stundzyte and PRA written and performed by Justas Tertelis, satirical agitation “Winged Matas” by Kazys Binkis works, biographical improvisations “Land of Rain”. In 2012 theatre created three performances: “Dear Teacher” (directed by Ieva Stundzyte), “1/3 of life” (playwright and director Justas Tertelis), “Ophelias” (written and directed by Ieva Stundzyte). As well theatre produced two performances for children: “DiViDukas” and “Grandma’s tale” (it received Golden Stage Cross for the best performance for children). In 2013 theatre presented a new performance for children “About love, war and wood sorrel”  (directed by Aidas Giniotis), the same year Aidas Giniotis staged “Love for Three Oranges” by Carlo Gozzi. In 2014 theatre presented performances “About a man, who killed a swan” (directed by Aidas Giniotis) and “Va Banque!” (directed by Ieva Stundzyte).THE IDEA OF OUR THEATER:When someone dares to talk, it's the same as confession. By confessing one can know himself. By knowing himself one can know others. By talking about ourselves we talk about our generation. It’s an endless way from self-actualization to knowing others. It's like vicious circle. Our goal is - to open the circle, to start talking in straight theatre language, by using it’s unique rules. We are ready to talk about the others and ourselves, to heal and be healed by theatre. WHAT WE NEED AND WHAT WE ASK FOR:It is the first time when theater OPEN CIRCLE is coming to USA. We are very excited about this tour and we are looking forward for the meeting with American audience and presenting our performances. We have scheduled performances in Chicago, where we will show the biographical improvisations „The Land of Rain“ in Chopin theater (two performances will be played with simultaneous translation into English, and it is the unique and rare opportunity for US audience to see Lithuanian professional theater abroad performing in English). Besides scheduled performances in Chicago, we have invitations to come to Washington DC and New York too. But we lack some funding for this, therefore we are addressing to you with the request to help us to come there. We are in the need of support for the following:- Travel expenses (we intend to rent two minivens (12 people on tour) Chicago – Washington DC– New York – Chicago- Accommodation in Washington DC and New York (12 people x 4 nights)- Per diems or catering in Washington DC and New York (12 people x 4 days)WHAT YOU WILL GET:Any kind of your support and contribution is very valuable and precious for us, and it will help us to fulfill our dream and to show you the unique and genuine performances of Lithuanian theater. Therefore we want to express big thanks for your support and offer you the following gratuity for your contribution:10$ - badge with theater Open Circle logo20$ - tea/coffee coaster set with theater Open Circle logo30$ - linen bag with theater Open Circle logo50$ - T-shirt with theater Open Circle logo (size S, M, L, XL)75$ - 2 tickets to selected performance in Chicago (except Opening Night) Performance dates: 14 October, 7.30 pm – in Lithuanian language, 21 October, 7.30 pm. – with simultaneous translation into English100$ - 2 tickets to the Opening Night in Chicago, Chopin theater (13 October, 7.30 pm) + poster of the performance with signatures200$ - 2 tickets to selected performance in Chicago (including Opening Night) + poster of the performance with signatures + linen bag with theater Open Circle logo + T-shirt with theater Open Circle logo (size S, M, L, XL)ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE „THE LAND OF RAIN“:„Those  who cannot remember the past, are condemned to repeat it.“ (George Santayna)The performance „Land of Rain“ is created of biographical improvisations, based on true life stories of the people sitting in circle. Interwar and postwar events related these life stories, which affected everyone personally. The original play “The Land of Rain” tells several stories of Lithuanians just before and during the outbreak of the Second World War and the following occupation of Lithuania by the Soviet Union. All characters in the play and their stories are based on and composed from the authentic life stories of actor’s grandparents’, parents’, uncles’ and aunts’ lives that are told throughout the performance as a personal biography of the actor in character. In order to strengthen the sense of authenticity, actors are given a great deal of freedom to improvise during each performance. In this way, the play is only finalized on-stage by actors during each performance.Theater Open Circle elaborated their own personal attributes and uniqueness during years of studies. The base of their performances was their own life, i.e. they began to tell stories of their own, based on their own private biographies and their own very individual experiences. “The Land of Rain” was based on the same principle: the stories about Lithuanian history were taken from the life of their own and their parents or grand-parents. So the method they invented themselves is based on a big research of their own and other people’s real experiences, not on already written plays or novels. In such a way the big narrative of Lithuanian history became very individualized.Through oneself – about the others. About the past living today, but thinking about the future.Directed by Aidas GiniotisCast: Giedrius Kiela, Vytautas Leistrumas, Ieva Stundžytė, Jonas Šarkus, Justina Smieliauskaitė, Justas Tertelis, Benita Vasauskaitė, Judita Urnikytė.Set and costume designer Ramunė SkrebūnaitėIn 2012 the performance won the viewer’s prize for the best small stage performance at the Spring of Lithuanian Theatres’12 festival.In 2012 the performance was nominated for the Golden Stage Cross, the most prestigious performing arts award in Lithuania, for the best national dramaturgy.In 2013 received the prize as the Best national dramaturgy performance in the Professional theaters festival of Dalia Tamuleviciute.HERE ARE SOME REVIEWS ABOUT THE PERFORMANCE “THE LAND OF RAIN”:It turns out, that nothing more is needed to create the theatre, devouring and thrilling the audience. Those few things that actors bring to the scene, they are the symbols of the experiences of their heroes. Family photo, letter, handmade cutlery from the camp – these are only remains, fragments, but the whole history of human life lies there, objects causing many memories  and testifying the authenticity of the words.Karolina Matuszewska  / Nowa Siła Krytyczna The attendance here couldn‘t restrain the tears, succumbed to emotions and  briefly went back to the youthful experiences and dramas of their parents, grandparents and relatives. Julia Kiško in Brussels, www.delfi.ltIn „Land of Rain“ actors sit in a circle in order to tell the experiences of their grandparents, parents, neighbors or total strangers. The feeling of community not only persists, but also takes purity.Rūta Oginskaitė, www.lrytas.ltEverything seems insignificant, but extremely precious. You are a part of the same pattern. The dweller of the same „Land of Rain“. The generations of your tribe, already gone or still live, loved likewise. Your home closet may still keep your mothers and grandmothers dresses, similar to the ones weared by the actresses of „Land of Rain“ .Rūta Oginskaitė, www.lrytas.lt

story:
WHAT WILL IT TAKE TO KILL RADIOHOLE IN OUR NEW SHOW TARZANA?!?!
67 Razor Blades,  312 Bombs,  3 Gallons of Bleach,  497 Sleeping Pills,  8640 fl oz of Beer,  36 Feet of Rope,  1 Rental Car,  5 Buckets of Blood.

HOW CAN YOU HELP KILL RADIOHOLE?!?!?
TARZANA, the latest show from Radiohole, is a giant bloody mess, and we need your donation to make it good to the last drop. We commissioned award-winning playwright and screenwriter Jason Grote (Mad Men) to write a text, which we have exploded with gleeful abandon. TARZANA unfolds in a hand-drawn landscape following the misadventures of a guilt-ridden Superman, Two Non Blondes and architect of the Terror, Robespierre. What comes to pass is surreal mayhem in true Radiohole tradition: an uproarious, bacchanalian, beautiful mess. Be warned: there will be karaoke. And blood.



We started to work on TARZANA in August 2014 through a Process Space grant at the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council. TARZANA had a work in progress showing at Jim Findlay's studio in May 2015, and is headed this week to MASS LIVE ARTS for its world-premiere on July 23 -25. The next edition of the piece will land in New York City in 2016. We are in the final push to make Mass Live Arts happen, are in need of critical funds RIGHT NOW, and urgently need your help.

HOW MUCH $$$ DOES RADIOHOLE NEED?!?!?
You may have seen the Wall Street Journal article which asked 40 theater artists to imagine they had the power to disburse $1 million each to any NYC theater-makers - Radiohole was #3 on the list, with an imaginary award of $1.5 million. Strangely, this $1.5 million has not been forthcoming, so we are asking you now to bring us as close to $1.5 million as we can possibly get. We will settle for $10,000.

What does it cost to make a Radiohole show? Besides having the cash to buy enough arts and crafts supplies to hand make the entire set and all the props from cardboard, we also need to rent rehearsal space, carry insurance and, of course, pay the people. A total production budget of $60K means we could all focus our time and energy on making the first version of this show, and if we could raise one quarter of that from individuals like you we’d be more than halfway there.

The most significant contributions to Radiohole come from the venerable presenting institutions that commission and produce our work, like PS122, The Kitchen, and in this case MASS LIVE ARTS. For 16 years now we have been regularly funded by government organizations like NYSCA, the DCA, sporadically funded by charitable foundations like Edith Lutyens and Norman Belle Geddes Fund and social awards like The Spalding Gray Award, but most significantly individuals like you have chipped in $100 here, $20 there and every once in a while, even $1000. 

Donations from individuals are THE SINGLE MOST important funding source for us - since this money comes from people who appreciate what we do and have no agenda for how we spend the money, it gives us the freedom to be as wildly experimental and sincerely authentic as we want to be.


WANT TO KNOW MORE ABOUT TARZANA?!?!?
 Influenced by film-makers such as Alejandro Jodorowsky and David Lynch and the New York Punk scene of the 1970s and early 80’s, TARZANA brings together Original Holes Erin Douglass, Eric Dyer, Scott Halvorsen Gillette and Maggie Hoffman with Longtime Holes Ryan Holsopple and Amanda Bender.

Commissioned by MASS LIVE ARTS, the new theater festival brainchild of Ilan Bachrach, TARZANA will play for three performances ONLY on July 23-25 at Daniel Arts Center in Great Barrington, MA. DONATE any amount today (tax-deductible!) and come see the show to find out how many cardboard cigarettes can Erin & Eric possibly smoke? How many cardboard razor blades does it take for Maggie to kill herself? How many buckets of blood will spew across the stage?  And of course - how much beer will our audience drink during the shows?

story:
The My True Colors Festival Presents:

America, and the Adventures of Nat Turn-Up!

Short Summary

Nat Turn-Up, is an 18 year old rapper from Brooklyn, New York. After a taste of the ills of America's justice system, via the lens of a short stay in a juvenile detention center, he returns home to his community of family and friends on a mission. He is determined to become a revolutionary. To uplift and resurrect the minds of his people. Nat, along with his community are all fighting for their right to be heard, to be seen, to discover who they are and thrive in a world that both at times covertly and overtly oppresses them from being able to bask in the freedom which they all seek. As Gil Scott Heron once so poignantly said "Who Will Survive in America?" The characters in this play all ask this same question. What will it take to truly be free? Is it possible, and for who?

What We Need
  • "America, and The Adventures of Nat Turn-Up!" is in the early stages of it's development. In the past I've jumped right into production mode but this time I want to take the time to really flesh this piece out because I believe it to be both powerful and special. It's extremely personal to me. Therefore, my goal is to produce a week and a half long developmental workshop that will culminate in 2-3 performances of the play being presented as a staged reading at The Faison Firehouse Theatre in Harlem, N.Y. this summer.
  • Everything we raise will be going right into making this Staged Reading/Developmental workshop a success.
  • Your very generous donations will contribute to things such as allowing us to secure a rehearsal space, acquire rehearsal materials, provide transportation funds & compensation for an extremely gifted and dope creative team, among other costs that may arise in the process of putting this project on it's feet.

The Impact

  • I was born and raised in Brooklyn, N.Y. The same borough that this play takes place in. It is really important to me to see my community reflected not only in the media, but on stage. I've always been very inspired by what August Wilson did in depicting the lives and stories of African American people in Pittsburgh, PA in his ten play cycle which spanned over the course of the twentieth century. My goal is to do something similar for Brooklyn. This play is to be the first part of a much longer cycle, giving voice to people and a community that often goes misrepresented and unheard. I too want to leave a legacy that honors those from which I come from and also delves into the complexities of our existence. I want my people to feel seen. I think that it's important for art to speak. To bring about social and revolutionary change. I want this play to inspire people to mobilize. To awaken and unite. I want my community to rise above the system that attempts to silence them, heal and feel empowered to reclaim the glory and royalty that has always been running through our veins. For any of these things to happen, it is essential that this developmental process has all of the tools that it needs. This is where you come in. : ) I really hope that you will consider donating to this project today.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this page with your family, coworkers and friends! Help us get the word out! #blacklivesmatter

story:
Short Summary

Hi there! Firstly I want to thank you for your interest in our campaign! I am Anna Carfora and I am running this campaign so that I can get my show “Circular – Strada Circolare” (a play I wrote myself a few years back) on the road towards this year’s Edinburgh Fringe Festival. I am a performer, and I am also producing this show. I have studied drama and worked as an actress for the past 10 years in Italy, Milano (that’s where I am from). In 2012 I performed at the Edinburgh Fringe, and I fell in love with this country, this arts system and the whole atmosphere of the Festival. Therefore I decided to attend an MA in Ensemble Theatre in London, which I did in 2013-2014. Once I had completed my studies, my passion for the arts was bigger than ever which led me to create my very own theatre company where I intend to pursue all of my and my colleagues’ artistic goals and make a difference to our world.  We are mainly Italian performers (or from Italian families) and the show Circular is very much based on Italian modern culture, society and history. 

As for my own personal history and my culture, they  are very important to me, but most of all the people who I cherish and loved deeply from my past are the ones who still give me strength to persue my artistic goals. Some of these people are no longer alive, and it’s to them my show is dedicated to. This is why this project is so important to me, I wrote this play dedicating it to my Aunt Zia Lidia (1924-2011), who never failed o feed my theatrical motivation and my mind. It will mean everything if I can share my story in an artistic and theatrical manner in order to keep her memory alive. 

What We Need & What You Get

Overall the company needs £3.500 to cover all costs, this is our breakdown and how we will spend the money. By contributing to this campaign you help us pay for:

·  300£ Registration

·  2000£ accomodation in Edinburgh

·  1000£ rehearsing rooms

·  100£ Fliers

·  100£ set and props

Should we not reach the entire goal, the sum will contribute to cover the accomodation expanses.

As a thank for your help, we will cite your names in the show credits. And for contributions of 100 £ or more we will send you the poster of the show which is an art piece designed by Emma Margaret Smith (www.emmamargaret.com)!

The Impact

As artists we believe that the spectators play the most important role in theatre, we perform for them, we tell them our stories, they are our purpose. We will be performing at the Italian cultural institute at the festival and as Italian actors living in the UK we will be able to communicate to our spectators a piece of the Italian culture in an authentic way; through the text (a translated text from Italian to English) and having the opportunity to have the writer perform in the play. We are putting all ourselves in the project, all our skills and all our professionality.  This is only a starting point! We are planning to tour the show to London and Europe (starting from Italy) and start a new way of making theatre through our own personal artistic view.  

Risks & Challenges

Unfortunately our journey so far has not been the easiest, but we do not fear difficulties! For the time being I have had to borrow money to pay off the registration fee and the accommodation in Edinburgh, getting the money in time was the biggest challenge we have faced so far but luckily a few generous individuals have put their trust in the company's potential and kindly helped us. As a producer, I am taking the project very seriously and I am using my day job as a safety net in order to pay for everything on time. However, my collegues and I believe this campaign will allow us to focus on the quality of this current project and to go forward and create future projects and shows after the Edinburgh festival. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are aware that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

Please do spread the voice between your contacts! If you have a social network account, please do share this campaign, and reach as many people as possible! Feel free to use Indiegogo share tools!

Great thanks to you all in advance, and perhaps... See you in Edinburgh!

http://viola-230.wix.com/nobodyschildtheatre?fb_ref=Default

https://www.facebook.com/pages/Nobodys-Child-sh...

story:
Short Summary

Hello My name is Andrew J Rogers a recent Graduate of Buffalo State College and a Former Member of Casting Hall. As a student I started to plan my own Theater Company and now I want to make it a reality but I need your help!!

I have a clear simple Goal : To Make Contemporary Theater both original and reinvent established works that a Younger Generation can connect to in a way they haven't before. And to give back to the Buffalo Region through Charitably events spreading peace, love and, compassion through Theater.

I feel as a young person just entering the Professional world there are ways of doing Theater that I believe could be more cost effective, environmentally, friendlier, and more sustainable for the Future. I want to create Minimalistic but effective peaces of theater and revisit some well known shows such as. "Tick Tick Boom", "RENT", "The Rocky Horror Show", and many others. I would also be interested in holding workshops and working with Buffalo's Youth I believe our Youth deserve to be exposed to Live Theater and get a chance to be the Star they truly are.

But I need YOU!!

What We Need & What You Get

1,000 Dollars at the bare minimum would allow me to raise the money I need to get the Company on its feet by holding a Fundraiser featuring Local Buffalo Talent for a night of Musical Theater, Poetry, and other Live Acts. If this happens I would also like to have a Basket Raffle so donations for that would be greatly appreciated. It would also be helpful to be able to have at least Tee Shirts created to be able to sell if possible. To anyone that donates they will be entered into a drawing to win Two Free Tickets to the first Production of the Company when it is up and running and Founder Status in each and every Program from the Beginning till the End!!

The Impact

Right now in Buffalo there are many Theaters But no Theater truly pushing the limits of Theater through innovation, inspiring others especially our youth and to try new and exciting things. I want to make a safe collaborative environment where we as artists can try new things and do it in a way that we can support each other and work towards one common goal which is to make Theater that speaks to everyone. I also want to build a environment where our audience is heard and can help us grow by listening and taking suggestions to heart. I believe constructive criticism is needed to make us all stronger in our craft.

Risks & Challenges

This entire Project won't be easy but having your support means the difference between its success and failure If 100 people donate each 10 dollars I would reach my goal tomorrow and be able to get this entire project off the ground.

It will not be easy I realize that I need to find the people to make this Company a reality. Artists that truly care about there craft and that want to make Theater that actually is meaningful. I need to find a space to produce shows which will be the biggest challenge and I need to fine stable and committed long-term donors that believe in my Mission Statement and are willing to help me make it a reality.

Getting Youth into the seats will be a challenge but creating entertainment they are interested in will help.

I also have a Price Structure to help with this issue.

Youth 18 and Under $10 Dollars

College Students and Seniors 65+ $15

General Admission $25

This is Subject to Change but I feel would be fair. I would also consider a Pay what you can Night.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate all I ask is you spread the word to people who can on Facebook, Twitter, Word of Mouth, Messenger Pigeon, Morris Code, etc.

But you can still be a part of making this all a reality.

I need the following.

1) Volunteers

2) A Board of Directors

3) Technical Staff including Stage Managers etc.


Thank You in Advance for your Support,

Sincerely,

Andrew J. Rogers

Artistic Director

I have a clear simple Goal : To Make Contemporary Theater both original and reinvent established works that a Younger Generation can connect to in a way they haven't before. And to give back to the Buffalo Region through Charitably events spreading peace, love and, compassion through Theater.
I feel as a young person just entering the Professional world there are ways of doing Theater that I believe could be more cost effective, environmentally, friendlier, and more sustainable for the Future. I want to create Minimalistic but effective peaces of theater and revisit some well known shows such as. "Tick Tick Boom", "RENT", "The Rocky Horror Show", and many others. I would also be interested in holding workshops and working with Buffalo's Youth I believe our Youth deserve to be exposed to Live Theater and get a chance to be the Star they truly are.
But I need YOU!!   What We Need & What You Get 1,000 Dollars at the bare minimum would allow me to raise the money I need to get the Company on its feet by holding a Fundraiser featuring Local Buffalo Talent for a night of Musical Theater, Poetry, and other Live Acts. If this happens I would also like to have a Basket Raffle so donations for that would be greatly appreciated. It would also be helpful to be able to have at least Tee Shirts created to be able to sell if possible. story:
When you help me in Japanese, please look at the Motion Gallery website.
日本語での支援をご希望の方は、以下のリンクから応援をお願い致します。
MotionGallery web site

Our Project

We, INAMORI Art Project Group(IAPG) from Tokyo, Japan, would like to realize a peaceful world without conflict, standing on a recognition that all existence is precious and all we are one Earth family on the same planet, beyond the differences of race, ethnicity, and religion. We are performing “Prayer of Love and Peace” in order to convey such a message through art.

We are going to stage the performance in New York in September. We need your supports in order to cover the costs of our performance except for the travel and staying expenses covered by our members. We would be very grateful if you could help us.


What Your Support Means

We are going to stage the performance in New York in September 2015. We carried out our past performances supported by voluntary donations of others, and paying our own expenses by ourselves. We don't have enough capital, since our members of various ages are engaged in these activities as volunteers, besides their own jobs or studies. Overseas performances call for a lot of money, needless to say about usage fee of facility, such as personnel cost and necessary transportation costs. Your donation will be used for the costs of the performance in New York, except for travel and staying expenses covered by our members.


What Is The Performance of “Prayer of Love and Peace”?

Now, on this planet we live, there are conflicts due to the differences of skin colour, culture, and religion. We are unable to appreciate each other, clashing with each other insisting each principle and assertion. However, isn't it the time to graduate from such conflicts? We think we must not destroy our planet Earth by our silly wars.

We need to live joining hands together as one family breathing the same air together, born on this wonderful planet filled with many lives, don't we? Our performance “Prayer of Love and Peace” is to give such a message to various places through theater, music, dance, drum, and paintings. We keep performing with such a desire in our heart, hoping the realization of a peaceful planet.


Who is Noriko Inamori?

Noriko Inamori, founder of INAMORI Art Project Group, was born in Tokyo in 1956. She was a mother having five children, and living an ordinary life as a housewife. However, since around 2007, her steps started swaying when walking, and after that the symptom gradually progressed. And in around 2009, she became unable to stand up alone. She was given a notice of the name of the disease, SND (Striato‐nigral degeneration), one of the Multi system atrophy. This disease is like Parkinnson disease, and it progresses faster than Parkinson disease, and before long to death. she was pronounced that she would live only for around five years by a doctor.

When she knew her own disease, she wondered what she could do to use her limited life. So she reached an idea to do something good to the world through the theatrical performances and songs which she enjoyed since she was young. Then she founded an amateur artistic group in 2009. She started the group with a few friends at first. Now it has over a hundred of people gathering as of 2013.

Noriko Inamori returned to heaven on August 26, 2013. All the members of the INAMORI Art Project Group is taking over her spirit, and keeping on the activities for the world peace.

Messages of Noriko Inamori

"I took it for granted that I could walk or speak in my life. When I started to have problems with my body, I regret not living more fully my life while I could walk and speak, so promised myself not to waste my limited time anymore."
Prayer of Love and Peace "3. Hoping for "Love and Peace on Earth" - Let us ring the bell of peace together -"


"I would like to send out my dream and ideal of making a future of hope with all the people in the world as we are the same living creatures living on the same planet through the same art form. I believe the light is necessary for the time now which is so full of distress. The world is covered by sorrow and a pain of tragic reality." 
Prayer of Love and Peace "4. My Prayer in the Light of Art - Why I started an art group -"

"I think it is the time for us, the people living on the earth, to awake as the earth humans. Like the sun for the earth, I think the love of God is what gives the energy of love without discriminating specific nations. Even though there are differences of skin colors, nationalities, and cultures, from the viewpoint of the children of the earth, I think animals and plants are also the earth children who are given the lives and made alive by the earth."
Prayer of Love and Peace "6. Peace and Unification of Religions"

"We women should share the same wish beyond our own country, culture, and religion. When we raise our voices as "Don't let our beloved sons and husbands and lovers die. Don't let them kill each other!", the situation will change. Because the half of the world is us, women."
Prayer of Love and Peace "7. I Convey to the Women All Over the World"


Introduction of Our Unit

Play unit "ORION"
We named the company after Orion, a constellation, which casts a flood of light on you in the winter. We believe all human beings are equal in importance regardless of race, creed, or color. With that belief, we give performances of our original plays.

Taiko unit "SUSANOO"
The band characteristically use Taikos, Japanese drums. They express their wish for the arrival of a peaceful world in their music performance.


Dance unit "AMATERASU"
The group is composed of 11 females. They design dances of many genres for their original pieces of music. Their beautiful carriage is suggestive of a Japanese spiritual culture.


Music unit "Primavera"
The group is composed of three female vocals. Their voice is suggestive of a spring breeze, which is related to the band name. They wish their song healed the world and gave hope to people across the globe.


Music unit "ARION"
The band is composed of two male and three female vocals and a pianist. They engage in piece movements with their original songs the themes of which are about love and harmony.

Music unit "Green Impulse"
The group is composed of 15 dance vocalists of wide generations. They believe all people on the planet from “a family” regardless of race, creed, or color. They often give a performance in aid of charity.

Art unit "Apollon"
production and presentation of art works, and in charge of visual effects at the performance



Hoping A Realization of The Planet of Love and Peace – Please Give Us Your Assistance


Considering also that 70 years have passed since the end of the World War II, all our members have a strong desire to perform in New York on the occasion of the United Nations Peace Week of September. On the basis of your financial support, we are practicing hard every day so that we can convey the message of Love and Peace to those who come to New York. Thank you in advance for your kind support for our performance“Prayer of Love and Peace in New York in 2015”.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Helping us spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, and via e-mail
  • See the Show  in September!

story:
Poetic Justice Project

Will Dorothy survive Chowkilla Prison? Money, the wicked witch, wants her to get more time. Momma G wants to help her go home. But she'll get there only with the help of her companions--who have courage, brains and heart. 

Poetic Justice Project, based in Santa Maria, is California's only theatre company of formerly incarcerated actors. We are taking our new play, WIZARD OF GREY BAR HOTEL, to audiences in northern California.

We need your help getting our cast and crew of 11 to Alcatraz Island and Santa Cruz. All contributions will go toward fuel, food, lodging and a small stipend for each actor. 

Poetic Justice Project began in 2009 with the vision of unlocking hearts and minds with bold, original theatre. Almost 100 actors--most with no previous theatre experience--have appeared in 13 plays. This will be our fourth performance on Alcatraz!

What We Need & What You Get

We need help with travel costs! All donations will go toward:

  • Gas  
  • Food 
  • Lodging 
  • A small stipend for cast and crew
You will get our heartfelt thanks!

The Impact

Poetic Justice Project changes lives! In almost seven years, only three actors have returned to prison. Audiences are entertained and educated about incarceration, rehabilitation and re-entry.

Poetic Justice Project is a program of the non-profit William James Association. Your contribution is tax-deductible!

Risks & Challenges

We know there are a lot of worthy causes out there. We hope you will contribute to Poetic Justice Project. We are changing the world one play at a time!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please send this link to your friends and family. Help us get the word out!

story:
Short Summary

Since 1979, King'sPlayers Theater has been providing accessible theater to the Seattle/Edmonds community. 

Artists of all backgrounds and experience levels come together to create one, singular moment of theater excellence

Maybe it's a stay at home mom who enjoyed theater in high school and wants to try again, or perhaps it's the actor who is just starting out, waiting to get experience on the stage before moving on to bigger venues, or even if it's someone who is just looking to try something new. We welcome all.


King'sPlayers is a learning and mentoring environment where support and encouragement are follow under the pursuit of theater excellence.

What We Need

Theater, even small theater, is expensive. Costumes, artistic personnel, musicians, sets, rights and venue rental all cost thousands of dollars. We are hoping YOU can put a dent in that!

The Impact

We are hoping to launch a full scale musical and host a new works festival in 2016. In 2014, we produced Fiddler on the Roof, which was critically very well received and followed that with our original one act play festival, Random Acts of Theater, that featured local playwrights. We're hoping to get back to that formula next season. You can help us do this!

Your donation can help us build our season back up and with the success of our show in the spring of 2016, we will be able to generate enough revenue to propel us forward! We just need a little push!


Other Ways You Can Help

Currently, our Fall show, The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged!) is opening October 8-10. It's a small window, and tickets are limited, but they are only $10!

You can check the show out here: http://kingsplayers.bpt.me

story:
WHO I AM

My name is Natalie J Kolosci, I am the owner and artistic director (choreographer, teacher, music editor, costume designer and administrative director) of Civic Dance Center located in Portage, IN. I have been involved with dance for over 50 years with my forte being ballet.  My ballet beginnings were with the Allegro Ballet Company in Chicago where I was later introduced to Miss Ann Barzel, dance critic for the Chicago Tribune and Dance Magazine, and Miss Elisa Stigler who became  central figures in launching many acquaintances for me in the dance field during the next several years.

I made my ballet debut at age 8, dancing with the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow, Russia as an 'extra' for their Chicago performances.  For the following six years, I continued to perform, alternating each year with the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad.  I received a medal of the Bolshoi Theatre from Asaf Messerer, Artistic Director of the company, and was asked to be the assistant coach for the Children' roles, while on tour in Chicago.  My professional debut came at age 15, dancing the lead role of the "Sugar Plum Fairy" with the Allegro Company.  Richard Ellis (of Ellis -DuBoulay Ballet School in Chicago) was another great inspiration for me, dancing parts in Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, and Giselle.  For eight years I also performed in Ruth Page's production of the Nutcracker Ballet in Chicago, directed by Dolores and Larry Long, progressing yearly to more advanced roles.

I was the owner of Natalie's School of Dance in Lake Station, IN, for over 20 years and traveled throughout the U.S. with my dance troupe, "FABULOUS FEET," participating in regional and national competitions, conventions, lectures and performances, accumulating over 500 awards.  Several of my students have continued their dance education in college, while others have gone on to dance with major ballet companies in the U.S.  I did free-lance teaching and choreography in the Indiana/Illinois region for several years before I decided on settling with a new dance center in Portage, IN.  I've been there for over 10 years and continue to expand my technical classes and choreography.  I try to encourage students in the dance field who would otherwise have chosen a different arena.  Civic Dance Center's annual production of the Nutcracker and Winter Showcase has become a yearly holiday tradition in the community as it was for me many years ago!


MISSION STATEMENT

Being a dancer is not only a physical activity – it is a state of mind. The longer one studies, the more each of the attributes is developed. The gifts of ballet training forever enrich who we are and remain with us throughout our lives.


MY CAMPAIGN

My campaign is to raise funds to be able to produce the full length ‘Nutcracker’ Ballet without asking for donations from parents or using my own limited funds to pay for all the extra expenses that go into a production such as this. This includes, but not limited to, guest artists, costumes, scenery, props,  rehearsal space/time, travel and storage expenses.  Every day there are other expenses that put strains on our financial budget.  We are a small group of students and parents that volunteer time to work back stage, fix costumes, put together props and many other functions that bring together this production. They love the ballet and most importantly are excited to present the Nutcracker to our community.

This campaign is important to me because while with the Ruth Page Company, the first ballet I performed with them was the "Nutcracker," at the McCormick Place in Chicago – being on stage with all the professional dancers made me feel important; all the hard work I did in the classroom was paying off while dancing on stage.  I want my students, in turn, to feel the same way.  I want them to get excited about the role they obtained, the costumes they are wearing, the people they are dancing with and more importantly to feel good about themselves that they got up on stage to perform for mom, dad, family and friends!


HOW YOU HELP

The magnitude of what contributors will help me achieve is a truly professional ballet along with an opportunity to continue to produce such performances well into the future.

Nearly $10,000 was spent on our first production, purchasing over 100 costumes and materials for backdrops and props. I took on that debt myself and it took quite a few years to recover, but the production was absolutely beautiful and I couldn't have been more proud of my students. Each year more costumes are always added along with all the aforementioned expenses. Since this is our 10th anniversary, I wanted so passionately to present the full length ballet. This year, we have roughly $5200.00 in unaccounted expenses. We were able to raise nearly $2000.00 from a fund raiser, which leaves $3200.00 that I'd rather not put on my credit card again. I would like to do my best to avoid all the debt going forward, with help from others who love and are willing to support the arts in our community. Any contribution you can provide would have my utmost gratitude and be appreciated by all those involved. Thank you so very much!

Portage, IN. I have been involved with dance for over 50 years with my
forte being ballet.  My ballet beginnings were with the Allegro Ballet Company in Chicago where I was later introduced to Miss Ann Barzel, dance critic for the Chicago Tribune and Dance Magazine, and Miss Elisa Stigler who became  central figures in launching many acquaintances for me in the dance field during the next several years. I made my ballet debut at age 8, dancing with the Bolshoi Ballet from Moscow, Russia as an 'extra' for their Chicago performances.  For the following six years, I continued to perform, alternating each year with the Kirov Ballet from Leningrad.  I received a medal of the Bolshoi Theatre from Asaf Messerer, Artistic Director of the company, and was asked to be the assistant coach for the Children' roles, while on tour in Chicago.  My professional debut came at age 15, dancing the lead role of the "Sugar Plum Fairy" with the Allegro Company.  Richard Ellis (of Ellis -DuBoulay Ballet School in Chicago) was another great inspiration for me, dancing parts in Sleeping Beauty, Cinderella, and Giselle.  For eight years I also performed in Ruth Page's production of the Nutcracker Ballet in Chicago, directed by Dolores and Larry Long, progressing yearly to more advanced roles.I was the owner of Natalie's School of Dance in Lake Station, IN, for over 20 years and traveled throughout the U.S. with my dance troupe, "FABULOUS FEET," participating in regional and national competitions, conventions, lectures and performances, accumulating over 500 awards.  Several of my students have continued their dance education in college, while others have gone on to dance with major ballet companies in the U.S.  I did free-lance teaching and choreography in the Indiana/Illinois region for several years before I decided on settling with a new dance center in Portage, IN.  I've been there for over 10 years and continue to expand my technical classes and choreography.  I try to encourage students in the dance field who would otherwise have chosen a different arena.  Civic Dance Center's annual production of the Nutcracker and Winter Showcase has become a yearly holiday tradition in the community as it was for me many years ago!
MISSION STATEMENTBeing a dancer is not only a physical activity – it is a state of mind. The longer one studies, the more each of the attributes is developed. The gifts of ballet training forever enrich who we are and remain with us throughout our lives. MY CAMPAIGN
My campaign is to raise funds to
be able to produce the full length ‘Nutcracker’ Ballet without asking for
donations from parents or using my own limited funds to pay for all the extra
expenses that go into a production such as this. This includes, but not limited
to, guest artists, costumes, scenery, props,  rehearsal
space/time, travel and storage expenses. 
Every day there are other expenses that put strains on our financial
budget.  We are a small group of students
and parents that volunteer time to work back stage, fix costumes, put together
props and many other functions that bring together this production. They love
the ballet and most importantly are excited to present the Nutcracker to our
community. 
This campaign is important to me
because while with the Ruth Page Company, the first ballet I performed with them was the "Nutcracker," at the McCormick Place in Chicago – being on stage with all the
professional dancers made me feel important; all the hard work I did in the
classroom was paying off while dancing on stage.  I want my students, in turn, to feel the same
way.  I want them to get excited about
the role they obtained, the costumes they are wearing, the people they are
dancing with and more importantly to feel good about themselves that they got
up on stage to perform for mom, dad, family and friends!HOW YOU HELP
The magnitude of what
contributors will help me achieve is a truly professional ballet along with an
opportunity to continue to produce such performances well into the future. 
Nearly $10,000 was spent on our first production, purchasing over 100 costumes and materials for backdrops and props. I took on that debt myself and it took quite a few years to recover, but the production was absolutely beautiful and I couldn't have been more proud of my students. Each year more costumes are always added along with all the aforementioned expenses. Since this is our 10th anniversary, I wanted so passionately to present the full length ballet. This year, we have roughly $5200.00 in unaccounted expenses. We were able to raise nearly $2000.00 from a fund raiser, which leaves $3200.00 that I'd rather not put on my credit card again. I would like to do my best to avoid all the debt going forward, with help from others who love and are willing to support the arts in our community. Any contribution you can provide would have my utmost gratitude and be appreciated by all those involved. Thank you so very much!

story:
Who we are 

Boudoir Theatre is a brand new Montreal-based theatre company. Our main goal is to create enchanting theatre pieces showcasing dynamic female characters who offer a rich variety of work for women. As actresses we have come to understand that the competition amongst women is feirce, more so than it is for men, thus leaving us with limited choice and uninteresting roles. This is why we decided to be the creators, so that we can choose which plays we are interested in and offer other female actors more opportunity. 

What's coming up! 

Our first production is called “Housekeeping and Homewrecking” written by Alex Haber. It is a heart-wrenching piece about romance, marriage and loss. All in all, it is the truth about love. Our show encompasses quirk, sorrow, fear, budding romance, torn hearts and much more.  

What We Need 

As an up and coming theatre company, we have significant costs for our first production. We need YOUR generous donations to bring this story ALIVE.  BELOW is what your donation would go toward as we gear up for opening night: 

  • $ 1,437 is what we need to rent a performance space 
  • $ 200 towards a rehearsal space 
  • $ 200 towards Set design
  • $ 100 towards Advertisement 
  • $ 100 towards costumes
  •  $ 187 towards ticket fees(printing, box office services)  
  • $ 30 towards printing our scripts 


The Impact

By Donating to our cause you will be helping us receive the acknowledgement and exposure that is so crucial to up and coming artists like ourselves. The most important role as an actor is to continue growing and by doing so we must continue our practice. By giving us the chance to expand our horizons we will allow others to do the same. 


Challenges

 We face one particular challenge as an up and coming company. Our challenge is that we must rely on the public, that is YOU, to be recognized. We hope to be able to bring in a full house at every show but we need YOUR help to make that dream a possibility. 


Where and When

Our show will be playing at La Balustrade, In the Monument National
March 4th, 5th, 6th and 7th! RESERVE TICKETS NOW by Messaging Boudoir Theatre On Facebook, OR by contacting box office: 


At the Box Office

1182, Saint-Laurent Bld, Montreal, Qc H2X 2S5

- See more at: http://www.monumentnational.com/en/ticket-office/#sthash.2jz0C7SH.dpuf 
Or by Phone: 514.871.2224     1-866-844-2172 (toll-free)

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are very understanding that not everyone has the means to help us out financially. By sharing our campaign with people who CAN potentially help us. OR come check out our show! 

Also you can like us on Facebook/twitter and Follow us on Instagram! 

TWITTER: @boudoirtheatre

INSTAGRAM: Boudoir theatre

www.facebook.com/boudoirtheatre
