story:
IF YOU ONLY HAVE A MOMENT:

Emily Berry and artistic collaborators of B3W Performance Group (B3W) bring The FORGIVENESS Project from workshops across the globe to the forefront of the stage from Friday to Sunday, May 20, 21, & 22, 2016 at BMCC Tribeca Performing Arts Center in New York City. Part community-building, part performance, The FORGIVENESS Project is a pursuit to recognize the hardships of forgiving through storytelling, hoping to come together as a unified people and share perspective, both at a personal and a global scale. Funds for this campaign will go directly towards the payment of artist and collaborator fees, as well as production costs for “FORGIVENESS - Part I: Forgiving the Personal,” and will play a vital role in bridging the gap with our $32,000 budget.

Interested in our project, but would like your contribution to be tax-deductible? Contribute on our fiscal sponsor page at The Field, by going to this link: http://bit.ly/1qYTD1k.


ABOUT THE FORGIVENESS PROJECT: 
PART COMMUNITY-BUILDING, PART PERFORMANCE

"You also learn from other people's stories. You feel less lonely in your own pain and are encouraged to move along on your path because you feel like people are walking with you." - Workshop participant from Portici, Italy

In 2015, Emily Berry, Artistic Director of B3W Performance Group (B3W), traveled for seven months around the world, initially implementing the The FORGIVENESS Project’s Community Workshop component across 6 continents and within 11 countries, including: China, India, Australia, Italy, Greece, Brazil, Thailand, South Africa, Scotland, England, and Denmark; as well as in Michigan and New York in the United States. During her travels, Emily discovered that creating a space for the expression of stories on forgiveness through art, words, and movement, provided an opportunity for transformation, regardless of culture, age, religion, or occupation.

Following this expedition, from 2016 to 2019, B3W will shift from multi-month incubation periods to a culmination of this research by performances in three parts, both locally in New York City, and internationally:

  • Part I: Forgiving the Personal
  • Part II: How Can Forgiveness Play a Role in Dismantling Systems of Oppression
  • Part III: Self-Forgiveness

Through devised intermedia performances integrating words, live music, new media scenography, and movement, each body of work will highlight personal accounts from B3W artistic collaborators, in response to the FORGIVENESS Community Workshops. The FORGIVENESS Project hopes to intersect the arts with community by exploring the unraveling, the consequences, and the expressions of multiple viewpoints and stories of forgiving.


ABOUT B3W PERFORMANCE GROUP

Founded in 2006, B3W is a social impact arts organization committed to collaboration, reflecting and revealing the world we live in through community-building workshops and multi-disciplinary performances.

B3W Performance Group is:
Direction: Emily Berry
Script: Sarita Covington
Original Sound Composition: Daniel Bernard Roumain
New Media Scenography: Eamonn Farrell
Performers: Sarita Covington, Hyunjin Kim, Nicole McClam, Sara Roer, Daniel Bernard Roumain, Ricarrdo Valentine

GIVE A TOKEN TO FORGIVENESS

B3W believes that art has the power to create change in any community.

To solidify a successful run of “FORGIVENESS - Part I: Forgiving the Personal” performances at Tribeca Performing Arts Center from May 20 to 22, 2016 in New York City, contribute to our fundraising goal of $10,050, and help make ends meet with our $32,000 production budget. Take a look at our budget, in detail, below.

Your gracious contribution to Part I of The FORGIVENESS Project will go towards:

  • Artistic Collaborators ($9000)
    B3W will bring together original sound composition, scenic design and projection mapping, writings and movement.
  • Performer Fees ($11,500)
    Each performer gets a minimum wage of $15 per hour for 122 hours of rehearsal time ($1,830), plus a $750 (3 performances at $250 each) Performance Fee for their time devoted to the project (totaling $2,080 each performer).

  • Production and Set Design, Lighting Designer, Costumes ($4,500)
    Make our interactive set come to life, by contributing to design and materials.

  • Rehearsal Space Rentals ($1,500)
    In total, we will have rehearsed a total of 122 hours in preparation for FORGIVENESS - Part I.

  • Live Feed with 3-Camera Shoot ($1,750 + $3,400)
    In an effort to continue the conversation on a global scale, B3W will live stream the Friday, May 20, 2016 performance to participants from FORGIVENESS Community Workshops to see consequences from their experiences on the stage.

  • Plus, the little things ($2,000+)
    Sponsored Facebook ads, Press Kit printing, percentage fees to Indiegogo, credit cards, fiscal sponsor, and more.

Other supporting funds for FORGIVENESS - Part I include resources from our presenting venue, Tribeca Performing Arts Center, in addition to Lower Manhattan Cultural Council, and PSC-CUNY Research Grant, and The Field through the Field Leadership Fund, however, these supporting funds only cover a portion of our budget for the production of this work.


SURPASS OUR EXPECTATIONS + TAKE US ABROAD

Get B3W past our initial fundraising goal of $10,050, and become a part of our international journey! Any additional contributions received beyond our initial $10,050 fundraising goal will go towards international touring of “FORGIVENESS - Part I” to be scheduled in 2017 in Asia and Africa, including air travel, per diem, and more.

FORGIVE AND FORGET? (WE HOPE NOT!)

"I have more courage to love, and believe love in the world is much greater than I thought." -  A workshop participant from Beijing, China
Hearing stories from different people around the world has led us to dig deeper into ourselves as impactful and thoughtful artmakers on the theme of forgiveness: what it means to us; how it affects our local, national, and global communities; and how it can have an impact on us individually and collectively as a whole. We hope that you will be a part of our journey on forgiveness, as well as be a part of the legacy, as we delve into different areas of forgiving in the next few years to come.


WITH FORGIVING, COMES REWARD

As a token of our appreciation, we want to thank you for your thoughtfulness and encouragement to bring The FORGIVENESS Project to it’s next phase! 
A few thank you gifts include:
  • VIP tickets to FORGIVENESS - Part I: Forgiving the Personal from May 20 to 22, 2016 at BMCC Tribeca Performing Arts Center
  • 75-minute Thai Bodywork Sessions with Sara Roer, performer of B3W
  • Creative Access and participation in discussion during the initial rehearsal process for Part II of FORGIVENESS
  • Souvenir keepsakes from Emily's travels abroad during The FORGIVENESS Community Workshops
  • 5" x 5" in prints from the country of your choice during Emily's travels
  • Acknowledgement in our Programs and Website
  • + More! Check out in detail our gifts to you, to the right --->


TAX DEDUCTIBLE?

Interested in our project, but would like your contribution to be tax-deductible? Contribute on our fiscal sponsor page at the Field, by going to this link: http://bit.ly/1qYTD1k.

A LITTLE GOES A LONG WAY...

If you're unable to make a monetary contribution to the project, please consider sharing this information with your friends and family on social media by sharing this page. And if you live in the New York City area, consider purchasing a ticket at this link to join us for the premiere of "FORGIVENESS - Part I: Forgiving the Personal" from May 20 to 22, 2016.

Add us on Facebook - Twitter - Instagram, and follow our journey by checking out #b3wforgiveness.


VIDEO INFORMATION
Music: "19" by An Ending Ascend
First video clip of B3W in rehearsal. 
Other video clips from FORGIVENESS Community Workshop interviews (in order of appearance) from Edinburgh, Scotland; Copenhagen, Denmark; Grahamstown, South Africa; Athens, Greece; Johannesburg, South Africa; Portici, Italy.
Video editing: Alexis Convento

story:
About The Jungle Book: Cobwebs and Moontalk

Strung Up tell stories that are messy and boisterous and fun. We find pre-loved tales and reimagine them in forests, bedrooms, tents and back gardens. We tell tales of philosophers and misfits, people who live on the fringes and always ask ‘What if…?’. 

We work with an eclectic group of performers who bring their unique combination of skills to the creation of each story. This can be everything from poetry, music and singing to puppetry, dance and aerials acrobatics! 

The Jungle Book: Cobwebs and Moontalk is a brand new adaptation of the much loved The Jungle Book, premiering at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival this summer. We are placing Kipling's curious daughter, Elsie, at the heart of the story. Against her father's sternest instructions, she sets out on an adventure into the darkness of the jungle and discovers a world of mysterious creatures and mythical laws. 

What We Need

£100 on aerial equipment. It's important that our aerial silks and hoop are safe for the performers to use, this money will go towards extra rigging equipment and upkeep of the silks throughout the run. 

£400 on the creative team. Our performers are the life and soul of the production (They're throwing every they can into this- from composing, writing and singing to dance and aerial acrobatics!). They are working every spare hour they have to make the show a success so this money will go towards supporting them with accommodation and travel costs throughout the run. 

No matter the amount, we would like to thank you personally so please leave your name!

Any money raised above the goal will continue to go towards supporting our cast with their travel and accommodation costs for the run.  

The Impact

Any donation you make will support us to create family theatre that is thoughtful, challenging, engaging and lots of fun. 

It will also support our key aim: that finances should never be a barrier to being involved in our productions.  Our performers are working every spare hour to make the show a reality, as well as studying and working other jobs, any contributions will directly help them with travel and accommodation costs. 

Risks & Challenges

Getting in an audience at the Edinburgh Fringe is notoriously hard. We're aware of this and the challenges of marketing a show that is in competition with hundreds of others. 

We have a strong history of success at the Fringe. Our previous show, Chaucer All Strung Up, enjoyed a sell-out run and glowing reviews. We know that our unique blend of literature with aerial acrobatics and live music will stand out at the Fringe and draw in a wide family audience. 

Other Ways You Can Help

There are loads of ways you can help us out! 

  • Share the campaign on your facebook page- please help spread the word!
  • Come and see the show! We'd love for you to come, tickets can be bought at http://www.cthefestival.com/2016/the-jungle-book-cobwebs-and-moontalk. Dates are 4-21 August, 3.45pm at C South
  • If you are interested in become one of our 'patrons' and setting up a donation monthly or per show, please find out more here: http://strungup-theatrecompany.com/get-involved/support-us.html

story:
(Para español, ve más abajo)

Résumé

Bonjour,

Je m’appelle Ruth Salama. Je suis née à Barcelone et ça fait déjà quelques années que je travaille entre la France et l’Espagne.

Je fais du cirque, du funambule et de l’aérien aux tissus. J’ai traversé sur le fil avec mon balancier des fleuves et fait des ascensions aux clochers des églises. Sous le chapiteau du cirque, j’ai tourné avec un numéro de danse sur le fil, comme fil de fériste. En France, j’ai découvert le cirque contemporain, donc, j’invente des histoires que je raconte à l’aide du fil, les tissus… Ça, c’est la partie cirque de ma vie.

L’autre partie de ma vie, c’est le flamenco que j’ai appris à danser quand j’étais enfant. La danse ne m’a jamais abandonné et moi, je n’ai jamais abandonné la danse. J’adore le flamenco, c’est ma drogue!

Le spectacle “Quiroquo flamenco”, « Locura flamenca » en espagnol, est notre nouveau projet : la rencontre du clown et du flamenco. Du burlesque et du flamenco avec, sur scène, moi et Roman « el afilao » avec le regard complice de Gino, du cirque la famille Morallès.

Cette création mêlant burlesque et art flamenco est fait avec un immense amour et respect , mais avec un grain de follie . Une danseuse naïve et bavarde, maladroite avec ses éventails et ses robes, un musicien à l’humour anglais qui suit sa danseuse comme il peut…Ces personnages sont les ingrédients que le clown utilise pour créer de la poésie et révéler une autre image du flamenco, loin des sentiers battus.

  • Equipe artistique: Ruth Salama, Roman “el afilao”, Gino Moralles
  • Costumes: Cara Murfin
  • Lumières et son: Franck Biard, Laura Boutilly.
  • Graphisme : Les presses du bocage, Gorron.
  • Communication: Joseph de la Paz, Toc-toc diffusion
  • Conseil chorégraphique: école de danse Paca Garcia, Barcelone.


Nos besoins

C’est la première fois que nous lançons une campagne de financement participatif.

Nous travaillons en Mayenne, une zone rurale près de la Bretagne française et nous avons besoin des temps de répétition pour créer et le temps c’est de l’argent !

En plus, les professionnels sollicités ont besoin d’être payés pour s’impliquer dans ce projet et pas dans un autre ! Bref, ce sont des professionnels.

Nous avons par le moment, trois théâtres coproducteurs et nous avons reçu une subvention mais ce n’est pas assez.

Pour arriver à la première avec sérénité, le 21 mai, avec un spectacle susceptible d’être acheté par les programmateurs et les théâtres, nous avons besoin de récolter 5000 €.

Avec cet argent, nous pourrons payer les artistes, les costumes, l’affiche, des micros spécifiques pour la guitare…

Si nous ne réussissons pas à récolter la totalité nous investirons surtout dans salaires et la communication.

Si nous récoltons plus, nous investirons surtout en une chargée de diffusion pour faire tourner le spectacle après la première.


L’impacte

Nous sommes une petite compagnie , Le cirque perdu, installée en zone qui fait partie des déserts ruraux du pays…

Il y a des grandes salles polyvalentes, mais souvent il n’y a pas de spectacles. Nous faisons des spectacles dans des lieux insolites et dans des petites villes. Nous amenons culture et art là où nous nous posons, là où les institutions de l’état ne sont pas présentes.

Nous sommes indépendants artistiquement et politiquement. Nous créons un peu d’emploi quand même, dans notre territoire, faisant appel aux artisans et commerçants de proximité.

Des spectacles mêlant burlesque et flamenco, il y en a pas à ma connaissance… pas encore !

Nous sommes dans la dernière ligne droite à 1 mois de la première, le 21 mai.

La prochaine répétition avec public aura lieu le 15 avril à l’espace culturel Colmont à Gorron, à 18h.


D’autres façons de donner un coup de pouce

Si ce projet te plaît, aide nous à diffuser cette campagne : partage la, s’il te plaît.

Si le flamenco ne t’emballe pas, pense que cette création aborde cet art de manière originale et inattendue, tendre et avec un clin d’œil…clownesquement !

Si tu ne peux pas contribuer financièrement, mais tu veux nous aider, bienvenu ! Si tu as des connaissances en graphisme, photographie, informatique, si tu as des contactes, un ami producteur, une adresse… n’hésite pas.

Tout ce que tu nous apporteras signifie beaucoup pour nous. Chaque grain de sable aide et nous donne des forces ! Ecris à cirqueperdu@ruthsalama.com

Ton aide est vitale. Avec créativité et ingéniosité nous y arriverons. Merci infiniment!


Resumen

¡Hola! 

Me llamo Ruth Salama, he nacido en Barcelona, y llevo años trabajando entre Francia y Barcelona.

Hago circo. He hecho funambulismo a gran altura cruzando ríos y plazas encima de un cable. Bajo la carpa del circo he girado con un número de danza en la cuerda tensa en varios circos en Europa. En Francia descubrí el circo contemporáneo así que invento historias que cuento con el cable, con las telas… Esta es la parte circo de mi vida.

Mi otra parte es el flamenco que aprendí a bailar cuando era una niña. Ni eso me ha abandonado nunca, ni yo he dejado de bailar. Me chifla el flamenco, soy adicta.

El espectáculo” Locura flamenca”, (Quiproquo Flamenco en francés) es nuestro nuevo proyecto: clown y flamenco. Humor y arte flamenco, con el guitarrista Roman “el afilao” y la mirada externa de Gino, del circo: la familia Moralles.

El proyecto rebosa amor y respeto a este arte, pero le añadimos mucha locura: una bata de cola mágica, unos abanicos sorprendentes, unas castañuelas despistadas... Estos son los ingredientes. El clown lo guisa a su manera con ingenuidad, poesía y humanidad.

  • Equipo artístico: Ruth Salama, Roman " el afilao",  Gino Moralles
  • Trajes: Cara Murfin
  • Luces y sonido:Franck Biard, Laura Boutilly
  • Diseño gráfico: Presses du bocage.
  • Comunicación: Joseph  de la Paz, Toc-toc diffusion
  • Asesoramiento en baile flamenco: escuela de baile Paca Garcia


Lo que necesitamos

Es la primera vez que lanzamos una campaña así. Trabajamos en una zona rural en el noroeste de Francia, cerca de la Bretaña, y necesitamos tiempo para investigar, experimentar, ligar la danza al clown y a la música. ¡Y el tiempo es dinero! Además, los profesionales con los que colaboramos necesitan cobrar para implicarse en este proyecto y no en otro.

Tenemos tres teatros coproductores y hemos recibido subvenciones, pero no es suficiente.

Para llegar con serenidad al estreno en mayo con un buen producto que después salga de gira, necesitamos recaudar 5000 €.

Con esta suma podremos pagar a nuestros colaboradores, artistas, trajes, escenografía, diseño de luces, diseño gráfico del poster, micrófonos específicos para el baile flamenco, etc.

Si no logramos la totalidad de la suma, invertiremos de forma básica en trajes, micrófonos y comunicación.

Si recaudamos más, podremos contratar una persona  para  la distribución del espectáculo  después del estreno.


Tu impacto

Somos una compañía pequeña instalada en una zona rural en Francia, llamada también desierto rural… Hay salas de actos y de deporte pero no hay funciones. Nosotros hacemos espectáculos en pequeñas ciudades y en lugares insólitos. Traemos poesía y arte a lugares donde las instituciones culturales oficiales no llegan. Somos artística y políticamente independientes. Además, creamos empleo en zonas donde las tiendas y las escuelas cierran sistemáticamente .

Nuestro último espectáculo, “Pista flamenca”, fue programado hace ya 5 años, y tuvimos que añadir dos días más, porque las entradas se habían agotado. La última vez que bailé en el auditorio del conservatorio de Mayenne, cuando salí a bailar y levanté la mirada, había gente sentada en el escenario, y en todas las escaleras…

Espectáculos de teatro o danza contemporánea, suele haber por aquí. Espectáculos de circo, de flamenco o que mezclen los dos, no hay... todavía.

Estamos de lleno en los ensayos, a menos de 3 meses del estreno, el 21 de mayo en Gorron.

El 17 de marzo tuvimos un showcase en el Centre Culturel Jovence.  La próxima presentación será en el teatro del estreno  en Gorron el 15 de abril a las 18h de la tarde.


Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar

Si este proyecto te gusta, ayúdanos a difundir esta campaña: compártela, por favor.

Si esto del flamenco ni fu ni fa, piensa que en este espectáculo se aborda el flamenco desde una perspectiva divertida y humana. En este sentido, es un espectáculo universal.

Lo que puedas contribuir con el proyecto, sea mucho o poco, significa muchísimo para nosotros. Cada granito de arena ayuda y nos da ánimos.

Si no puedes aportar dinero pero quieres ayudarnos, ¡bienvenido! Si tienes conocimientos de informática, sitios web, o si eres diseñador gráfico, o si tienes un contacto, un productor en algún lugar del mundo, o un dibujo, o un traje de flamenco que ya esté pasado de moda… Gracias. Escribe a cirque@ruthsalama.com

El camino está lleno de obstáculos. Pero con creatividad, ingenio e intuición, los superaremos todos. Tu ayuda es vital. ¡Muchas gracias!

story:
Hello again, friends and family!

As many of you know (and might have seen this past January), I have written, produced, and performed a one woman show called, "I Found That The Sun Will Rise Tomorrow", a funny and dramatic autobiography about my challenges with physical and mental illnesses through the lens of being an actor. The show was quite a success! So far, it has been accepted to five fringe festivals, and I will be performing in two of them-The Capital Fringe Festival in Washington, DC, and the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in Scotland! I am incredibly excited to take this show to the next level, but I need your help. I am planning on self-funding a large portion of the money that is needed to send me to these festivals on my own, but will not be able to make enough in time for both festivals, which are happening in July and August. This show is the most important thing to me- it means the world to me to be able to share my story with the world, and even with people who have struggled with similar issues but don't have the outlet to speak up about them. Please donate what you can- a dollar, five, ten! Make my dreams come true and help me get to these wonderful arts festivals!


Best, 

Anna

story:
YOU'RE MY BEST FRIEND: AN EVENING WITH PETER FREESTONE
CELEBRATING FREDDIE MERCURY'S 70TH BIRTHDAY
TICKETS @ www.peterfreestone.com/tour

I first met Peter Freestone, Freddie Mercury's best friend, personal assistant and biographer, in 2006 while touring the world as bass guitarist for Queen It's A Kinda Magic, a large-scale theatre reproduction of rock's most majestic band.

We got to know each other over many dinners, drinks and stories during a 6-month world tour dubbed 'The Freddie Mercury 60th Birthday Tour' which Peter had agreed to endorse at the time. As a Queen fan and performer of the band's music, I was very fortunate to be granted such rare and revealing insights into the life of the man who's music I loved.

Fast forward to 2016. Peter and I have remained friends over the intervening decade, running into each other in various cities around the world on our respective travels. My work in the music industry has lead me to a tour manager position for an Australian-based booking agency called First Base. 

And once again Peter has agreed to share his stories. This time with Australian audiences on a tour to celebrate what would have been Freddie’s 70th birthday in September 2016.

Presented by First Base Events, You’re My Best Friend: An Evening With Peter Freestone will be an intimate evening of personal stories, rock anecdotes, rare photos, unheard audio and audience Q&A covering the 12 years Peter spent living with and working for the Queen frontman.

The pair, who met in 1979 whilst Peter was working in wardrobe for London’s Royal Ballet, formed an immediate friendship which saw Peter become Freddie’s personal assistant, a role he continued daily until the singer’s untimely death in 1991.

Author of the memoir, Freddie Mercury (Omnibus Press), Peter currently resides in the Czech Republic, a place he has called home for the last 13 years between stints travelling the world to make regular guest speaking appearances at AIDS awareness events and Queen fan conventions.

In the lead up to the tour, Queen and Freddie Mercury fans will have the chance to pre-purchase merchandise and limited spots on private VIP events with Peter during his two weeks in Australia. This will be a unique opportunity to get up close and personal with the man who knew Freddie Mercury best.

On offer will be signed prints from Peter's private collection, signed copies of his book, Freddie Mercury: An Intimate Memoir, t-shirts, tour posters, fan Polaroids, and the piece de resistance: a very limited number of seats at either breakfast, lunch or dinner tables with Peter for various dates and cities during the tour.

This is a rare opportunity for Queen and Freddie fans to meet, spend time with and hear first hand accounts of their hero from one of the people who knew Freddie best - Peter Freestone:

“The whole world knew the musical genius, the master of the stage. For me he was also the kindest, most generous and loyal friend I could ever wish to have. 

I was Freddie's chief cook and bottle washer, waiter, butler, secretary, cleaner and agony aunt. I travelled the world with him, acted as his bodyguard when needed and in the end, of course, I was one of his nurses.”

So why are we doing this?

First and foremost, myself and my business partner at First Base are Queen fans. I ended up in a Queen tribute show and travelled the world simply because my absolute love of the band and their music lead me along that particular path of destiny. 

As booking agents we wanted to take that passion and turn it into a successful tour aimed squarely at the fans. In doing so, we have been hands on, from our initial proposal to Peter on Facebook ("Hey Phoebe, this year will be Freddie's 70th and we've started a booking agency. Wanna tour Australia to celebrate?") right up to booking the venues, organising national press and making sure that Peter's day to day needs will be met along the way.

As such we are underwriting all the expenses of a 2-week tour at our own financial risk; international flights to get Peter to Australia, appearance fees, marketing and promotion, venue hire, in-house production staff, domestic flights, accommodation in each city, daily meals, hire cars, fuel, parking, per diems, entertainment expenses, etc.

While we have secured some financial backing, it's still not the amount required to get us over the line to cover the initial tour set up and running expenses. Therefore, this campaign is all about inviting fans to be part of our journey and in the deal giving them access to something that they can't get elsewhere. 

By purchasing any of the perks we have on offer here at our campaign you will not only be rewarded with some amazing experiences, but you'll also be helping us to make this a successful tour and increasing our scope to make many more such tours in the future with people like Peter Freestone. In fact we've already reached out to one of David Bowie's former producers - watch this space.

All funds raised from our campaign will go toward tour running expenses. So head over to the'PERKS' section of this campaign and see what's available! All purchases can be made via credit card or Paypal.

We look forward to meeting some of you out on the road and hope that some of what we have on offer here can help make a wish or two come true for Queen and Freddie Mercury fans alike. Just as mine did many years before.

Thank you!

David Christopher
*First Base*

Ticket, venue and booking information for You're My Best Friend: An Evening With Peter Freestone is available at: www.peterfreestone.com/tour

TOURDATES

THU 8 SEP – HARMONIE GERMAN CLUB, CANBERRA
FRI 9 SEP – ILLAWARRA PERFORMING ARTS CENTRE, WOLLONGONG
SAT 10 SEP – THE PARAGON, KATOOMBA
SUN 11 SEP – LIZOTTE’S, NEWCASTLE
MON 12 SEP – JIVE BAR, ADELAIDE
TUE 13 SEP – THE BASEMENT, SYDNEY
THU 15 SEP – THORNBURY THEATRE, MELBOURNE
FRI 16 SEP – THE GRAND POOBAH, HOBART
SAT 17 SEP – THE LOFT @ CHEVRON ISLAND, GOLD COAST
MON 19 SEP – THE ZOO, BRISBANE
story_txt:
YOU'RE MY BEST FRIEND: AN EVENING WITH PETER FREESTONECELEBRATING FREDDIE MERCURY'S 70TH BIRTHDAYTICKETS @ www.peterfreestone.com/tour
I first met Peter Freestone, Freddie Mercury's best friend, personal assistant and biographer, in 2006 while touring the world as bass guitarist for Queen It's A Kinda Magic, a large-scale theatre reproduction of rock's most majestic band.


We got to know each other over many dinners, drinks and stories during a 6-month world tour dubbed 'The Freddie Mercury 60th Birthday Tour' which Peter had agreed to endorse at the time. As a Queen fan and performer of the band's music, I was very fortunate to be granted such rare and revealing insights into the life of the man who's music I loved.


Fast forward to 2016. Peter and I have remained friends over the intervening decade, running into each other in various cities around the world on our respective travels. My work in the music industry has lead me to a tour manager position for an Australian-based booking agency called First Base. 
And once again Peter has agreed to share his stories. This time with Australian audiences on a tour to celebrate what would have been Freddie’s 70th birthday in September 2016.
Presented
by First Base Events, You’re My Best Friend: An Evening With Peter Freestone will be an intimate evening of personal
stories, rock anecdotes, rare photos, unheard audio and audience Q&A
covering the 12 years Peter spent living with and working for the Queen
frontman.
The
pair, who met in 1979 whilst Peter was working in wardrobe for London’s Royal Ballet, formed an immediate
friendship which saw Peter become Freddie’s personal assistant, a role he
continued daily until the singer’s untimely
death in 1991.
Author
of the memoir, Freddie Mercury
(Omnibus Press), Peter currently resides in the Czech Republic,
a place he has called home for the last 13 years between stints travelling the
world to make regular guest speaking appearances at AIDS awareness events and
Queen fan conventions.


In the lead up to the tour, Queen and
Freddie Mercury fans will have the chance to pre-purchase merchandise and limited spots on
private VIP events with Peter during his two weeks in Australia. This will be a unique opportunity to get up
close and personal with the man who knew Freddie Mercury best.On offer will be signed prints from Peter's private collection, signed copies of his book, Freddie Mercury: An Intimate Memoir, t-shirts, tour posters, fan Polaroids, and the piece de resistance: a very limited number of seats at either breakfast, lunch or dinner tables with Peter for various dates and cities during the tour.
This is a rare opportunity for Queen and Freddie fans to meet, spend time with and hear first hand accounts of their hero from one of the people who knew Freddie best - Peter Freestone:

“The whole world knew the musical genius, the master
of the stage. For me he was also the
kindest, most generous and loyal friend I could ever wish to have. 
I was Freddie's chief cook and bottle washer, waiter,
butler, secretary, cleaner and agony aunt. I travelled the world with him,
acted as his bodyguard when needed and in the end, of course, I was one of his
nurses.”
So why are we doing this?
First and foremost, myself and my business partner at First Base are Queen fans. I ended up in a Queen tribute show and travelled the world simply because my absolute love of the band and their music lead me along that particular path of destiny. 
As booking agents we wanted to take that passion and turn it into a successful tour aimed squarely at the fans. In doing so, we have been hands on, from our initial proposal to Peter on Facebook ("Hey Phoebe, this year will be Freddie's 70th and we've started a booking agency. Wanna tour Australia to celebrate?") right up to booking the venues, organising national press and making sure that Peter's day to day needs will be met along the way.
As such we are underwriting all the expenses of a 2-week tour at our own financial risk; international flights to get Peter to Australia, appearance fees, marketing and promotion, venue hire, in-house production staff, domestic flights, accommodation in each city, daily meals, hire cars, fuel, parking, per diems, entertainment expenses, etc.
While we have secured some financial backing, it's still not the amount required to get us over the line to cover the initial tour set up and running expenses. Therefore, this campaign is all about inviting fans to be part of our journey and in the deal giving them access to something that they can't get elsewhere. 
By purchasing any of the perks we have on offer here at our campaign you will not only be rewarded with some amazing experiences, but you'll also be helping us to make this a successful tour and increasing our scope to make many more such tours in the future with people like Peter Freestone. In fact we've already reached out to one of David Bowie's former producers - watch this space.
All funds raised from our campaign will go toward tour running expenses. So head over to the'PERKS' section of this campaign and see what's available! All purchases can be made via credit card or Paypal.
We look forward to meeting some of you out on the road and hope that some of what we have on offer here can help make a wish or two come true for Queen and Freddie Mercury fans alike. Just as mine did many years before.
Thank you!David Christopher*First Base*
Ticket, venue and booking information for You're My Best Friend: An Evening With Peter Freestone is available at: www.peterfreestone.com/tour
TOURDATES
THU 8 SEP – HARMONIE GERMAN CLUB, CANBERRAFRI 9 SEP – ILLAWARRA PERFORMING ARTS CENTRE, WOLLONGONGSAT 10 SEP – THE PARAGON, KATOOMBASUN 11 SEP – LIZOTTE’S, NEWCASTLEMON 12 SEP – JIVE BAR, ADELAIDETUE 13 SEP – THE
BASEMENT, SYDNEYTHU 15 SEP –
THORNBURY THEATRE, MELBOURNEFRI 16 SEP – THE GRAND
POOBAH, HOBARTSAT 17 SEP – THE LOFT @ CHEVRON ISLAND, GOLD COASTMON 19 SEP – THE ZOO,
BRISBANE

story:
WHO WE ARE & WHAT WE'RE DOING

  • Clear Theater Collective is a new theater company in Williamsburg, Virginia, made up of former and current students of Naomi Marrow and Backstage Productions, a staple of Williamsburg theater since 1999. 
  • For our inaugural production, we are producing Neil Simon's iconic comedy, "The Odd Couple" in a show that is produced, directed, and performed by the Collective as a whole.
  • CTC's "Odd Couple" Indiegogo campaign is about one thing: Putting on a great show that is completely free to our audiences!
  • We believe that free local theater is a necessity, not a luxury. Your donations will make it possible for up to 500+ audience members 
  • All members of the cast and crew are volunteers! 100% of your donations go towards paying for the expenses of producing "The Odd Couple". 

WHAT WE NEED & WHAT YOU GET

  • Our fundraising goal of $800 covers the following: Performance rights ($250), venue rental ($275), props and costumes ($150), as well as printing and advertising costs ($125).
  • Some of the perks for donating: You can get your name in the show program, reserved seating, shout outs before each performance and on social media, a Producer credit and even be IN the show!

YOUR IMPACT

  • As former students and members of Backstage Productions, which has been performing free plays and musicals regularly in Williamsburg for 17 years under the leadership of Naomi Marrow, the importance of theater being provided for free as a community service was instilled in us from the beginning, and influenced our philosophy in starting the company.
  • For too many people, seeing live theater is a luxury that many cannot afford. Clear Theater Collective wants to make it possible for anyone to see unique and innovative theater, completely free. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

1) Come see the show! August 10th and 11th, 6:30 p.m. at the Williamsburg Regional Library in Williamsburg, VA. Even if you can't donate, we still want you there!

2) Bring your friends and family! 

3) Spread the word about the show and our Indiegogo campaign! Share this link and help us get the word out.

story:
The Name of the Game:

Is World Domination.
My name is Catherine Waller and I am the creator of "The Creeps", an award winning dark solo clown show that has been accepted into 3 of the most prestigious theatre festivals in the world. I was born in New Zealand and trained at Toi Whakaari: the New Zealand National Drama school, where I learnt and fell in love with the art of clowning and bouffon (dark clown). In 2014 I devised The Creeps as part of the Hollywood Fringe Festival and received awards such as Best Female Performer and Producer's Encore Award.
Now, I'm taking it on tour.
It has been a dream of mine to work as an artist on a global scale since I graduated school. I am a passionate story teller, a driven performer, and someone who is committed to impacting the world on a global scale by making moving, visceral and beautiful art. I have the capacity and the commitment to achieve all I've ever wanted for myself and my life. I want to be A World Renowned Superstar, and I want you to help me.
On August 1st, my producer Elle Shaw and I will fly from Los Angeles to Scotland where I will perform 6 shows in the Edinburgh Fringe Festival. We then travel to London where I perform in the Camden Fringe. We will travel through Europe by train and then fly to New York City to perform in the New York Clown Festival, before going to Boston to perform, back to LA, then back to New York in October to perform in the United Solo Festival; the largest solo festival in the world, on 42nd street in Times Square of New York City.
I told myself 4 years ago I wanted to take my show to Broadway, and for it to actually be happening, is almost unbelievable.
What we need to do this is $25,000, and your help.

“Catherine Waller has created a piece of art in the truest sense of the word. For 45 minutes you are glued to your seat watching her transform from one character to another in a dark world. One second there’s humor and the next a glimmer into the depressing reality of this underworld she’s created using only herself. She wonderfully inhabits the empty space, bringing it to life through her physicality within the space. Her performance is fearless and moving and even in its extremities it is laced with heartfelt truth and comedy. This show is proof that there is still creativity and wonderful originality in theatre.” -Eve Danzeisen

What We Need & What You Get

Our budget for this tour is $25,000.
This is will cover flights and accommodation for 2, to all cities we are traveling to; theatre rentals; festival registration fees; technical support (technician fees); insurance; food; transportation; marketing and distribution (posters, pamphlets, programmes, printing costs); and per diems for us. 
Our Perks:
$25: A special thanks on Social Media!
$60: A special thanks on The Creeps website! www.thecreepsplay.com
$100: A personal message from one of The Creeps.
$250: 2 Tickets to a show in your nearest city. (Hollywood included)
$500: 2 Tickets to a show and a Creeps T- Shirt!
$1000: 2 Tickets, T- Shirt, 2 Drinks on me!
$5000: A virtual experience of the show! If you can't make it live, I'll record it live and you can watch it from the comfort of your living room.
$15,000: The Creeps is taking you out on the town GURL.
$25,000: Are you serious? ANYTHING.
Every penny of what you contribute will go towards our travel and theater needs. Everything towards World Domination.
"A true actor and chameleon, seamlessly changing characters all while pushing the audience out of their comfort zone and bringing attention to an ongoing social disregard for mental health" - Julia Porter

What is The Creeps? And how does it impact?

The Creeps is a dark, visceral, emotional and physical clown show where I play 5 characters, all completely different in their physical traits, who all exist in a lonely and mysterious world, and who all interact directly with audience. The show is transformative, interactive, and personal, and offers a unique experience for an audience that is truly alive. In fact, I literally demand the audience is a part of it. The reason why I love this show so much, and why I believe it can exist on an international level, is because I am providing a transformative experience, one that is odd and absurd and yet to its core is about humanity and connection. It provokes the question: "What is theater in 2016?" and how can a simple solo black box show provide such a potent experience. I'm on a mission to find out.
Reviews of the show, and the impact it has had on audiences:
"Catherine schizophrenically slips from one character to the next, pulling us through the rooms of the asylum she effortlessly creates. You have no choice but to go along and be teased, seduced, intimidated, and entertained."  - Alek Tomkiw
“Catherine Waller is a creature apart. In her new solo show THE CREEPS she manages to summon four highly distinct personalities that will seer themselves into your mind for days and days to come. I don’t want to give anything away but the title is a perfect description of the vibe from beginning to end. Her body morphs almost supernaturally into distinct personalities so pathetic, disturbed and disturbingly relatable. At times it feels like a horror movie – by horror I mean the horrors of the soul and the mirror is constantly turned on the audience in its interactive format. She crawls around the floor doing things with light and sound that are so perfectly timed that she seems to surpass the physical world entirely." - Michael Shaw Fisher

“THE CREEPS was a superb show that I wish I would’ve caught before its closing night. The Creeps follows 4 characters and leaves you at the edge of your seat the whole time. Catherine Waller is an absolute genius in combining a comedy with dark truths whilst breaking the fourth wall and interacting in conversation with the audience. I never knew one person could bring so many emotions to me in a 45-minute production.  The lighting was creative and accented the mood entirely. The background noise brought the show to life and though it was just a plain black box theatre, the set was perfect. Waller has core strength beyond belief and used her dance background throughout the show in lyrical ways. It was honestly such an amazing experience, watching a show where I could ask questions and access the minds of the characters, and it was so perfectly timed in how Waller would say open ended things compelling you to speak up and ask.  Throughout the story, one of the characters said repeatedly “I’ve got what you want” and Waller gave just that. Waller gave me everything I’ve wanted to see in a show before I even knew what I wanted to see, and I can’t stress enough how much I wish there were more shows so I could go again and bring more people, and with such an interactive show, it could’ve been completely different the next time. Swag.” -Marcus Wells

“Distortion reveals—-darkness liberates—-hysteria serves as the foot soldier of truth. THE CREEPS forces us to confront our broken counterparts.  Talk, literally talk, to creatures that don’t exist, funneled through one woman metamorphosing into vastly different physical and psychological figures in the space of a blackout.  Catherine Waller frees these creeps from the corner of your eyes and the edges of your limbic system. In this dark comedy, you laugh as your hair stands on end, trying to escape.  Intentions turn ambiguous, reality shifts in a moment, and paradoxes dance—-when the most hospitable is the most sinister, when the most pathetic is the most noble, when the most exploited is the most in need, when the most battered is the most cruel.  Twisted by their own evil or their own need for salvation, each creep is both abuser and abused: Cast-offs, relegated/exiled to a basement of terrors where modern-day and fairy-tale detritus decay in the same heap.  Anything can happen, because the creeps can see you. You can’t hide. You’re paralyzed in your chair.  You think: I can’t become one of these creeps. I have to get out of here. I can’t be associated with them. And as they treat you as their own, you feel yourself distorting, disintegrating, becoming grotesque.  Will you listen to the evil and fall for it? Will you embrace the good, even if it is damaged, infected, deadly? Can you save anyone? Will you dare? Can you save yourself?  THE CREEPS are isolated——they enjoy the company——but you might not be able to leave. They might keep you there forever. Indulge them, and let them mingle with your own enigmas, demons and malformations.  You will leave relieved. At least you’re not doomed, controlled, locked in eternal pain and confusion like the creeps.  Except we are. And that’s the comedy of “The Creeps.””-Isaac Mell

“My only regret is that I didn’t see this show earlier in its run because I would’ve seen it again and again and again. I’ve tried to start this review many times but can’t seem to find the words to justly describe how amazing the world was that Catherine Waller created. Her performance was genuine and perfect and present and everything great acting should be. I don’t think anyone in that theatre wanted it to end. As I said to her after seeing the show, my mind was blown.” -Courtney Cunningham

Risks & Challenges

If we do not reach our goal we will create new pathways to fundraise the money we need to tour, such as private investments and art grants. The challenge with this is making sure we have it in time to book our flights, accommodation, and completing payments to all theatres by the date we have agreed to. However, this tour is happening! And we are unstoppable! We will do what it takes to fulfil on our goal and it will happen in its perfect way. Your contribution will ensure forward momentum and completion of our goal.

Thank you for your contribution!

By taking the time to read this campaign you have already helped. My request is, if you cannot contribute financially, that you keep the possibility of this conversation alive, and you share this with 10 people. Yes, you!
With your leadership, by the time I perform my first show, this campaign will have reached and impacted the whole world, and people will already know The Creeps.
Thank you so much for your unrelenting and consistant support for me. Truly, I am so, so, so grateful for all of you.
Thank you for playing this game with me! 
The tour starts now!

story:
About the Project

Setesdal Collective are a theatre group fresh out of Rose Bruford College of Theatre & Performance, who have made a few bits of experimental theatre, and want to take them around town.

In a summer, a long long time ago (2015) Markus Tarasenko Fadum stayed at Johnathon Parkins' mum's house whilst working in Manchester. In lieu of payment, Johnathon suggested the two work together, and the eventual result was The Eternal Kiss, a dance beat thumping look at how David Bowie and Steve Reich could be connected to the mating rituals of the anglerfish.  It triumphed in ways other fish based rave/ballets could only dream of, and will be at Bred In The Bone Theatre Laboratory's Dreams Before Dawn Festival in July in Paris. 

                                                       Photos by Ryan Lawrence

Meanwhile, Johnathon had enlisted the help of Markus, Kristine Grændsen and Marie-Laure Hay among others to make Burgsdagsfest, a show focusing on love, relationships and David Bowie as two dead-pan daters struggled to stay serious. This has been accepted to the prestigious Summerhall venue at the Edinburgh Fringe and also to Bred In The Bone Theatre Laboratory's Dreams Before Dawn Festival. 

                                               Photos by Michael O'Reilly

We have venues, actors, and even UV paint, but sadly this is not enough. With your support and generosity we can make this summer a reality. 


What Your Money Will Buy

Your donations will go toward the essentials of taking our show to France and back, in particular:

  • Hiring specialist equipment that needs to be rented and transported for several weeks. 
  • Travel from Norway for Markus and Kristine, as well as train fare and accommodation to take the shows on the road.
  • Marketing and publicity for the shows.
  • A bit left over for food, maybe just a pain au raisin. 

Risks & Challenges

We are already booked into these shows, and it would be awful to let producers and fellow artists down, who have invested time and love into us, and have matched your generosity in so many ways. However, if you wish to know more about how your money is helping, please don't hesitate to email Johnathon at jparkins018@gmail.com, and he'll get back to you. 

Other Ways You Can Help

You can still help by sharing this page, and telling anyone you think may be interested...if nothing else, come to the shows and we can share a Cornetto together xx
story_txt:
About the Project
Setesdal Collective are a theatre group fresh out of Rose Bruford College of Theatre & Performance, who have made a few bits of experimental theatre, and want to take them around town.
In a summer, a long long time ago (2015) Markus Tarasenko Fadum stayed at Johnathon Parkins' mum's house whilst working in Manchester. In lieu of payment, Johnathon suggested the two work together, and the eventual result was The Eternal Kiss, a dance beat thumping look at how David Bowie and Steve Reich could be connected to the mating rituals of the anglerfish.  It triumphed in ways other fish based rave/ballets could only dream of, and will be at Bred In The Bone Theatre Laboratory's Dreams Before Dawn Festival in July in Paris. 



                                                       Photos by Ryan LawrenceMeanwhile, Johnathon had enlisted the help of Markus, Kristine Grændsen and Marie-Laure Hay among others to make Burgsdagsfest, a show focusing on love, relationships and David Bowie as two dead-pan daters struggled to stay serious. This has been accepted to the prestigious Summerhall venue at the Edinburgh Fringe and also to Bred In The Bone Theatre Laboratory's Dreams Before Dawn Festival. 



                                               Photos by Michael O'ReillyWe have venues, actors, and even UV paint, but sadly this is not enough. With your support and generosity we can make this summer a reality. 
   What Your Money Will Buy Your donations will go toward the essentials of taking our show to France and back, in particular:  Hiring specialist equipment that needs to be rented and transported for several weeks.  Travel from Norway for Markus and Kristine, as well as train fare and accommodation to take the shows on the road.
Marketing and publicity for the shows. A bit left over for food, maybe just a pain au raisin. 


    Risks & Challenges We are already booked into these shows, and it would be awful to let producers and fellow artists down, who have invested time and love into us, and have matched your generosity in so many ways. However, if you wish to know more about how your money is helping, please don't hesitate to email Johnathon at jparkins018@gmail.com, and he'll get back to you. 
    Other Ways You Can Help You can still help by sharing this page, and telling anyone you think may be interested...if nothing else, come to the shows and we can share a Cornetto together xx

story:
in a nutshell

Gutted is a play written by Sharon Byrne.

Three women working in a Dublin fish factory tell the stories of their lives - sometimes painfully tragic, sometimes shocking and funny. They swear and sing, transporting you away from the chill water and bloodied fish, with the music, social mores and politics of 1980's Ireland.

The fine and insightful team at the Marlowe Theatre, Canterbury, has invited Sharon Byrne to produce Gutted for seven whole performances from 21-25 February 2017.

 

we need to raise £2,000

 

 

We are working with talented actors and a committed production team including, an award-winning set designer and an expert technical crew.  What we need now, is a chance to pay our cast and crew in more than just fish. We need your help to raise £2,000 to produce Gutted in February 2017.

With your help we'll be able to pay for:

 

  • set design and build
  • costumes and props
  • PRS music licence
  • cast, stage manager & director pay and expenses
  • producer fees 

If we reach our stretch targets, 

The more we raise, the more we'll do. Exceeding our targets will help us to create opportunities to put Gutted on the road to other regional and London theatres. With your help we will be able to produce programmes, Gutted jewellery and make printed copies of the script available for our keen audience (in the theatre and here on Indiegogo). 

We are also applying for other Arts/Theatre grants, so we aren't putting all our eggs in the crowdfunding basket. The Marlowe Theatre is being incredibly supportive with a range of staffing, publicity, technical and rehearsal space support. 

to show you how good Gutted feels

Gutted: a feeling. When you miss an opportunity. When you lose a friend. When you feel betrayed and your heart is left in a bloody mess on the floor. You're gutted, but you know you have to go on. You've got one life and you're going to live it.

This play is about three women working in a fish factory in Dublin in the 1980s. Work here everyday and you'll understand why someone would want to talk about life outside - even if that life is difficult and the people you trust let you down. 

Everyone has dreams though. And this play is ultimately about surviving, thriving and a shared understanding of how gutted feels.

    because no-one can predict the future

    Our biggest risk if we don't achieve our funding target is that we won't be able to pay our cast and crew. We'd be gutted, they'd be gutted, and you? Well, maybe you'd be gutted too. Please help us to put on an amazing performance.

    We are looking at lots of ways to achieve our goal through a range of perks being made available through this crowdfunding campaign but also through networking and sales to the people and businesses we know:

    • Advertising & sponsorship packages
    • Gutted t-shirts and sweatshirts
    • Rehearsal insights
    • Script sales
    • Ticket sales
    • Applications to the Arts Council and other grant giving bodies

    but everyone can help

    We really appreciate your support, in what ever size or shape you can manage. Financial donations are vital, but so are tweets, Facebook shares, a chat online and even telling friends and family about Gutted. 

    Any help you can give us in spreading the word will be really appreciated.

    By the time February rolls arounds, we are hoping that as many of you as possible will be there to see the show for yourself - that's going to be the best support of all. And yes, there'll even be a licensed bar. Honestly, what's not to love about that?

story:
Short Summary

"We feel an absolute urgency to tell this story so it is remembered and never forgotten. So much of what happened in Sarajevo was about violence against difference. Without expressing our traumatized past we merely manifest war into our daily mentality. A mentality of destruction perpetuated into our homes as rape, into our friendships as betrayal and ultimately into our society as apathy. This story is about the endurance of the human spirit to overcome insurmountable acts of violence and hate. It brings a message of healing, history and love that is relevant not only on our own soil but to the world. “ - Aimee & Lidija

Cheers to Sarajevo has been invited to showcase in Austria as part of the renowned Strawanz Festival as well as the National Grahamstown Arts Festival. We need your support to ensure that the company of 8 are able to travel to these destinations and share our story. 


What We Need & What You Get

Your funding will contribute towards the following: 

$25 000

Austria:
1. Air travel for 8 people from Johannesburg to Austria.
2.Travel within Austria from the airport to Bregenzerwald. 
3.Transportation of set.
4. Per diem for a company of 8 (money provided for food on a daily basis.) 
5. Printing of advertising material. 
6.Visas for 5 company members. 

Grahamstown:
1. Renting of mini bus and trailer for company of 8 and set to travel from Johannesburg to Grahamstown. 
2. Accommodation for a company of 8.
3.Per diem for a company of 8.
4. Printing of advertising material.
5. Cost of venue rental.


We don't expect you to give us something for nothing :) Have a look at our perks to see the exciting rewards you get for your contribution. 

In the unfortunate instance that we do not reach our goal: 10% of what remains will go towards The Villa of Hope Orphanage in Johannesburg, South Africa and the remainder will be put towards helping the show travel worldwide once sufficient funds are raised.  

The Impact

War and hate are themes that are perpetuated on the news daily.  Cheers to Sarajevo epitomizes the importance of compassion, forgiveness & love in a world that is submerged in fear, pain and discrimination. The power of theatre is to speak beyond the limitations of media, screens & print. This play touches the hearts of the enemy, reminding them that the man we kill is our brother, the women we rape is our mother and the children we maim, they are the future of our humanity. 

"As a series of personal and political conflicts take over, the audience is taken into the heart of Sarajevo where beneath the rubble of war, the spirit of its people refuses to die. From reading the script last year to seeing the work in progress performance tonight, there has been some huge shifts. Judging by the way a full house audience was engaged with the play and gave it a rousing applause, I have no doubt that tonight's work in progress performances were the seeds from which a very successful production will grow. Hats off to the young company."  Ismail Mahomed - Artistic Director National Arts Festival

"I saw Cheers to Sarajevo last night and was blown away by this wonderful piece of theatre. This is a beautifully written, brilliantly performed, powerful, heart -wrenching piece of theatre that speaks about war and the division of communities. It has to be seen - GO SEE IT without delay! They deserve a world platform for this important work. May it grow and travel and be seen by millions!"  
Helen Iskander - Writer, Director & Teacher

"Having spent two years in Sarajevo during the war and the siege of the city, the performance never ceased to move me; even after I had seen the trailer several times, as well as portions of the rehearsals and multiple performances. The characters were entirely credible, down to detailed mannerisms and verbal expressions; and the ambience created by the set and the use of Bosnian music transported me to the terrifying reality of war-torn Sarajevo and the poignant relationships and inspiring human endurance I had encountered."
Anne Mariè Bezdrob - Former UN Peacekeeper in Bosnia. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, there are other ways you can help us. Direct people to our campaign page using the Indiegogo share tools. You can also like our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter. 

https://www.facebook.com/cheerstosarajevo

@Cheers2Sarajevo

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCpOogB-y0taBLo...

And that's all there is to it :)
